business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER(Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: CSIRO Clayton (Eastern Precinct) Development Works, Vic.

CSIRO proposes to consolidate the Victorian activities of its divisions of manufacturing science and technology, mathematics, information science, information technology services and petroleum resources at its Clayton site in Victoria. The consolidation and rationalisation of accommodation for CSIRO throughout Australia and replacement or refurbishment of outdated, substandard facilities are key elements of the CSIRO property management plan.

The project will enable CSIRO to vacate sites at Preston and Syndal, freeing up these sites for sale. It will also relocate staff and resources from leased premises at Carlton and Clayton into accommodation at the Clayton site, which is owned by CSIRO and is located adjacent to the campus of Monash University.

The Clayton site is one of CSIRO's largest sites and is occupied by more than 700 staff. It is the organisation's major Victorian site and the centre for CSIRO research into mineral, forest products, molecular and polymer science, manufacturing science and technology, and mathematical and information sciences.

The development will provide approximately 7,000 square metres gross floor area of new building accommodation, together with another 7,000 square metres of refurbishment in the 35-year-old, outdated and substandard `David Rivett' laboratories and provide accommodation for over 370 staff. The work will provide laboratories, offices, process and technical bays, research support facilities and staff amenities. The project has a budget of $28 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is expected to commence early in the year 2000, with completion scheduled for mid-2001. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 11 May.

para.inline: Senate's amendments—

subdebate.1.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 14, page 6 (after line 4), after the Table of Subdivisions, insert:

para.inline: Guide to Division 46
46-1 What this Division is about

subdebate.1.para: This Division allows a deduction, over 21/2 years, for capital and non-capital expenditure you incur in acquiring or developing software for your own use.
You may choose to pool such expenditure. This can help you to work out your deductions if it would be hard to attribute your costs to individual projects separately.

The Division also allows an immediate deduction for expenditure on software, incurred before 1 January 2000, to ensure that a computer system attains Year 2000 compliance. Immediate deductions are also allowed for minor expenditure and for expenditure on software that you decide never to use.

para.inline: [This is the end of the Guide.]

subdebate.1.para: (2) Schedule 1, item 14, page 6 (lines 19 to 34), omit all the words and examples after paragraph (c).
(3) Schedule 1, item 14, page 7 (after line 13), at the end of section 46-15 (after the example), add:
(2) This Division also does not apply to *expenditure on software if:
(a) you can get a deduction for the expenditure under a provision of this Act (including section 8-1) outside this Division; and
(b) the *software was acquired or developed other than principally for you to use to perform the functions for which it was acquired or developed.

Example 1: You incur capital expenditure in developing new software to use in controlling your mining operations. You would consider selling other similar businesses a licence to use the software, but this has not influenced your decision to develop it. This Division still applies to the expenditure, even though Division 330 (Mining and quarrying) might otherwise have applied to it, because you developed it principally to perform that function in your business; not principally as a product to sell to others.

Example 2: You incur expenditure in developing new software principally to sell to the general public, but you also incidentally plan to use the software in your own business. Assuming that the expenditure is also covered by section 8-1 (General deductions), this Division does not apply to it, because you developed the software principally to sell it to the public; not principally to use in-house.
(3) To avoid doubt, expenditure is excluded from the scope of this Division if it is covered by either or both of subsections (1) and (2).
(4) Schedule 1, item 14, page 7 (line 16), after "if", insert "(having taken into account the effect of section 46-15)".

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

The amendments will ensure that all expenditure on software will be deductible, either within new division 46 or elsewhere in the tax law. Following the original introduction of the bill into the House, the government received representations that there may be a small number of cases where taxpayers may not be able to obtain a deduction under any provision of the law, including new division 46, for expenditure on software. This would be an unsatisfactory outcome and the amendments will address that situation. The amendments represent yet another area where the government's commitment to consult on the new regime for software expenditure has provided a workable outcome.

talk.start.para: —These amendments were raised in the Senate following the expression of concerns that there could be a number of cases where taxpayers might not be able to obtain a deduction under any provision for expenditure on software. The opposition supported those amendments in the Senate and we intend to support them here also for the same reasons. They will ensure that all expenditure on software will be deductible either within the new division 46 or elsewhere in the tax law. In saying this I again record the opposition's concern that there is a flaw in this bill that no provision has been made for any software problems which get revealed when the year 2000—that dreaded year—comes in. It is our view that if businesses find, once Y2K happens, that they have some problems which need to be addressed then there ought to be a six-month period of grace in which they could still attract the benefits available through this depreciation legislation. We regret that the government has not seen fit to pick up our position on that. It is an issue that may need to be revisited at that time. We will be supporting these amendments.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Dr Kemp:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Lee moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"The bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for removal of the items which seek to impose voluntary student unionism, which will damage the interests of students, communities and the nation as a whole by
(1) undermining the independence of universities by imposing political conditions on Commonwealth grants;
(2) reducing student representation in an attempt to silence opposition to higher education funding cuts;
(3) slashing services available to students, such as child care, legal and employment advice, cafeterias and sporting facilities;
(4) placing a further financial burden on universities; and
(5) putting at risk community services, facilities and employment, particularly in regional areas."

talk.start.para: —The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

—It is interesting to follow in this debate the member for Lawler, who spoke late yesterday afternoon on the subject of the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 , particularly with respect to VSU because the member for Lawler coincidentally was the final President of the Australian Union of Students, that organisation that failed in the mid-1980s. There are some semblances of comparison between the member for Lawler and the last emperor of China, because he and she both presided over a vast, morally bankrupt, scandal ridden, inept and ultimately failed organisation—namely, in the case of the member for Lawler, the Australian Union of Students.

speech.para: This was an organisation, Mr Speaker, which during its time—probably not under the member for Lawler; hopefully, she would not have entertained such appalling practices—funded organisations like the Palestine Liberation Organisation and the Communist Party of Malaya, declared that marriage was a form of prostitution and gave money to the Shining Path organisation in Peru. This is the sort of organisation that the member for Lawler associated herself with as president in the 1980s. It was a mark of great victory for the non-Labor side of politics that, as students, they were able to defeat and ultimately close down the Australian Union of Students.

But, turning to this bill, the idea of compulsory associations strikes at the heart of every Liberal. All citizens should be free to choose whether or not they belong to an association. For too long university students have been denied this fundamental right. The bill pres ently before the House corrects this inequality and delivers the right to freedom of association to students. The coalition government, with the help of the Labor member for Dickson, has already extended the right of non-compulsory unionism to workers through the Workplace Relations Act 1996. The act did not benefit students, as they are not employees of the universities, but they are still entitled to the same right of freedom of association as is every other Australian, and yet the Labor Party and the student unions are trying to deny them that same right.

The coalition government is, on the other hand, committed to asserting the rights of students to freedom of association in the higher education sector. We believe that students should not be compelled to fund organisations that they do not support. Students deserve to enjoy the same rights on campus as they do off campus, and this legislation will ensure that they enjoy that right. Indeed, student unions are about the last group still claiming that they are entitled to compel people to belong to them. If the Labor Party wishes to participate in genuine policy development, it cannot continue to hoodwink Australians into believing that employees and students are incapable of understanding and protecting their own interests without the compulsory involvement of unions.

This bill also provides students with greater choice over what goods and services they buy. Consumer choice in what goods and services you can purchase is a right expected by most Australians. Student unions on most Australian campuses compulsorily acquire from students, as a condition of enrolment, an up-front fee to pay for services they may not need or wish to use. The fee can range from $90 to more than $300, as at Monash University, and over the course of a four-year degree it can amount to more than $1,000. Unlike HECS—the Higher Education Contribution Scheme—the student union fees cannot be deferred until such time as a student is financially able to pay them back, and they are the same for every student.

The timing of the fee is usually the time when students can least afford it. At the start of an academic year, students have many substantial and often competing costs such as textbooks and stationery. For some students, particularly those from rural areas, there are also accommodation costs such as tenancy bonds and furniture purchases to consider. Voluntary student unionism will put money back into the pockets of students so they can decide what sorts of services they want to spend their money on. Under the current system, the system that Labor supports, students do not have that choice. On most campuses, these decisions are made by the student body at the whim of the student union. Students deserve to enjoy the same consumer rights to purchase only the services they want on and off campus, and this legislation will ensure that they have that fundamental right.

At present, on most campuses students are forced to fund sporting facilities regardless of whether or not they play sport. Similarly, students are compelled to contribute to student entertainment irrespective of whether they have the time or the inclination to participate. At most universities it is mandatory for students to subsidise the regular publishing of union newspapers even though they may not read or subscribe to their views. What happens to students who challenge this compulsorily acquired up-front fee? Put simply, they are denied the opportunity to graduate at a university. This legislation will remove the last compulsory up-front fee charged at university entry to most Australian students.

But Labor's double standard on this is well documented. The 1998 election platform for higher education stated that `up-front undergraduate fees are undesirable' but then they contradicted themselves by also saying they opposed giving students freedom of association and supported the compulsory acquisition of student money. It is a case of complete hypocrisy. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs recently illustrated this point when he quoted the member for Werriwa saying:
I first read the document—
the higher education policy—
in the car going from the Frankston launch to Melbourne to go home.

Clearly the Labor Party has so little regard for his views that they chose not to even bother to give him the policy before the launch of the document. It is little wonder that the increasingly frustrated member for Werriwa has gone to the back bench—but only, I would imagine, for the meantime.

There is only the one compulsory up-front fee for most students, and the Labor Party stands behind that policy. There is no confusion with the coalition government's position. The bill before the House will remove a financial hurdle to higher education for students on low incomes. It is a much better system to allow students to manage their own financial affairs. Individual students are the ones who are best placed to know their own financial priorities. They are certainly better placed than the officials of student organisations. Voluntary student unionism will also lend itself to the financial flexibility of allowing students to spread their expenditure over the year, better reflecting the fact that their income is also spread over the year.

At present, most student unions are unrepresentative and unresponsive to the needs of the students they purport to represent. The legislation before the House will improve this situation by ending the monopolistic and uncompetitive features of student unions. The structures that are currently in place force students to pay for services they do not need or wish to use.

Compulsory student unionism also fails to recognise that the nature of university campuses has changed dramatically over the last decade. There is an increasing proportion of students who study part time or externally and are forced to pay for services they cannot use. In some instances, external students can be paying well over $200 a year for those inaccessible services. The failure of student unions generally to cater to the needs and interests of this increasing niche market is just one example of why we need to change the current arrangements. The challenge for student unions is to be responsive and representative of student needs. The status quo has certainly not achieved this.

The Western Australia state government sought to find a better system in 1994. Volun tary student unionism was introduced by that state in 1995 and, despite a brief disruption to its operation caused by the former Labor government's scandalous abuse of taxpayers' money through the notorious SOS legislation, it has proved to be successful. It has meant that student unions in Western Australia have had to be smarter in how they utilise their resources and in what they offer students. In Western Australia, the experience has been that student unions are following the student dollar by offering a range and a quality of services which are likely to be of value and benefit to students. For example, in 1994 the University of Western Australia student union offered 27 different types of services under compulsory student unionism, but in 1997 under voluntary student unionism the same student union was able to offer 45 different types of services.

Student unions have the ability to add to the unique culture of a university campus. Organising social events and activities and providing the infrastructure for a network of associations are some of the contributions that student unions have made and can make in the future. Student unions are also unique in being able to coordinate services targeted specifically for student needs. Voluntary student unionism will not only make student unions more accountable and transparent, it will ensure that they target these services to meet student needs. Under the government's policy initiative, student unions will fulfil their potential and add to the cultural dimensions of campus life while simultaneously preventing the profligate use of students' precious resources on causes or services that students neither want nor need.

Under the current system of compulsion, student unions provide so-called services such as newspapers which have in the past, in very recent times, explained to readers how to inject themselves with heroin, how to successfully shoplift and how to get away with drink-driving. This is the system that Labor stands behind and wants to protect.

Opponents of voluntary student unionism claim that the government is silencing student dissent. This is a gross distortion of the situation. The legislation before the House makes absolutely no reference to the silencing or restricting of freedom of speech. The fact is that universities are the cradle of leadership. There will always be student politicians and they will always be vocal and controversial. The opportunity to represent, to put forward ideas and to participate in the political process is what motivates student politicians, not modest honorariums—although in some cases they are not-so-modest honorariums.

Opponents of voluntary student unionism attempt to draw a correlation between taxes and student union fees. It is a superficial argument. Income earners are generally means tested to determine if they are in a financial position to contribute to the Treasury, which in turn finances things of universal benefit. With student union fees there is no means testing. Every student pays the same fee regardless of their station in life. Student union fees are not means tested or tiered in terms of liability. The poorest university student is liable for the same amount as the wealthiest.

As an adjunct to that argument, it is worth noting that, in Western Australia under voluntary student unionism, emergency loans and guild loans are still available at Edith Cowan University and the University of Western Australia respectively because those universities have decided that that is a service they want to provide their students and they want to subsidise that service out of their profit making services. That is exactly what student unions should be making the decisions about.

Many advocates of compulsory student unionism say that students currently have a form of voluntary student unionism in the shape of an option to be a conscientious objector, but they ignore the fact that the fee still has to be collected although it can be paid to a charity rather than the student union. But if you do not pay the fee you cannot graduate at the end of your university term. When I was at university, we had a student called Brendan Harradine who refused to pay his student fee and took the matter as far as the Supreme Court of South Australia. It was found that, if he did not pay the fee, he would not be able to collect his degree and practise as a lawyer—an absolutely despicable state of affairs.

Opponents of voluntary student unionism also peddle misleading arguments when they contest that student union fees are not applied for universal benefit. What do student unions do for part-time or external students in rural areas to justify fees of up to $200 or $300 a year? The benefits are not universal and, under compulsory student unionism, are applied to a mixture of worthy or in fact unrepresentative or indulgent interests.

The 1998 edition of The Australian Good Universities Guide to Australian Universities indicated that more than 150,000 Australians are studying externally through universities. At four of Australia's 38 public universities, there are more external enrolments at undergraduate level than on-campus enrolments. At Central Queensland University, which has its main campus in the member for Capricornia's electorate, 56 per cent of enrolled undergraduate students are studying externally. Nearly 80 per cent of postgraduate students at Central Queensland University are external students. So how can the compulsory fee be described as universal for all of those students, part time or external, who are not even on the campus to use the services—so-called—for their benefit?

talk.start.para: —Great point.

—Thank you. These figures are just scratching the surface. Part-time and mature age students are a significant group who do not always have direct access to the supposedly essential services provided by student unions. Australia is competing for fee paying external or full-time international students. The emphasis of their choice will be on the quality of education and the cost. We cannot expect to be completely competitive if we continue to slug external, part-time international students with union fees of a few hundred dollars a year. How can we justify asking external international students to pay compulsory fees to subsidise cafeterias, campus newspapers and entertainment for the rest of the student body, which they cannot access?

speech.para: Recently I was speaking at the Adelaide University on the subject of voluntary student unionism and, after a rather willing debate stacked with proponents of compulsory unionism, a German international student came up to a group of resistance people who were haranguing me and made the point that in Germany they have all the facilities for students that are provided at Australian universities. They have the campus life, the cafeterias and the sporting associations—they do all the things that we do—and they have never even considered having a compulsory fee to fund student unions. They just expect that students will be able to raise the money or that students will spend their consumer dollar in such a way that those services can be provided. He was bewildered that we still held to this outdated view that compulsion was required to have students participating in service provision.

Senator Natasha Stott Despoja has been very vocal in her support for compulsorily charging fees of between $90 and $350 a year. She claims to stand up for the interests of young people but in the next breath wants to slug university students with the only compulsory up-front fee that most students have to pay at university. A trademark of Senator Stott Despoja's career has been her ability to create a dislocation between appearance and reality. She argues that reforming compulsory unionism on campuses will contribute to a psychological disincentive for young people to participate in tertiary education. Is there any wonder that the public are taking her less and less seriously?

In considering where to study, students are far more likely to consider factors such as the reputation of the particular faculty and the university, the curriculum of the particular course of study, the possibility of postgraduate study, perhaps even the geographical location of the institution and, of course, the likelihood of getting a job after they have finished their university degree. The status of a university's student union is important only from the perspective of the student politicians who adhere to it. The compulsory nature of the university fee has no bearing on that culture. Indeed, Senator Stott Despoja's views on compulsory student unionism are at odds with the founder of her party, the Democrats, Don Chipp, who was a fervent supporter of non-compulsory student unionism.
I would like to draw the House's attention to some comments made by Senator Harradine in a committee hearing on the Australian National University Amendment Bill 1984 when he said:

I too am concerned about the history of payments made by certain student bodies for purposes other than the purposes for which these bodies were established, namely to protect and promote the welfare of students.
He also said:

Nevertheless, we are faced with a situation here in which a student could be compulsorily levied money which could be applied not for purposes associated with the rights, responsibilities or indeed the welfare of the students but for other party-political purposes or issues by ideologically motivated organisations.

Senator Harradine is right. In the course of his service to the parliament he has seen successive generations of student unions fail to adequately represent and provide welfare for students. The government's voluntary student unionism policy will address the concerns of Senator Harradine. I would hope that, when this bill comes before the Senate, Senator Harradine would support the government in the interests of students and in the interests of student unions.

By introducing VSU we will be helping student unions to be more relevant, more responsive and hence more popular with their students. Voluntary student unionism will allow student unions to fulfil their potential and will add to the cultural dimensions of campus life. But it will prevent the profligate use of students' precious resources on causes or services that students neither want nor need. By its very nature, VSU will make student unions more accountable and will lend itself to more transparent operations. Voluntary student unionism is about giving students choice in the associations they join and in the services they buy. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is interesting to follow the member for Sturt on this issue. He has a fascinating history. Despite his opposition to the notion of automatic membership and this deep concern that he professes about the uses of students' money, the member for Sturt was elected as the finance vice-president of the Adelaide University in 1986-87. This position meant that the member for Sturt was responsible for the stewardship of the finances of the student organisation. He was responsible, like his colleague the Treasurer is for the country, for looking after compulsorily acquired funds—in this case from students. Unfortunately, we do not know if his belief in compulsion is the same as that of the member for Higgins, but in participating, holding office and exercising power he was certainly complicit in it all.

speech.para: The member for Sturt was paid to do this job, paid from compulsorily acquired funds from the students. Given this great concern that he expresses about students wasting money, you would have expected him to conduct himself with the utmost of professionalism in his use of it. How did the member for Sturt conduct himself? Let me quote from the campus paper On Dit of 4 May 1987, from an article titled `Give back your pay finance VP'. It reads:
Students should be informed that on April 16th at the last Students Association Council meeting the Finance Vice-President, Mr Chris Pyne, had his honorarium revoked for neglect of duty.
The substantive argument was that Mr Pyne quite simply was never around the office to perform this function.
The article went on to report Mr Pyne's reaction:
. . . Mr Chris Pyne argued that once elected the Finance Vice-President, a paid office bearer, can act as he/she sees fit.

Isn't it extraordinary that here we have the member for Sturt arguing his private members motion on VSU and speaking again today saying things like `by its very nature VSU will make student unions more accountable and will lend itself to more transparent options,' given the personal contempt which he displayed for ordinary standards of accountability back in 1987? It is incredible that he can rise in this House to get stuck into `unaccountable student organisations'.

Not only that but the member for Sturt is now part of a government that has jacked up fees for students left, right and centre, cut funds for university and driven up HECS leaving students high and dry. Has the member for Sturt complained about these attacks on universities? No. Did he ring up his mates at Adelaide University and ask for some space in the campus newspaper, the way he used to have, to explain why he thought back then that a $275 charge was the end of the world but that gutting universities of some $820 million, slashing 21,000 places off forward estimates and driving up HECS was all right? I think not. Why did the member for Sturt not rise up against the massive cuts to education in the same way as he did back in 1987? Because, like this piece of legislation, it is really all about politics rather than about the best thing for students.

This issue came up when I served in the Victorian parliament some years ago. Although it is not easy to nail this particular furphy because `voluntary' is something that sounds good to everybody on first hearing, we did succeed in nailing it and, therefore, I think it is worth going through that particular piece of history. The key promoter of voluntary student unionism in Victoria was Robert Clark, the Liberal member for Box Hill and a former unsuccessful student politician. I wondered at the time whether he was not being impersonated by John Clark, doing a former student politician who could not leave his past behind and did not understand the real damage he was doing once he had risen to the dizzy heights of the Victorian parliament.

Robert Clark had an electorate officer by the name of Charles Richardson who went into bat for him at some of these VSU debates, and I want to quote from a couple of things that Charles Richardson said in support of voluntary student unionism. He said:
Nobody wants to close down the toilets in the Union Building or whatever. Those services will survive . . . They will be targeted more effectively to the students.

I have to say that back then some of us male students could have targeted ourselves more effectively at the toilets at university—but I do not know how the reverse could be done. Perhaps Mr Richardson was thinking of `real user pays', `pay as you go'. In relation to toilets, this is something that we had 50 or 100 years ago. I happen to think that moving on from that has been social progress.

Mr Richardson further went on to talk about the problem of `freeloaders', people getting benefits out of the union but not bothering to pay, not bothering to join—and this, of course, is a real problem with voluntary student unionism. He said:
In fact though it is possible to limit most of the union's services to people who have paid. You could reserve the Union to members only like private clubs do . . .

Once again this gives the game away. The Liberal side of politics have that exclusive Melbourne Club view of these things, and they just hate it whenever something is accessible to everybody. They are still hung up on exclusivity. Deep down, they still dislike what Gough Whitlam did back in the 1970s in opening up universities and tertiary education to ordinary people, such as those in my electorate of Wills. For the Liberal side of politics, voluntary student unionism is a combination of an ideological wet dream and political payback.

Voluntary student unionism is no different in character from voluntary payment of taxes, or voluntary payment of council rates, or voluntary payment of Premier Kennett's infamous state deficit levy. It does not take first-class honours at university to work out the shortcomings of voluntary payment of taxes. Mr Clark was not an advocate of voluntary payment of the state deficit levy because, if people had not volunteered to pay that levy, there might not have been enough money for the additional $10,000 a year which Mr Clark got paid as parliamentary secretary to the Victorian Treasurer, being part of one of Premier Kennett's expenditure initiatives. Premier Kennett enjoys a caucus which has been either bribed or bullied into acquiescence.

It is not that Victorian parliamentary secretaries are necessarily lazy or undeserving, mind you. When I was there, the Victorian parliamentary secretary for education, Stephen Elder, was running education in Victoria, which was a considerable relief for anyone who was aware of the performance of the minister, Don Hayward. It was a bit like some of the parliamentary secretaries here: saving their ministers from being discredited and making sure that the rest of the world does not have to worry about their performance.

Voluntary taxation: yes, theoretically we could have voluntary taxation. The Fraser Liberal government more or less did that during the 1970s, such was the proliferation of tax avoidance—and, from leaked documents that I brought to the attention of the House some weeks ago, there are some concerns that this is starting to happen again. But voluntary taxation is the same thing as doing away with tax altogether, because nobody would pay it if it were optional—just as voluntary student unionism means no student union, the death of the student union.

If tax were voluntary or non-existent, I could go and pay somebody to construct the piece of street outside of my house and pay somebody else to construct a piece of concrete next to it so that I had a footpath. I could even hire a private bodyguard to keep me safe, or at least a private investigator to recover my belongings in the event that they were stolen, and so on. A couple of hundred years ago, before welfare state or state socialism not only in Victoria but in Australia, many things did work this way. But there are problems. I do not have the time to do all those things myself—to hire the road maker or the footpath maker or the private investigator; I do not have the time to check their credentials or their workmanship or to sue them if they stuff things up. Even if my section of the road is perfect, what if my neighbour is too poor, or too lazy, or does not drive a car, or does not do his or her section, or does it in gravel instead? I do not want a patchwork quilt; I want a road that I can use.

So I find, and over the years whole communities have found, that it makes more sense to pool our money and have someone else look after these things so that we can get on with our lives and get on with the things that are important to us. That is how student unions also developed at the turn of the century. The services that they provide by and large represent better value for time and money than if individual students had to do all these things themselves—set up their own bush walking club, organise the building of a swimming pool, and so on.

The other possibility here is that everything gets done on a fee for service basis—and I guess the Liberal Party's health and other policies are going in this direction. It will not take too much more of Liberal Party government before ambulance drivers and doctors start asking for your cheque book before assisting you. Fee for service has some advantages. But the end result will be that less well patronised events—theatre, dance, concerts, and so on—simply disappear and universities and TAFE colleges become sadder, duller, grayer places.

Lower cost can be achieved, but with that comes lower quality. If that is what you want on campus, you just bring in Ronald McDonald and Colonel Sanders; I guess they are the experts in this area. Mind you, it ought to be said that student food perhaps is not the best argument for a student union. But the student union does provide important services: free dental service, student discount club cards, the organisation of campaigns against violence on campuses and things of that character.

This debate is really about whether we need student unions or whether we are better off on our own. Certainly when I was a student, I found university quite impersonal and intimidating; anything in the way of shared activities and a shared voice represented value for money.

At another perhaps more sinister level, this is a proposal from a Liberal Party obsessed with power and intent on crippling opposition or any independent source of influence or authority. In Victoria voluntary student unionism came after the sacking of the Law Reform Commission—for inquiring into a closed shop of all things—the sacking of the Accident Compensation Tribunal, the sacking of the equal opportunity commissioner, restrictions on freedom of information, intimidation of the 7.30 Report and the Sunday Age, attacks on Justices Nicholson and Fogarty, getting rid of the Director of Public Prosecutions, Bernard Bongiorno, the defunding of the Energy Action Group and the Victorian Council on Problem Gambling, the sacking of all the councils and the replacement with administrators, the attacks on trade unions and the abuse of parliament.

All of that came from a born-to-rule mentality and a manic determination to stamp out opposition from any and all quarters. And so it is here: the Howard government has proved to be little better. Recently I attended a protest meeting at the Coburg library concerning the Commonwealth Attorney-General's review of the function of the Victorian legal services. For those who are unaware, this review proposes a merging of the centres so that resources will be spread even thinner than they are now and a focus on the outputs so that the public interest work of the legal centres and legal services disappears.

As my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, the member for Barton, has pointed out to me, the Commonwealth government spends a paltry $5 million on funding legal services. This is not about saving money; it is about stifling and suppressing dissent. And so it is with student organisations. As student organisations represent a source of criticism from time to time, this government has determined that they must be crippled and crushed. This is what this bill is all about. It is not about some benign view of giving students choice.

By contrast, the National Union of Students and other student bodies used to be highly critical of the federal Labor government over HECS and other issues. Nevertheless, the Labor Party—and this is one of the conspicuous differences between us and those opposite—is big enough to take criticism and to tolerate dissent. We did not try to kill off student unions. It is this kind of arrogance and authoritarianism, a dislike of the pluralism and tolerance which, in the Labor Party's view, makes us a richer, more diverse, more successful community, just as much as the job shedding, the school closures and the like which caused Victorians to give up hope for the future of Victoria and move to the Labor states of Queensland and New South Wales at a rate exceeding 200 per day.

Voluntary student unionism is nothing more than an attempt by the Liberal government to shut students up and keep them passive and in their place, egged on by former Liberal students seeking revenge after being perpetual losers in student politics. After we fought the good fight in Victoria, the government were forced to amend their legislation. But they did end up with a hastily cobbled together compromise riddled with anomalies. So we have a situation where overseas students could achieve representation but not local ones and students could run their own TV or radio services but not newspapers. So student cultural activities were all right but not student political ones. It was a bit like Eastern Europe before the Berlin Wall came down. We ended up with a situation where the students were taxed but did not have a right to effective representation—the exact opposite of what this government is claiming for its legislation.
Claude Forell in the Age some years ago belled the cat in a piece on voluntary student unionism. In the article, after asking why the government was doing all of this, he stated:

The clue is to be found in a leaked Liberal Party education policy committee document which said: "We do not want compulsory moneys flowing out to anti-Kennett and anti-coalition campaigns and other fringe activities of the hard left."
He went on to say:

So there we have it. This is not about lofty principles of free association. This is about preventing by law the possible allocation of small fractions of student funds by their elected representatives to political causes of which the Kennett Government disapproves. Even the financing of student newspapers is suspect, and therefore excluded.
Claude Forell went on to say:

Well, boo-sucks to that. University and college administrations are quite capable of determining campus needs and ensuring that student unions are properly constituted and accountable. Student communities should be entrusted to elect representatives to act in their collective interests—which may include political campaigns.
We may not always like what they do or say, but that's not the point. The . . . Government has no business to impose its own politically-motivated curbs on academic autonomy and student democracy.

We have also heard that voluntary student unionism has been introduced in Western Australia. Let me point out a couple of consequences of that. It has led to reduced employment services at Curtin, it has forced the closure of the disabled students department, the part-time external and mature aged department, the women's department, the sports library, the tool library and student loans, and the guild income has been slashed from $3 million to about $100,000 a year. That is not about voluntary student unionism; that is about the destruction of student services. That is precisely what will occur in other universities and tertiary institutions if this legislation goes through and is successful.

I point out to the House that the bill states that it will `make voluntary student unionism a condition of Commonwealth grants to higher education institutions'. What is voluntary about this? It is compulsory to be voluntary, so where is the choice being given to universities? This is no mere semantic point, because the universities themselves do not support this and do not want it. I have no doubt that if it comes to pass it will do the universities immense damage. It displays on the part of the government a contempt for the best interests of students. The best thing for students would be for this government to stop meddling in student affairs, to abandon this legislation and to allow students to decide themselves what they want from their student organisations. This legislation is akin to putting a gun to universities' heads and saying, `Do as I say or we stop your funding.'

This is an offensive interference in university affairs and it should be comprehensively rejected by this parliament. It reflects Liberal Party paternalism towards young people: `We know what is best for you. No, you cannot manage your own affairs.' We see this with youth wages, with the proposition they put up there. They are prepared to support discrimination based on age alone, whereas we say that wages ought to be based on skills and experience rather than age. They put this forward in their approach to the youth allowance. They put this forward in their approach to drugs. Once again, we get that paternalism from a party which is out of touch with the world of young people and indifferent to their right to manage their own affairs.

talk.start.para: —Just to summarise the speech of the member for Wills, he was saying that he believes the government should respect the autonomy of the universities to compel students to join a student union. What he was saying is that we need to have compulsion to join a student union, otherwise under a voluntary system you will have something like an Eastern European totalitarianism regime. He is saying that we need compulsion to avoid becoming totalitarian. That is an Orwellian argument. It comes down to a fundamental problem that the Left have always had: they have never been able to reconcile freedom with organisation. The government is offering the same rights to university students that anyone else in the community holds, that is, the freedom of association. University students will be given a choice of whether to join or not to join.

speech.para: Touching on another point that was raised, the member for Wills said that he was opposed to voluntary taxation. He did not think voluntary taxation was a good idea. What is wholesale sales tax, which they support? What is excise? What is the whole indirect tax base? That is an area in consumption where people actually do have some choice. What we have heard from the Labor side is a defence of student unions. But that is not the issue here.

No-one has a problem with the role of student unions. The issue is that of compulsion. The Australian Labor Party's argument goes something like this: the student unions are so good we need to compel everyone to join. That is a totalitarian argument, saying, `These unions are so good we need to compel students to join. We cannot actually give people a choice of whether to join or not to join.' The fundamental question here is not the role of student unions. The fundamental question here is: why should university students be denied the fundamental right of freedom of association? It is undemocratic for one group in this community to be denied freedom of association. The reasons I believe in voluntary student unionism are those, on the point of principle of freedom of association.

Student unions and the Labor Party in their approach to this do not take account of the fact that not all students are full-time undergraduate students. We now have more part-time students than ever before; we have more external students than ever before; we have more cross-institutional students than ever before; we have more mature age students than ever before. Not all of them want to join the student union. Why do we need to compel them? Under voluntary student unionism, student unions will become more responsive to students' needs. They will not die if they offer students what students want.

The government is not introducing VSU—voluntary student unionism—to destroy student unions or to silence one of its most vocal critics. We believe in voluntary student unionism because we believe in freedom, and deep down the Left does not. We believe in freedom of speech and freedom of association. These are fundamental principles of liberalism, which the Liberal Party stands for. We believe that a well informed debate is healthy and natural; that is why we are encouraging debate in areas such as industrial relations, tax reform and the private health system.

In this debate on voluntary student unionism I have heard many unionists and present and former student union leaders tell us about the benefits of students unions, but I have not heard any compelling or definitive reasons about why membership of a student union should be compulsory. It is highly likely that members of the Labor Party on the opposite side of the chamber have raised and will raise peripheral issues of student union membership; these issues are not the point. The central question is not the value of student unions but why membership should be compulsory. Students are being denied the fundamental right of freedom of association.

Critics of voluntary student unionism have said that it is wrong to confuse student unions with trade unions. I would ask the ALP: if students unions are not trade unions, why do we have so many trade union officials listed on this paper to speak on the debate? There is plenty of cross-fertilisation between trade union officials and student union officials. The ALP are advocating the continued use of a traditional union tool, that of a closed shop. Nowhere else in the work force does this still exist, yet it is all right to continue it in the universities. The ALP has spoken of the benefits of student unions. That is an argument which is consistent with voluntary student unionism. These are the types of benefits student unions should be promoting to attract new members when voluntary student unionism is implemented.

I believe that student unions have a place. They have an important role in lobbying for and representing their members and providing services for students. For example, the University of Adelaide union have just introduced the trial of a smartcard which can be loaded and used to pay for parking meters, for photocopying and so on. This is an example of the innovative role of a student union. But it is not an argument in favour of compulsion; it is an argument to say that people should at least have the choice.

Some universities do have conscientious objection clauses which allow you to opt out of student union membership, but this year was the first time I had actually heard about them; they are not publicised. When students receive their invoice for their fees, their enrolment notice and so on, they are informed that failure to pay outstanding union fees will result in them being placed in bad financial standing with the university. That means you cannot get your results and you cannot graduate. I do not believe that is fair.

Unlike the member for Melbourne, I can declare some consistency on this issue. Ten years ago, I argued that clinical, medical and dental students should be able to pay a reduced union fee because they were not on campus to access student services. It was very much an argument in favour of user-pays and it was very much in support of the principle that people should actually have a choice to pay for what they use. It was opposed by the Left who were, 10 years ago, staunch defenders of compulsory unionism. They still are, 10 years on, staunch defenders of compulsory unionism. I still have the letter I wrote to all Liberal Club members asking them to support it, in view of their support for voluntary student unionism, as the first stage—being described at the time as the thin edge of the wedge—of voluntary student unionism.

Everyone would agree that student unions do enrich life for university students. That is not the point. The point is that students should at least have a choice of whether to join or not. Voluntary student unionism was implemented in Western Australia in 1994 and there has been no substantial effect on the services offered to students by the student guilds and the universities. In fact, there has been a reduction in union membership fees. It is up to the student unions themselves to promote the benefits of student union membership and to be responsive to student needs. They should not be relying on compulsory union membership for their members.

I studied medicine full time in the mid- to late-eighties and, more recently as a candidate, I did economics part time. I would say that when I was studying full time I would have joined voluntarily the student union. I received a lot of benefits through associations with clubs, including sporting clubs, societies and so on. But I would have also said that when I was working and studying part time I probably would not have joined if it were voluntary—I had a lot of other things to do—and I think people should be given that choice.

Compulsory student union fees were introduced when most university students were full-time undergraduates. As I have said before, there are more part-time, more external, more cross-institutional and more mature age students undertaking university courses than ever before. There are more postgraduates. Why should all of them be compelled to join a student union? Not all of them have the time or the inclination to get involved in university extracurricular life. Why should they subsidise other students, especially a student political elite? It returns to the point that, if students do benefit from union membership, why do you have to compel them to join? Why can't students have choice?

One of the recent editions of Adelaide University's On Dit was almost totally dedicated to letters from university students stating their opposition to voluntary student unionism. They do not seem to have grasped the point that under VSU all of them will still be able to join the university union. If the amount of students who have written to this newspaper is reflective of the student population, the union will survive and thrive. In fact, one of the letters in the university student newspaper was from the President of the Adelaide University Labor Club. In an Orwellian attack which is all too typical of the Labor Party, she argues in the same letter that it is acceptable for the Adelaide University Student Union to ban the Liberal club from distributing pro-voluntary student unionism material and also says in the same breath that the Liberal government is crushing `free speech'. This is Orwellian.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in case you do not remember, two months ago the Adelaide University union banned, during orientation week, the Adelaide University Liberal Club from distributing VSU material in the union building. They cannot say, `That's okay but we think the Liberal government is trying to crack down on free speech.' Nothing could be further from the truth. In actual fact, in the same newspaper the Resistance Club—hardly a traditional ally or supporter of the Liberal Party—condemns the ban by the Adelaide University union.

One of the arguments that has been used against VSU is that sporting clubs will be decimated. You may remember the shadow minister asking a question without notice of the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs on 23 March relating to VSU legislation placing at risk the Year 2000 University Games at Ballarat. For the shadow minister's information, the 1999 Australian University Games will be held in Perth, so the Australian University Games are being held in a VSU state. During the 1998 University Games the University of Western Australia travelled all the way to Melbourne and won the award for the `spirit of the games'. Remember, this is a university from a VSU state. The award was for having a very successful team and for their enthusiasm and great attitude.

Highlights of the University of Western Australia's performance were the winning women's water polo team and the men's water polo team coming fourth. Another university from Western Australia, Edith Cowan, came third in the men's tennis. Last year the Australian universities' men's rowing eight for the New Zealand challenge was made up of students from Edith Cowan University and the University of Western Australia—not bad for a VSU state. I believe that under VSU there will be no difference in the number of members joining a sporting club. Why would there be? After all, university members now have the choice of whether or not they join a sporting club. Why would there be any difference?

Ten years ago, I was the President of the Adelaide Medical Students Society. Membership of that society was voluntary, but most students joined because they knew they would benefit from their membership. We did receive from the union a grant of $1,000, but we were in no way dependent on that grant. While the grant was appreciated, it was actually relatively small compared with the amounts of money that we raised for charity and that we raised in various functions. The society was self-reliant and raised something like $2,000 for charity, which was much greater than the grant that was received from the union.

Compulsory student unionism has also encouraged a situation where waste and inefficiency are unchecked. In 1987 at the University of Adelaide the most popular club to join was the Days of Our Lives Club. It was the largest club. It had over 600 members. It was formed for the explicit purpose of seeking a union grant for kegs to run a party. That was the way it worked. In 1988 it was the Chocolate Appreciation Society. Again, the impetus was to get as many people signed up at $2 on their books and they would get a grant which was based on a per capita basis. The aim of the Chocolate Appreciation Society was to hold a party where chocolate was served. Both of those are examples of clubs that were formed under the rules just to get a grant from the union. Clubs like that might be dependent on their grant from the union. Most thriving clubs—sporting clubs, societies—at universities would not be dependent on their union grant. So it is compulsory student unionism that has created this grant dependency.

Even if you accept the extreme argument that no-one will join a union if it is voluntary, which would be an indictment of student unions, I do not believe it will affect clubs and societies, because most of them are not reliant on their union grant. Most of them do not depend on their union grant. I think it is only fair that university students should have the choice of whether to join the student union. Proponents of compulsory student unionism assume that once VSU is introduced then all student services will cease. If those services are meeting the needs of students, students will fund them. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —We all come to this place with different intentions, different ambitions, different visions, with a sense of great things, with the aim of doing big things for the nation. Different members of this House obviously have different views on many issues, but most of us are driven by some sort of ambition about some issues, some grand themes, some great visions for the future of our country. Some want to pursue issues of poverty, others wish to enhance the rights of women and some would like to make the Australian economy more vibrant, more productive and more efficient.

speech.para: The Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 actually relates to the vision of one member of this House—the Treasurer. And what a grand, sweeping and noble vision it is; the vision not of improving the lot of ordinary Australians, not of abolishing poverty, not of tackling unemployment, not of improving the efficiency of the Australian economy, but one of the great crusades of all time in Australian political history, the crusade to wipe out student unionism! Such is the great vision of the Treasurer!

We all do have our visions, as I have said, and I will get to one of mine, one of the things that I am passionate about, which I think is relevant to this issue, later in this contribution. But what we are dealing with here is narrowness of vision, narrowness of interest, nastiness and the continuation for purely petty ideological reasons of a conflict that has occurred over the past 20 years or so. It has been very valuable to the Treasurer in his battles for advancement within the Liberal Party. It has been a vehicle through which he has pursued the interests of both himself and his various lieutenants—although, of course, it is worth pointing out that his major lieutenants in the faction of the Liberal Party in Victoria who are obsessed by this issue appear to be in decline as a result of the increasing strength of the Jeff Kennett faction in Victoria and are suffering regular defeats now on important issues.

I have had the dubious privilege of watching the evolution of this `great vision' and the obsession of the Treasurer on this issue for over 20 years. I had the dubious privilege of being an employee of the Melbourne University Student Union in 1977 when the case brought by the then Treasurer of the SRC and Liberal Club member Robert Clark was initiated. He is now a state Liberal MP and a member of the Costello faction. But what we have seen since that time is a regular sequence of assaults on the institution of student unionism led primarily by the Treasurer but also by others such as his good friend Mr Kroger and various people around the country.

It has been a tremendous vehicle for the Treasurer to win support within the Liberal Party and particularly from people like Malcolm Fraser and others. During the late seventies and the first half of the eighties it was a badge of honour for the Treasurer. It was a vehicle through which he was able to bring himself to the attention of many others. It has become a very important part of the Costello mythology. I emphasise the word `mythology' because essentially that is what it is. If you believe the stories, then brave Sir Peter went out to battle on his white horse and slayed the evil dragons of the Left in the student unionism area.

Of course, the truth is a little different. Yes, he did win one or two elections in the Monash Association of Students in the late 1970s. But within a year or two the Left were back in control, and by the time the Treasurer had departed the campus nothing had changed. He left no legacy, no change in the political power structure, no change in the way that the place operated. In 1979 he tried to set up a breakaway national student union and failed. This effort went on for about six months and ultimately collapsed into dust. Although the Australian Union of Students did go out of business in 1984, it was fairly quickly replaced by the National Union of Students. And, of course, if you listen to the rhetoric from opposite, you will find that they believe that nothing really substantially has changed. Yes, there has been legislation in various parts of the country, in some cases similar to the legislation before the House today, which reflects the voluntary student unionism obsession of the Treasurer and some of his cohorts. But in many cases this is phantom legislation as, indeed, one of the Treasurer's strong supporters, Senator Synon, pointed out in her maiden speech, and I will return to that in a moment.

But it is interesting to note how much the mythology on this issue has diverged from the reality. Of course, it has a direct parallel, which I am sure the shadow minister for industrial relations is aware of, which is the mythology about the Treasurer's role in the famous Dollar Sweets case where he carried the bags for the senior barrister, Mr Alan Goldberg. But, of course, the subsequent recording of that has been that the Treasurer actually won the case and somehow the QC who actually prosecuted the matter and successfully handled it has been written out of history.

In looking at the level of achievement that has occurred on this great crusade so far, the major example of voluntary student unionism legislation that is worth considering is of course that brought forward by the Kennett government. What the Kennett government did is really revealing of what this whole thing is about. It is not about principle. It is not about a desire to ensure freedom of association. It is not about any sense of giving freedom and choice to people. It is about keeping compulsion but getting rid of accountability, getting rid of democratic decision making and getting rid of participation.

The Kennett government legislation kept compulsory fees. The fee that was previously a student union fee was retained. It narrowed down the range of activities for which this fee could be expended, so that it was all right for sport and sporting clubs to be compulsorily funded by the fees of the non-sporting, for example, but it was not all right for student newspapers to be funded by the compulsory fees extracted from people who did not read them, and it was not all right for student theatre to be funded by the compulsory fees extracted from those who did not attend their events.

In effect, nothing of substance has changed. The student newspaper is still funded out of the profits generated by commercial activities run by the student union, for example. The only change is that there is less accountability, less student involvement and less student control over the decision making processes. Everybody still has to pay the fee. This reveals that this agenda is purely and simply about suppressing dissent and removing institutions that are seen to be power bases for people opposed to the conservative parties. That is why they target things like student newspapers. I happen to be a former editor of a student newspaper. Student newspapers actually tend to express points of view that are at odds with the views of conservative governments. That is what this whole exercise is about.

Finally, after 20 years or so of this great legacy building by the Treasurer—this grand crusade—we are now starting to see a glimmer of hope that there will actually be some sort of outcome on this front. The dragon has not quite been slain. This bill represents the zenith of the attempt by the Treasurer and his supporters to wipe out compulsory student unionism. But, already, within days of it having been published, support for this legislation started to disintegrate. A number of members of this House from various parts of the country—particularly rural areas— suddenly realised that student unionism structures actually function to uphold some of the important services in their areas. This legislation will destroy the basis for collective activity on campuses such as student clubs and societies, theatre and the arts, cinemas, student newspapers, child care centres, unsatisfactory progress representation, counselling, welfare services and the like. The vast majority of the activities of student unions consists of mundane, ordinary service provision which ensures that people can go to the cinema, go to the theatre and get access to cheap services of a wide variety of kinds.

As well as the practical outcome of this legislation, it is necessary to consider its philosophical basis. Our society actually has a variety of collective structures built into it. Some of them are compulsory in composition, some of them are voluntary. The analogy with trade unionism is fundamentally flawed in this instance, because the only significant component of compulsion that is involved with membership of a student union—as the Melbourne University example illustrates—is paying the fee, whereas membership of a trade union exposes you to the prospect of being part of majority decisions that you may not agree with. These may involve loss of income—taking strike action for example. There is no equivalent in the case of student unions. They are a collective means of providing ancillary services associated with universities that could easily be provided directly by the universities without student accountability, without student democracy, without student participation—where the students are still ultimately paying the fees. That is the longer term consequence of this legislation. That is the only avenue that we can head down, if university campuses are to remain like they are today.

The real analogy is with local government; and you have a geographic commonality between the local government example and universities. I may not use the local swimming pool in the city of Moreland. I have on one or two occasions but generally I do not. I may not use the library. We have got a very good library here that I use quite a lot. Yet I still pay my rates for those services, in the same way that a student at Melbourne University pays compulsory fees to give them the option—but not the obligation—to use the swimming pool at Melbourne University or, indeed, the various other facilities. That is the appropriate analogy. Even the conservatives do not suggest that we should make participation in local government and paying rates voluntary—although who knows where they will head?

The end result of incorporating these sorts of services into university budgets will be to ensure that there is no student control, democratic participation or accountability about how fees are spent and how they are disbursed. We have had the arguments over alleged funding of the PLO and various other supposedly exotic causes. The other day the Attorney-General of the ACT, Mr Gary Humphries, made totally unsubstantiated claims that student unions fund the PLO and the like. This sort of nonsense has been spread for many years and it is simply baseless. Some years ago, there was the odd example where a couple of hundred dollars might have been sent to some obscure cause that really did not have any great relationship with the interests of students. But all student unions, in their charters, have an obligation to apply their funds for the direct benefit of students. That is what the Clark case was about back in the late 1970s—enforcing those clauses—so, ultimately, there is a legal restraint which precludes that sort of thing from happening in any event.

Supporting a compulsory levy on groups of people for their common benefit is ultimately an issue that has to be assessed on the facts. What is the nature of the cost? What are the benefits? What disadvantages and obligations does it impose? How much fairness and transparency is there in the process?

It is ironic that people in the National Party, who have a long track record of supporting things like compulsory levies in particular primary industries, would be so opposed to compulsion. There are ample examples throughout our history of groups of people who have come together with a common activity—like growing sugar or whatever, which is entirely analogous to the common activity of being students at a university—where there has been a collective decision, often enforced by government, that it be compulsory for those people to participate.

So it is entirely hypocritical for many people in this chamber to be posturing about voluntarism and about freedom of choice when much of Australia's primary industry has been built on exactly the opposite sort of principle. Compulsion may have an appropriate role, and it depends on the facts of the situation. It depends on the nature of the compulsion, what the common outcome is and how reasonable the imposition is that is involved.

Finally, I want to turn to the issue that disturbs me most about this legislation. I am passionate about the question of social exclusion, loneliness, alienation, increasing atomisation and increasing individualism in our society. These are real issues. These are very important issues. You may ask: what on earth does voluntary student unionism have to do with these issues? I will tell you what it has to do with them: freedom of association in this context means less association. That is what this is about. It is not some highly artificial notion of freedom of association; it is simply about less association. It is about less interaction between young people in particular on university campuses. It is about less capacity to participate in a social sense to make friends, to develop an identity and the like.

Student unions are collective structures that provide nodes of participation within university campuses. They provide an enormous array of different structures, different collectivities, clubs and societies, theatre—a variety of activities which all flourish within that student unionism framework. Some of them are pretty exotic, some of them are pretty weird—there is no question about that—but they provide options for people. This is where the real choice comes in, not the artificial choice of, `I want to be free not to belong.' The real choice is the opportunity to go to a place which might be a long way away from where you have come from, where you may not know too many people, and have a variety of choices to meet people, to participate and to be involved in various activities.

Tertiary students are primarily young people and they represent a rapidly growing proportion of the young in our population. This is a period of time in most people's lives when they tend to be developing and are fairly vulnerable—looking for their identity, building friendships and relationships and the like. Many people rely on the structures that student unionism delivers to give them the opportunities to do those things. A university campus with student unionism structures provides a very wide array of participation nodes that enable people to do that.

I feel fairly strongly about this issue because I can recall turning up at Melbourne University, having come from the country. I had been on the place for a grand total of about three hours. I knew virtually nobody. I would go to the lectures and tutorials—sometimes—and would sort of politely say hello to people and then wander off. I might have had absolutely nothing in common with those people there. How was it that, as a 17-year-old who really did not know anybody or did not know much about the place, I made friends, got involved, developed an identity and participated in various things? It was through student unionism structures; it was through activities and structures provided by the institution of student unionism.

This legislation is ultimately about destroying a provision of collective activity, of participation and of belonging in our society at a time when these sorts of institutions and groupings are increasingly disintegrating or under threat, at a time when individualism and the notion that we are all islands and that the only relationships that should exist between us should be contractual are increasing. At a time when all that is occurring, we are seeking to tear down yet another framework of collective involvement, of belonging, of participating, of being social. In this context, freedom of association means less association. It means more alienated people. It means more lonely people. It means people having fewer opportunities to be involved, fewer opportunities to integrate into a community. That is ultimately what this legislation is about.

I see government as having a very different role from what this government sees it as having. I see government as having a very important and increasing role of ensuring that there are structures in society between the individual and government that do provide opportunities for participation, for belonging, and that do ensure that people are not alienated, that they make friends, that they build relationships, that they have some sense of social stability in their lives. That is what student unions do. Yes, they might occasionally say funny things and do strange things, but you should never judge things by the exception, by the occasional unusual thing. Underneath all that, student unions provide people with the capacity to belong, with somewhere to participate, with somewhere to develop and with somewhere to build self-esteem and an identity.

I see government as having a very important role in combating the rising tide of social alienation. It is not an easy thing to tackle. There are no obvious solutions, no legislation or anything like that, that we want to put forward immediately in these areas, but the last thing we want to do is pour petrol on the flames. That is exactly what this legislation proposes to do. We need a federal government that is developing new and innovative approaches to dealing with loneliness and alienation in our society, not one that is deliberately tearing down some of the structures that actually retard the development of those phenomena, that actually ensure that people do have a place to belong, that ensure that there are processes, structures and activities that they can be part of. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We take it for granted that we live in a wonderful democracy in Australia. Central to that democracy is the freedom of association. We are free to choose which religion we follow and which clubs or societies we want to be a member of, and our political alliances are a personal matter. We rightly expect this freedom of association free from any prejudice. We take it that these are unquestionable rights and freedoms to which we ought to be enti tled. That is why it is amazing that we continue to tolerate a situation where Australian students are forced to join an organisation whose views may be contrary to their own, to pay for services they may have no intention of ever using, and to subsidise activities with which they strongly disagree. I am talking of course about compulsory student unionism.

speech.para: It seems incredible in this day and age that in almost all states in Australia refusal to join a student union means that they face the ultimate prejudice of being unable to obtain a university education. Young Australians are being forced to give up their right to freedom of association in order to obtain an education. In my view, this is simply wrong.

The Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 seeks to give students real choice. It amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to make receiving operating grants conditional on universities not making membership of student organisations and associations and the collection of any compulsory general service or amenities fees a requirement of enrolment. In other words, Australian students will no longer be subject to the closed shop arrangements that were such a big part of how unions operated in this nation under Labor.

Thankfully, the Howard government has already abolished compulsory unionism in the workplace. Australian workers, under our laws, now enjoy the right of freedom of association. However, I note with dismay that some unions are still engaging in standover tactics at non-union workplaces. I was contacted recently by a local contractor who employs non-union labour. He was approached at a building site, and he and his workers were threatened with all sorts of problems if they did not join the union.

talk.start.para: —Disgusting.

—It is. Thankfully, that business and his employees have the weight of the law behind them, but such is the thuggery of the trade union leaders that they still believe they have the right to impose their views on all workers, even though less than 20 per cent of the residents of Forde belong to a trade union. The fact is that unions can be very effective and they do have a role to play in modern society, and good unions which offer real, tangible services for their members will have no problem in retaining membership. But compulsory unionism, as we have seen in the past, inevitably leads to inefficiency and the abuse of power. Voluntary unionism has forced many unions to re-examine the services they offer their members. The result is better services for their workers and a more responsive union management, which in turn leads to improved working relationships with employers.

speech.para: But, unfortunately, there are still many backward thinkers in the trade union movement and among their mates in the Labor Party who believe in compulsory unionism and would like a return to the bad old days when workers were forced to join a union. It is not surprising—with all of Labor's frontbench being members of a union and relying on union backing for their preselection—that Labor opposes this legislation.
