These days, under the weak leadership of Kim Beazley, it is surprising if Labor supports any legislation that makes sense and is all about a fair go. Labor's obstructionist tactics in the Senate are costing young people jobs, hampering our chances of securing real tax reform, retarding our ability to pay back the massive government debt left behind by the Labor Party, and the list goes on. If it is good for Australia and it makes practical sense, then Labor opposes it.

A big reason for that is that they are tied hand and foot to the trade union bosses. Kim Beazley would have done better to provide a true vision for his party if he had outlined a way for them to divorce themselves from the antiquated thinking of the trade union bosses who still call the shots in the Labor Party. This legislation is a clear opportunity for Labor to put the interests of Australian students first and to draw a line in the sand on the nature of unionism.

The simple fact is that if unionism is effective and offers tremendous benefits, then surely there should be no need for it to be compulsory for people to join unions. That is what it comes back to for our Australian students. Currently we have a situation where students have to pay a significant lump sum up front, all of which goes to the student associations or unions, for services that are not directly related to their education and studies. As the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs said in his second reading speech:

Choice about which goods and services they purchase is something expected by Australians. The compulsory general service fee charged on most Australian campuses requires students, as a condition of enrolment, to pay for services they may not want to use. On most campuses, in order to get a university degree you have to contribute to sporting facilities, whether or not you play sport. On most campuses, in order to get a university education you have to contribute to student entertainment, whether or not you have the time or inclination to attend. Students should enjoy the same consumer right to purchase only the services they want on and off campus, and this legislation will give them that right.

The minister is absolutely spot-on. I know many students these days take their studies very seriously. They are involved in many community activities and sporting clubs off campus and, with full-time study and part-time work, they find little time to participate in student association activities. So the question should be: why do students have to subsidise the entertainment, sporting and political activities of others?

Even more disturbing for some is the fact that their up-front fees are going towards activities that are absolutely contrary to their beliefs and values. It has been revealed that, on one particular campus, union fees were used to produce a book on drug use, a `how to' guide that promoted drug use. This is something that the vast majority of students would strongly oppose, and many young people I know resent the fact that their money is being abused in this way.

The political nature of many student unions also means that a full range of student political views are not taken into account. Indeed, students whose views are not radically left wing generally have to subsidise the political activities of the vocal minority whose views are. I want to stress that the motivation for this bill is not political. It is about freedom of association and freedom of choice. But the one-sided political nature of these student associations just serves to highlight the unfairness of the compulsory system.

It shows how unrepresentative these associations have become. Many have been corrupted into nothing more than noisy, political interest groups. One example is the fact that for many years the Liberal Party at the Queensland University of Technology was unable to be affiliated with the student union and therefore could not access the same funds as all other clubs and societies, simply because it supported voluntary student unionism.

In 1993 the National Union of Students spent over $100,000 on a `put Liberals last' campaign that was particularly aimed at defeating the coalition, and at the last election we saw evidence of similar campaigns by the student union. If students want to be political lobbyists, then that is fine and good. Student activism can be a healthy thing. But the question again is: why should all students subsidise the political views of a small group? If left wing Marxism is the answer to our social woes, then surely the supporters of those views can raise the funds themselves for their political campaigns.

Why should students who support the coalition government have to pay for campaigns that are directly contrary to their own beliefs? Again, this political aspect is just a small part of the reason why compulsory student unionism is unfair and does not work to meet the students' needs. Currently, compulsory union fees make up more than half the annual turnover of student associations. It is a guaranteed income and the system has led to much inefficiency and abuse. On most campuses student unions enjoy a monopoly on food and other services. Their rationale is that they subsidise these activities to benefit the students, but the reality is that the prices charged on campus are rarely lower than those off campus. This ongoing subsidy is merely an excuse for poor management and inefficiency in many cases and jobs for their mates.

I was discussing this issue with my children, who have attended and who are attending university. They can recount many stories of how their various student unions have spent money on frivolous events and ideas and provided ongoing employment for people who did little for the student body. The fact that many of today's students take their studies seriously and have little time to get involved in student politics means that many of the inefficiencies go unchallenged. Those fine individuals and organisations who dare to question the legitimacy of the many union activities—and I congratulate the Australian Liberal Student Federation for their time and efforts in this regard—find they come up against a brick wall. They discover that claims that the student association is there to serve the interests of the entire student body are simply that—claims. They don't represent the reality, and they are really just a weak justification for ongoing compulsory fees.

We have heard all sorts of doomsday predictions from the NUS and those opposite about how the legislation will impact on student services. The fact is that voluntary student unionism has been in place in Western Australia since 1995 and, far from having a detrimental effect on student services, the evidence points to the fact that student bodies have had to alter and improve their services in order to attract the support of the student body. As the minister pointed out in his second reading speech, at Curtin University in Western Australia the student guild no longer subsidises aerobics but it offers casual employment registers, assistance with resume writing and interview skills, and discounts at a range of on- and off-campus retailers.

I am sure that there would be many opposite who lament that the colourful nature of some students' activities may be altered, but is it really fair that the mainstream student body subsidises that enjoyment and the activities and personal power games of the noisy minority? It is a lot like Labor's approach to politics in general: be captive to special interest groups and vocal minorities, with little regard for the views and interests of mainstream Australia. This is a flawed, outdated approach. We saw nothing in Kim Beazley's so-called `Vision' lecture recently to suggest that Labor really is listening to mainstream Australia. We saw an incredible two-faced declaration on the power of the Senate to block legislation. That is a bit of a laugh. I find it hard to believe that the Leader of the Opposition has the gall to make a declaration along this line when all the while he is blocking and frustrating the government's sensible politics in the Senate.
On to the issue of education, which we are all in a sense discussing today. With this bill we saw Kim Beazley declaring that he wanted to be remembered—

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his correct title, please.

—He wants to be referred to in the future as `the Prime Minister for Education'. His assertion that he will be Prime Minister is arrogant in itself, taking a leaf out of his old mate Paul Keating's book. But has the Leader of the Opposition conveniently forgotten that he served as education minister during some of the 13 years of Labor government, a period during which we saw literacy levels fall to a record low? When we came to office one in every three 14-year-olds could not read or write sufficiently. That is the education legacy he left to Australia's young people.

speech.para: But it is not surprising that he would prefer to be remembered as `the Education Prime Minister'. He certainly couldn't be remembered for his efforts as employment minister, during which time we saw unemployment reach a record high of 11.3 per cent and more than one million young Australians out of work. He certainly would not want to be remembered for his efforts as finance minister, during which he whacked up successive budgets of over $25 million and also promised that Labor had the budget in surplus when in fact he was deliberately hiding a $10 billion budget black hole.

Is it any surprise that the Leader of the Opposition does not want to be remembered for these things? The fact is that he will be remembered for his refusal to modernise Labor by distancing the party from the trade union movement. Indeed, today's Labor is more at the behest of the union bosses than ever before. The refusal of the Leader of the Opposition to act in this regard has relegated today's Labor Party to nothing more than the political wing of the ACTU. On every issue they take their lead from the trade union bosses. That is a fact. When it comes to sensible job creation policies, like our unfair dismissal changes and our youth wage bill, they are selling out Australia's unemployed. They are putting politics above sensible policies that will help job seekers. They are putting ideology first and the national interest a distant last.

They are doing exactly the same thing with this important issue. They are putting the union first, above all else, pure and simple. The Western Australian example has shown that student services do not crumble under voluntary unionism; they become more relevant and more mainstream. Why should students who place their studies above extra curricular activities subsidise those who don't? Surely non-academic activities should be a matter of user pays. I challenge those opposite to explain why the entire student body should subsidise the activities of a small group. If people want to attend aerobics or a concert they surely should, and they should pay for it themselves. Students whose musical taste may differ from the student association's have to pay for any concerts they attend. Students who attend an aerobic class off-campus close to where they live or work because it may be more convenient have to pay for this themselves. This is fair. Those who want to take advantage of any services the student union may want to offer can choose to pay for those services and they will do that if they believe it represents value for money.

The student unions themselves are the ones who always claim that free education is a right. Yet the fact is that these compulsory union fees are the only up-front lump sum that students are currently forced to pay before they can commence their education. They have no choice in this matter. The vast majority have no direct say in how those funds are spent. Compulsory union fees are in a real sense simply a tax on all students to fund a corrupt system that serves the needs of only a very small few. If, as those opposite would argue, student associations offer very real and important services to their members, then they should have no trouble in retaining their membership. That is the bottom line—choice. Australian students are intelligent young adults. They should be allowed to make their own choices about how they spend their money. They should not be forced to join an organisation against their will just to be able to obtain their degree. That is not democracy. That is not the sort of freedom of association that we Australians deserve and expect.

I am pleased to strongly represent and support this bill, which is another example of how the coalition is providing fair and practical government for all of us, ensuring that the needs of all Australians are put above those of noisy minority interest groups.

talk.start.para: —There is something ironic about this matter being debated the day after a government, which the majority of Australians opposed and voted against, brought in a budget spending the taxes of all Australians. We have a minority government, which just over 48 per cent of the people supported, spending the taxes of 100 per cent of the people. Let us take the government's philosophy and extend it to its own activities—jobs for its mates, control by a minority over a majority and no discretion for the individual as to what services they pay for or how their money is spent. The fact is that most Australians did not want this government. The fact is they have got this government, and now the government is lecturing us and all Australians about how minorities should not control. I find it ironic. I find it particularly strange.

speech.para: Firstly, I would like to refer in particular to the University of Newcastle, but before I do I should place on record the fact that I am extremely proud to have been part of a government that, during its period of office, increased the number of university places by 120,000. Our government inherited a system where two-thirds of school students left school at year 10. Only one-third even went to year 12. I am quite proud to have been part of the government that doubled student involvement in higher education to at least year 12 and then to university. We inherited in 1983 a system which was more than flawed; it was ramshackle and incompetent. The then Treasurer, the current Prime Minister, should be embarrassed and ashamed to be in this place lecturing us about education. He has the audacity to talk about an education budget when the budget again incorporates a one per cent cut in university grants for the fourth year. The minister talks about promoting science and research when the money that has been put back into parts of research is a fraction of what has been taken out.

The vehicle for the government to vent its ideological spleen is the so-called unions. Speaker after speaker from the government says, `No, this is not about trade unions,' but every one of them mentions trade unions in their speeches. They keep saying, `No, we understand this isn't about trade unions,' but every single one of them mentions trade unions, and more than once. This is nothing to do with universities. This is nothing to do with student services. This is a government that is obsessed with its own view of the world, and it cannot see outside its own bottle. It is bottled up in a kind of way that I find difficult to understand.

The University of Newcastle has been in existence as an autonomous university for some 40 years now. It has been a difficult 40 years for a small university in a regional centre. I am probably the only person in this place who paid up-front fees as a student. I used to say before 1996 that the HECS fees that were introduced by the previous government were less, in relative terms, than what I paid back in the sixties as up-front fees. That is no longer the case. The current HECS fees are probably equal to, or more than, what I paid under the Menzies government.

I am also probably the only person in this place who was a member of a student union which had to build a new building. We had no facilities. When the University of Newcastle went to Tighes Hill we had vacant space. In our first year we had a pie wagon; you could buy a pie at a pie wagon in the middle of the campus amongst the mosquitoes and amongst the mud of a building site. We were part of a building site with no facilities. We borrowed heavily from the banks to build a student union. If there were no compulsory fees, we would never have got a loan. The student union would never have been there.

I say to those people opposite who sit there and talk about the ratio of part time to full time that the ratio in the sixties in Newcastle is not the way it is now. We had a large number of part-time students who could not access facilities on campus at night. There were virtually no bus services, there was no union, there was nothing. Young women were coming out to a remote site with no student facilities, and yet we are lectured by those opposite who say union fees should be optional. If the fees were optional there would not be a building. I am angry about this because I think the cynicism of those opposite is based on their own ignorance and their own spleen about unions. It is not, and it never has been, about students.

The views I hold are not just mine; they are shared by many. I would like to read a few comments into the record. The first comments are in a letter from the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Newcastle—who is not a Novocastrian, so one cannot accuse him of carrying forward Newcastle political values or views—to the minister back on 15 March. He says:
I write to express my considerable concern over the introduction to the Federal Parliament on 11 March of legislation to introduce voluntary student unionism to Australian University campuses.

All Australian universities and university student associations have spoken out strongly against this legislation and the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee (AVCC) has voiced its unanimous opposition. I reiterate that opposition for the following reasons.
The arguments you have advanced in support of the legislation have focussed on three propositions:
. that compulsory membership of student associations is one remaining `bastion' of compulsory unionism
. the fees collected are used to support activities that only a minority of students are interested in
. subsidies for student services gives these services an unfair `competitive' advantage over similar services on campus or elsewhere.
Universities and the AVCC responded as follows:
. The analogy with trade unions is false, with a better comparator being the payment of council rates—
or I would argue taxes, particularly in this context—
. students with a conscientious objection do not have to join the association, as long as they pay the same fee as other students
. making public funds contingent on not requiring the payment of student service fees is a dangerous intrusion into university affairs
. the quality of campus life will suffer as services deteriorate or as scarce university funds are diverted to support them.

At a recent AVCC meeting in Brisbane, held in association with the 10th anniversary of the establishment of QUT, an outline was given by the Vice-Chancellors of Western Australian universities of the impact of VSU on student associations, which was imposed by the Western Australian State Government two years ago. Student associations for two of these universities have been seriously affected, with the others `struggling' to continue to provide student services at an adequate level. Membership of student associations has been reduced to <20 percent of previous levels, which has seriously compromised student services available at those universities.

From my viewpoint, it is clear that the premises underlying the legislation to introduce voluntary student unionism are open to question. The potential impact of the VSU legislation on student services is a cause of considerable concern. The Western Australian experience indicates that the draft legislation on VSU should be immediately reconsidered.
That letter is signed by Roger S. Holmes, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Newcastle.

The point he makes is that this is not some student plot. These are not some activist, rebellious, left-leaning political would-bes; they are vice-chancellors, the conservative part of the university establishment. These are not the radicals; these are the establishment of the university who are saying, `This is dangerous', and it is unanimous.

The President of the Newcastle University Students Association, Mr Michael Kachel, wrote to me about the matter. In his letter he outlines a range of services and raises many of the arguments that have already been raised. He also points out in the letter a number of services that are available for students, which include orientation for newly enrolled students.

I take note of the comments made by the member for Melbourne who went from a country area to a new university. In Newcastle many of our students come from very small towns a long way away, and orientation for those students is absolutely vital. This is student orientation, not necessarily academic orientation, which is absolutely vital to the successful pursuit of their studies. Many students do not last the first year because they do not fit comfortably into their new social and academic environment. The importance of that orientation is vastly underestimated, certainly by government members.

Other essential services provided by the association include representation on university committees and to the government when defending the rights of students. As a member of the previous government, I can say the students attacked us as much as they are attacking the current government. We did not take our bat and ball and go home and say, `We will cut off your funds' like the current government has said to almost every body that disagrees with it. Whether it be AFCO, the Pensioner Federation or AYPAC, anybody who disagrees with the government has their funding cut. We have seen spectacular examples with environment and research where people who do not agree with the Minister for Health and Aged Care lose their funding in future years. This is the politics of spite and venom.

The students at my university campaigned against the Labor government on more than one occasion and I expect that they would campaign against governments in general. As a student I used to campaign against governments, both state and federal. It did not much matter what their politics were; it was what they did to us that mattered and how we saw it. Additional services provided to students by the association include advocacy for individual students to the university relating to unfair assessment, sexual harassment, academic progress hearings, and so on. It is absolutely vital that somebody is there for the students when they need them. The government says that the students should pay in advance just in case, because they might need some services down the line. Should the students pay the fees before they go for advocacy?

The fact is that the people who are most likely to need the service are the ones who are least able to pay. For the government to say, `This is not really important. This is discretionary. It does not really matter. It is optional. If you want the services, you will pay for them', means that the students with the least money will say, `This is not really important, therefore I will not pay it.' If that same student gets into difficulty, they will have no support and no right to representation, because they are not part of the body.

That particularly applies to overseas students. What is not understood by governments is that overseas students are an increasingly important part of our national economy. It is something like a $3 billion a year in overseas earnings. Student bodies represent those students when in many cases no-one else does. They are simply seen as a source of revenue in many cases.

Who fought the campaign for students with disabilities against both governments over many years? It was the student bodies. The student bodies recognised long before the politicians that students with disabilities needed extra support and they campaigned for it. Newcastle in particular is very proud of its record. I compliment Newcastle University and the range of services available at that university is enormous.

I also would like to refer to a letter I received from Mr Adrian Iakin of the University of Newcastle Sports Union. Earlier I mentioned the building of the university union, which is the facility body, and there is also a student union, which is impacted by this legislation. Over the years the student union has been a major provider of sporting infrastructure to Newcastle—absolutely vital infrastructure. It has done the job for governments. Where governments have failed, the students actually built their own facilities. They point out:

The direct impact of this legislation on the university sport sector will have significant implications for the provision and maintenance of community facilities, employment, the ability of universities to promote themselves internationally and the quality of the university experience offered within our national institutions.
He goes on to point out the following in particular:

The cost benefits of maintaining and extending university sporting and recreational infrastructure have already been recognised. The Government Committee report, Rethinking the funding of community, sporting and recreational facilities: A sporting chance , which reviewed the provision of national sporting and recreational infrastructure, recognised university facilities as a great opportunity for the community. It acknowledged that university facilities were already being used extensively by the community and that contributing to them provides for a very cost-effective means of providing improved facilities for community use. The Sports Union conceived, designed and provided 2/3 of the funding for the construction of the world class indoor sporting facilities of The Forum—
which is a facility at Newcastle University—

which is used by thousands of school children and community members every week. The Forum has been the linchpin of all Hunter region proposals attempting to entice overseas Olympic teams to train in the Hunter valley in the lead up to the Olympic Games in 2000. The Sports Union also designed and paid for the construction of the University of Newcastle No 3 Oval which is the training base for the Newcastle Knights. None of these wonderful facilities and opportunities for the Hunter community would have been possible if VSU had been in place 10 years ago!

By the way, the loan for the Forum is still some $4.6 million. It is only possible because the banks know there is a guaranteed source of revenue. The stupidity of what the government is doing is unbelievable. The leveraging up of capacity on university campuses through student unions has been enormous.

If you go back to my era in the mid-1960s and to 1965 when the university was established at Tighes Hill in Shortland the number of students on campus at any one time was minuscule. There is no way that the student union could have serviced a commercial operation. All we had for the first year that the union was commercially operated was a pie wagon—a caravan like Mr Whippy's—that sold pies like at a football game. That is all that the union could justify because there were not enough students. If you take any point in time—whether it be weekends, weekdays or certain periods of the day—the business is very patchy. The same then happens with sporting facilities where it is difficult to estimate the number of people who are going to pay for a sporting facility at any one time.

What will happen if the government has its way is that the number of contributors to a student union will reduce, as it has in Western Australia. Let us put the lie to this: while member after member opposite quoted the Western Australian experience as having a positive impact, they have all received a letter which is a joint statement by the student guilds of the four universities in Western Australia—Murdoch, Curtin, UWA and Edith Cowan. The letter reads:
Dr Kemp has stated that VSU has had a positive impact upon Student Guilds in Western Australia, making us more accountable, more entrepreneurial and more relevant to the student body.

We wish to make it clear that the West Australian VSU legislation has had a dramatic and negative impact upon our organisations and hence the ability of our organisations to provide essential services and representation to the students of Western Australia.
Enclosed are lists of services that are no longer provided at WA universities as a result of the introduction of so called Voluntary Student Unionism.
We urge all members to vote against this.

Government members—speaking even today—are still quoting the Western Australian situation as a positive experience when they all had letters from the Western Australian universities saying, `Not true. This is a lie. Please vote against this legislation.' The audacity, the sheer hypocrisy of those opposite misusing that information is breathtaking.

But it is no more breathtaking than the budget that purports to act for all Australians when it does not—from a government elected by a minority of Australians pretending to have a mandate to speak for all—for a government that does that and then criticises the universities for having the same principle. I think the example is much more relevant to taxes than to rates. We all tend to be coloured by our own experiences; we all tend to base our view of the world on what we see and on what we understand.

I go back to my years as a member of the student body and as a student politician representing Newcastle in national forums and also as someone who had the enormous task—as we all did in those days—of trying to build facilities on a campus where there was absolutely nothing at all. If you go to Newcastle university now—and many of you have been—and go through the union building, you should remember that the first block was built with a bank loan borrowed by the student union of which I was a member and had financial responsibility for. The loan was given based on the fact that we had fees on all our students. At that time we had 2,000 students altogether of whom probably almost half were part time.

If a director of a company takes out a loan that is unfinancial, then they become personally liable. No student union board member could take out a loan on the basis of VSU. I have heard speakers opposite say, `Give me a compelling reason.' That is the compelling reason. No student representative could take out a loan on behalf of the student body in a situation where there is VSU, because they could not guarantee their revenue. Therefore, in terms of corporate law, they would be personally liable for financial responsibility if the student union went broke in the current situation. That is why compulsory student unionism is essential. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think we have all enjoyed the sheer nostalgia of the contribution from the member for Newcastle. The year is 1999, and he has taken us back to 1965 and told us all about what happened in Newcastle in those days. I could not help but reflect on that famous saying, `If you do remember the 1960s you actually weren't there.' Nevertheless, I was quite pleased to listen to the contribution from the member for Newcastle.

speech.para: I would like to reflect upon it in a number of ways. I suspect that all of the good work of building universities that student unions may have done in the past is really now a lost argument, because times have moved on. I shudder to think that the member for Newcastle would have had his name associated with some of the absolutely outrageous and disgusting pornographic and downright socially irresponsible publications that a lot of student unions put their names to around this country. I do not think the member for Newcastle would have run a student union the way they run them these days. I suspect that the member for Newcastle's nostalgic trip is a valid debating point but nothing else.

I support the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 before us today because I believe in freedom of association. I support this bill because I believe in freedom of choice and I believe in the rights of individuals to make decisions about exactly what organisations they will choose to join.

I know those opposite are desperate on this matter. This is an article of faith; at stake are some of those great suppliers of campaign funds and campaign apparatchiki: student unions at various universities. I have had first-hand experience at just how closely tied the Australian Labor Party and student unions are—and I will deal with this issue a little later.

This is also about keeping faith from the government side as well, because over a long period of years many people in our ranks, party members, have put time and effort into getting the item of voluntary student unionism up on the agenda. A great deal of tribute should be paid to the Australian Liberal Students Federation and its office bearers for having expended such an effort over a long period of time, as have also the Young Liberals and Young Nationals. They have all had first-hand experience in recent times of just how off the rails the unions they are forced to join on campuses around this country have become.

Currently, 600,000 students attend Australian universities. Those students are required to join a student union or an association as a prerequisite for enrolment; in other words, they do not even get a chance to achieve something as a result of their studies if they are not involved in and contributing money towards a student union. Yes, I know on some campuses you can be a conscientious objector, but you still have to contribute the same amount of money to the union. So you are not a member but you are still making a compul sory contribution as a prerequisite for enrolment. Quite frankly, this is outrageous.

Universities have always been a bastion of good debate, a place where civil rights and individual rights are promoted as an absolute priority. A lot of the great struggles for equal opportunity and recognition of people's sexuality and racial differences which have gone on for many years have had their beginnings in universities. I would have thought universities today would be embracing the concept of raw, blatant liberalism, standing up for the rights of individuals with a great deal of fervour. I would have thought also the vice-chancellors, who all too often are tied hand in glove to keeping their academe colleagues and student union colleagues happy, would be standing their ground and saying, `What the government has proposed is fair enough; we cannot force students to contribute to an association as a prerequisite for enrolment.'

This debate is all about choice. Students who feel there is value in the services they are being provided with and who use them will still pay their fees. It is a very simple proposition to follow. If university student unions are providing `must have' services, they will attract membership—and it is the same argument with the trade union movement. Declining membership has occurred over a long period of time as people vote with their feet, saying the trade union movement is not relevant to real workers—and the same can be said about student unions. Yet here we have absolute compulsion being applied and each student being forced to contribute to something which is not doing anything for them.

I know of students who have gone through university without even being aware of the union services available to them on campus. So much for the pro-activity of student unions in this country. There are many people who do not need to access the services. There are also some who may not need to access the services but who choose to contribute in a sort of good community sense. There is a variety of different people with different aspirations and different wants and needs and circumstances. For this reason, compulsion to join an association is quite wrong.

Voluntary membership of student unions will see student associations becoming far more dynamic and responsive to the needs of students. They will have to work to attract membership. They will have to provide students with absolute certainty of their being organisations which are interested in what the students who may join are on about. I know of these matters from my own experience. I studied from 1987 in a part-time capacity at Griffith University, located in the centre of my electorate. I think I am still the one and only person who has ever been elected to this place as a Griffith University graduate.

I want to reflect on Griffith University. It is an absolutely fine university. I know the minister at the table is well aware of just how wonderful Griffith University is. This university does things a little differently in a lot of ways. In fact, Griffith University uses an Office of Community Services model. Perhaps if other universities around the country had followed this model, we would not have needed this bill.

The Director of the Office of Community Services is concerned at Griffith University being caught up in the changes to come. In keeping faith with him and what I think is a good system, I would state for the record: the Griffith University does not have a system where services are provided through the organisation of a student union; the university itself has established this Office of Community Services which conducts the various businesses. It uses a compulsory fee for the provision of services and facilities on its campuses.

But one thing the Office of Community Services also agrees with is: the requirement should not exist for students to compulsorily join an organisation. So, in other words, Griffith University proves you can have a system which does not force people to join as a prerequisite for study but still works—a bit like the rates system which those opposite keep talking about—with the concept of contributing to the community through a fee. I think the Griffith University model has a lot to offer, as demonstrated by the case I have put.

Nevertheless, at the end of the day Griffith University also should feel very confident about the services it provides—the very mature range of services it provides—being taken up by students as they study at this university. Students will maintain the payment of such a fee to keep those services going because they know it is worth doing. It can no longer be compulsorily charged, but people do understand, unlike those opposite, the need to make a contribution does exist.

I believe the Griffith University model not only will prove to be something others will follow but also itself is a success which will continue to be a success. Griffith University is run in a much different way from the way other universities have run themselves over a long period of time because it does not tie itself into the student union to provide the services which are there.

The other thing that is very important is that the Office of Community Services does not direct funds into lost causes and foul publications to which student unions around this country subscribe. The people at Griffith University need to be congratulated for the way they have conducted themselves. They should feel very confident about their prospects to come.

Let us contrast that with the campus at the Queensland University of Technology, QUT. It is 10 years old, and the Australian vice-chancellors have met there recently to celebrate its 10th anniversary as a university. The QUT student union in 1996 directed $34,000 of student union funds to the socialist left member for Moreton at the time, and they failed. In fact, I would be delighted if they continued to contribute vast amounts of money into promoting the Labor Party cause, because it seems to fail every time they do. But $34,000 of student union funds from the Queensland University of Technology was directed deliberately into attacking the now government in the 1996 election, and I believe a similar or perhaps slightly smaller amount was contributed in the last election.

I have 34,000 good reasons to vote for this legislation. I have constituents in my elector ate who are students at that university who are outraged to see the money they are forced to contribute being used in such a blatant political way—multicoloured brochures which cost $34,000. The member for Melbourne made a comment before that student unions have had since the seventies to provide a direct benefit to students. How does $34,000 being spent in a political campaign provide a direct benefit to students?
Mr Slipper interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I suspect it was a blatant misappropriation of funds, and they know it. It is also important to reflect upon the vile rubbish that is published by some of these student unions around the country. The University of Queensland union literature contains information on drugs—on how to grow marijuana. Graphic material on sex is contained within the booklet. There is material on all sorts of things. I will not go into the detail of it, but when all is said and done it is absolutely foul and outrageous. It is hard to believe that this year's Sydney University of Technology's orientation handbook, which is published by the student union, contained graphic material on drug use. It is a do-it-yourself guide to drug use. That is what Minister Kemp said, and he is right.

speech.para: They had a section in the handbook titled `How to find a vein' and another titled `The best location for injection'. This would be all well and good if it were dealing with life saving diabetes injections, but it is actually telling students how to administer potentially life ruining drugs to naive first-year students at university. That sort of conduct is at the heart of why we have had to act in this way. Charging a compulsory fee on people as a condition of study and then using those funds, which are compulsorily seized, in such an irresponsible way and as a direct result causing additional harm to society is a practice that I believe we are rightly attempting to ruin and discredit.

I have received a lot of letters from the Australasian Campus Union Managers Association, and I have round filed most of them. What appeared to be a reasonable organisation from its title `Australasian Campus Union Managers Association' was actually care of the Monash University student union. When I discovered that, I realised that anything they had to say was without any credit. They have sent me so much rubbish over the last couple of months about this question, and I can understand why. They can see that finally the gravy train is going to be shunted into the yard and a few of their carriages are going to be unhooked.

More to the point, student unions such as those at Monash University, QUT and Queensland University are all going to have to work for their members. They are now going to have to provide services of value and services that students want—something which trade unions should be attempting to do to arrest the ongoing decline in membership. We do not need these lazy, arrogant organisations demanding compulsory contributions of fees. The member for Newcastle reflected on life in the mid-sixties, but this is the late 1990s. We are heading for the year 2000. If the practices of the 1960s are relevant today, then we will go through the sort of pain and torment in the economy that we have had over the last 25 years. The world has changed around us, and those opposite who continue to lament for the bygone glory days for unions had better realise that the union movement in general, and student unions in particular, have to get their act together and start to prove themselves to those they would like to have as members. It is obvious to me that the trade union movement generally is becoming nothing more than a sorting out ground for would-be members of parliament.

I want to reflect on the Western Australian example. It has been five years or so that the Western Australian government prohibited universities from the collection of compulsory fees for non-academic services, and voluntary student unionism in Western Australia has proved to be very successful. In order to raise and maintain membership levels, the unions have had to make themselves attractive to students and service student needs. They have had to provide the services that students want in a much more efficient way. Let us face it: there are some very good reasons why students would want to use these services—for example, career counselling services and drug abuse services. Perhaps the student union is promoting drug abuse because they are trying to get some more clients for that particular service they offer.

Those sorts of services that student unions have grown to offer over the years are relevant services. I would imagine any student coming to a campus who sees the value in being involved in an organisation offering those sorts of services would join. So that is the challenge that comes out of this bill. This is not an anti-union bill. This is a pro-student bill. It is a pro-freedom of choice bill. It is a pro-individual bill. It is at the heart of basic liberalism. It stands up for the rights of individuals. It champions their cause. It says, `No. A compulsory requirement to join an association is wrong, but attracting people to join is certainly right.' I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I have listened to some of the contributions in this debate on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . I have not needed to listen to the contributions from this side of the House, because without question all of them have merit. But quite the opposite is the case with the contributions which have come from our friends on the other side. I want to pick up on a couple of issues which were raised by the member for Moreton. It may be news to him, but half the universities in Australia have the same administrative structure in relation to student unions as Griffith University; it is not unique. He also made pejorative remarks about the support—alleged support—given by a particular student union to a candidate in the Labor Party. It should come as no news to him—I am sure it comes as no news to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, or to members of this House or to the general population—that you could hardly call student unions or associations or those who work for them as tame-cat organisations or lap-dogs of the Labor Party or lap-dogs of the Liberal Party. Over many years, student unions have properly exercised their democratic rights in any number of ways.

speech.para: I recall in the period when we were in government between 1987 and 1996, when I was in this House previously, there were many occasions when student unions, either individually or collectively, campaigned against proposals put forward by the then Labor government. One of the most significant campaigns they ran in those years was the campaign against HECS. The Labor government did not then turn around and say, `This is the end of it, we have got to cut off the lifeline of the student unions. We are going to make mute the democratic voice of students'—not at all. There is a fundamental principle of democracy at risk here, and that is the right of people to be actively involved in politics and support whomever they like at any given time. In this particular instance we have got this member railing again an organisation for apparently choosing to support a Labor candidate. I understand why they would support a Labor candidate, in the context of recent elections, but I have to say to him that there have been many times when student unions and student union representatives have not been friends of the Labor Party—much to our sorrow, I might say.

I think that you could describe this bill before us as venal. I see it as venal; I see it as destructive. It is venal, because we have had articulated today in this House the reasons why this bill is before us. It is two things: it is an act of political retribution and it is an attack on the rights of individuals to be involved in organisations. It is acknowledging—the previous speaker made mention of it—that what they are doing in this legislation is supporting the objectives of some of their rank and file members who have campaigned ideologically over the years for the abolition of student unions.

We understand why they want to abolish student unions, for their own stupid, puerile, ideological reasons. But in the context of what good government should be about, of what good public policy should be about, this is a venal attempt, because there is no good public policy reason for it. Frankly—I am sure it will come back and haunt the coalition—it is just bad politics. I would have thought that even they would not be immune to the thought that this might be a piece of bad politics. I know that there are members opposite who are very concerned about the implications of this piece of legislation for universities in their electorates. I know this is particularly so for people who live in regional and remote Australia, with its small regional universities. I am one of those people. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, the Northern Territory University is in my electorate, based in Darwin.

It is of no coincidence that we are discussing this piece of legislation today after another coalition budget in which we have again seen universities hit. I need to say this, because I think it puts in context the damage that will be done to the higher education sector as a result of this proposal by the government: this year, as a result of the budget, university operating grants are hit with their fourth consecutive year of cuts which were announced in the 1996 budget. I believe and the Labor Party believes that this almost $1 billion worth of cuts have seriously undermined the quality of education for students and the ability of our best researchers to succeed. Surely the first test of John Howard's claim that this budget will improve education is whether he will reverse these cuts. At the very least, he should order a halt to the latest one per cent cut in university funding which he announced in 1996 and which takes effect in this budget. At this stage I am certainly not aware of any initiatives, other than the maintaining of the ARC research funding, for universities.

It is worth noting that there was a four per cent decrease in the number of university applications in 1999 compared with the number of applications in 1996. The HECS increases have made it impossible for many students from ordinary families to go to university. This was an issue over which student unions campaigned. Frankly, their campaign had a great deal of merit, because what it said to the government was exactly what has happened—that it would be a discouragement to ordinary Australians, working families, to have their children go to university because of increased costs as a result of the changes to HECS.

Then we have the announcement in the budget last night to abolish the equity scholarships that help kids from the bush and low income families get their only chance to go to university. What is this about? What is going on when a government can announce a budget surplus in excess of $5 billion yet penalise the best and brightest of those people who might have a disadvantage in accessing higher education? What is the purpose of this?

I say to the government: if you have got one bone or shred of credibility in terms of your arguments about supporting those people who live in regional and remote Australia, you would overturn this instantly. I know they will not because, again, for whatever stupid reason, they have got a fix that this particular savings measure is somehow important to the bottom line of the budget. Give us a break.

For people in my electorate this is a damaging exercise. In my electorate this will discourage people from attending university. Yet we can thank the Howard government for it. It is in that context that I talk about the bill before us. It will further discourage people from participating at universities and further prevent universities, already struck down by consecutive years of cuts to their operating grants, from providing much needed services to students at their universities.

In the context of the Northern Territory University, it is relevant that we look at what has happened since 1996 when these budget cuts were first announced. We have seen the cancellation of the second stage of the library building on the NTU campus, leading to diminishing access to books, periodicals, electronic information and general communication services. We have seen the loss of ceramics and sculpturing from the School of Fine Arts of the university. We have seen the loss of the English department from the Faculty of Arts. Do you believe this? We have a university in Australia with an arts faculty without an English department. I stand here in amazement. This is the Northern Territory University trying to market itself to South-East Asia and it has not got an English department.

I leave it up to your judgment, Mr Deputy Speaker. Do you believe there can be any merit in having an argument about whether or not you can have an English department at a university? Would you not say that one of the most important things in any university—in Australia, at least—is to have an English department? But now, as a result of the cuts which were introduced by John Howard in 1996, there is no longer an English department at the Northern Territory University. Thank you very much, Mr Howard! I guess what he is trying to do is ensure that those people who attend institutes of higher education around Australia including the Northern Territory University do not have the wisdom, in terms of their expression, to be able to debate him—which would not be very difficult, frankly, because he and his government talk in riddles most of the time.

There has been the loss of the international student unit, which was replaced by one person working out of the student access and equity department. There has been the loss of the in-house catering service and other services such as the cleaning of rooms with no corresponding reduction in accommodation charges to residents of North Flinders International House, which is the place where we want to house those students we want to induce to come to Australia to study, among other things, one would assume, English.

We have seen the overcrowding of lectures and tutorials. There is less access to lecturers in out-of-class time. There has been the outsourcing of the child-care centre. We have seen the outsourcing of on-campus catering, leading to higher prices. We have seen the outsourcing of photocopying services, leading to higher prices. We have seen a single careers adviser for around 10,000 students. There has been the amalgamation of nine faculties into four. There has been the devolution from the central administration of important roles and responsibilities to faculties, and no supervisors for many postgraduate students. There has been a high level of attrition and departure of staff, leading to increased workloads and very low staff morale.

There are problems with external students getting materials on time. And as you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, in the context of the Northern Territory and indeed Northern Australia, external students form an important part of the student body. There are no special arrangements for the Northern Territory University which recognise its position as the most isolated regional university in Australia.

These events have all occurred directly as a result of cuts which have been made to the university since 1996 by the Howard government. We need to understand that the loss of universal membership of student organisations in remote and small universities like the Northern Territory will lead to their demise. It has been demonstrated very clearly in debate that it will mean a very clear reduction in the level of services which are available to students at those universities. Access will become a matter of whether or not you have the additional resources to pay for them. It will become something the privileged will benefit from and those from working families will not, because they will not have the additional resources required to pay for these additional services at cost. This is what would happen as a result of the proposals put forward by the government.

Ultimately, the proposals will mean that students will not have the choice of joining a student organisation because they will not have one at their university. Student organisations will become the domain of those who can afford the luxury of participating in the university hierarchy—the top end of town. The Australian community pays its representatives in order to ensure—and I believe this is true—that it is not purely the domain of those able to afford the lifestyle of deciding upon legislation. Nor should it be so in universities. We should be trying to ensure that there is the fullest level of participation in university life by all students, no matter where they are from. This legislation will inhibit the ability of students to participate actively in campus life and get the full benefit of a university education.

talk.start.para: —What about free choice?

—We hear this plaintive cry about free choice. Let me say this to the member who so wantonly interjected. I have in front of me a media release from the university of the Northern Territory, from the vice-chancellor, dated 26 February 1999. I will read part of that media release for the edification of the member opposite. Perhaps you would like to listen to this, Mr Slipper:

speech.para: Northern Territory University Council decided last night to support the status quo and oppose legislation which reportedly would proscribe compulsory student services fees. Professor Ron McKay said that—

talk.start.para: —So what?
—Just wait—

speech.para: the University Council was in agreement with the Students' Union on the question of amenities fees.

At NTU the amenities fee is compulsory and pays for a wide range of services. For example, the traditional Orientation Week, commencing on Monday, is among the events paid for by the amenities fee. The Student's Union has organised three weeks of activities for new and continuing students as they begin their academic year. A range of activities will introduce students to the Student Information Centre, the Sports Association, and clubs and societies. Social events will provide new students . . .
et cetera. I conclude this extract from this statement and I ask Mr Slipper to open his ears once again:
The Vice-Chancellor said the NTU has an exemption option on unionism. Students have the right to opt out of joining the Students' Union.
Does that satisfy the issue of choice, Mr Slipper?
Mr Slipper interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, what we have got is this plaintive cry from the government that this is about choice. This is not about choice at all.

speech.para: Mr Slipper interjecting—

talk.start.para: —This is a venal act of retribution against students who they do not like—and they recognise that we have got fools like this in this chamber who sit here and say that this is all about choice.
—It is about choice.
—It is not about choice; it is about your ideological bias. You have corrupted the minds of young Australians by saying—
—Order! I ask both members to address their remarks through the chair.
—Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the member opposite is a hypocrite.

—And you are a clown. Mr Deputy Speaker, we have seen what happens in this place when you put a bit of needle into some of these jokers, because they know that what we say is correct. They know that this is a venal exercise. They know that this is an act of political retribution against people they do not like. We know what the impact of this will be on student unions around Australia and on the university campuses.

speech.para: The vice-chancellors oppose this particular move. The student unions around Australia oppose this particular move. Young Liberals in New South Wales oppose this particular move, but not these great paragons of virtue who sit on the government benches. These are the people who have cut $1 billion out of the operating grants of universities. These are the people who are now saying to universities, `We will not have compulsory student fees, therefore you will not have access to those fees to provide the services that universities currently provide through those associations and union organisations to students.'

The people who will suffer will be the universities and the students—not the hoi polloi, not the top end of town, not those with the money to afford to pay for these services but the poor students. People in regional and remote Australia will suffer, but not these clowns on the other side.

You do not have to look too far into what student representative organisations do to understand their importance. They provide substantial services and activities and networking opportunities to students on and off campuses. If they ceased to exist, the ability of the NTU, in this case, to attract international or interstate students will be diminished quite substantially, leading to lower enrolments.

The government's intention in this area is a symptom of their lack of understanding of Australian universities and how they operate, and this is particularly true of the Northern Territory. I keep saying this: I come into this place and I am amazed at the decisions which are made by this government which impact negatively on regional and remote Australia. This is yet another one of them.

We know what this is about, and I have said it clearly before. This is about ripping the guts out of the organisations which represent students around Australia because these people do not like them. They are ideologically committed to getting rid of them. We had the member for Moreton admit as much in his contribution when he said that this is all about paying back those legions of supporters of the Liberal Party—there are not that many of them, I would have to say—who support the abolition of student unions. That is what this is about—retribution and an ideological commitment to payback.

I have to say that it does not go down well, because the people who will suffer as a result of this are young Australians, in particular, who aspire to go to university. The people in my electorate, people who live in Alice Springs, do not have the luxury of a university in their home town. They have to pay to go away to university. If they go to Darwin not only do they suffer the cost of the distance in travel and the cost of getting accommodation but now they are going to suffer the cost of purchasing independently and individually any of the services that are currently provided by the Northern Territory University Students Association. That is appalling. It is bad politics, and it is bad public policy.

talk.start.para: —No matter how thin you slice it, it is still baloney from the member for the Northern Territory. Let us start with access to schooling. I really want to talk about the budget. Obviously he has not read it but no doubt he will get to it. Basic boarding allowance has increased from $2,900 to $3,500.
—You did nothing for three years.
—A big boost for—
—You are giving back what you took.
—I listened to the other speakers in silence. I expect some courtesy.
—Order! I ask the members to address their remarks through the chair.

—We increased the basic boarding allowance. I met in one of the remote Aboriginal communities a lady struggling to send her daughter to boarding school some 2,000 kilometres away. This is going to be a tremendous boost for people on very low incomes who want to give their children the best opportunity.

speech.para: We hear about equity from the member for the Northern Territory. Who set up the medical school in Townsville that is going to give an opportunity for five young indigenous people every year to go to university? Who set up the medical school that is going to have 60 student places? You spoke about it in the 1970s, and you did nothing about it. We are delivering. Who has got rid of your new schools policy which was your `no schools' policy, which stopped a new school, a Christian based school, opening in my electorate? It is now going well. It is increasing its membership and teachers and is doing a great job in one of the very small towns in my electorate.

Talking about `venal', what nonsense! This is the government that is delivering on education. This is the government that is delivering for people in rural, regional and remote areas in terms of education. This is another initiative that is going to make it less costly for students from rural and remote areas to attend university. This bill is going to extend the fundamental human right of freedom of association to university students. To say the least, from the addresses given on the other side of the House, the Labor Party would like to force conscription on university students, to deny them freedom of association and to treat them as irresponsible children. The Labor Party has been joined in this insulting and repressive campaign by student union executives, whose interest is clearly self-serving, and, sadly, by vice-chancellors who seem to have no difficultly preaching that `teacher knows best' to people who have long got past high school.

I received a briefing paper from the National Union of Students on this matter, and it was a most impressive document. It outlined all of the undeniably wonderful benefits that student organisations provide for their mem bers and how students' lives are enriched by these benefits and services. This document was supposed to convince me that student unions play such a vital and indispensable role in the lives of students that they deserve special legislative protection from the basic human right of freedom of association.

The extraordinary irony and inherent contradiction of their whole argument seems to have escaped the National Union of Students. Surely if the student unions were so marvellously popular, so faultlessly attuned to students' needs and so critical to the very survival of students, then they would have no trouble at all in attracting voluntary subscriptions. However, by their own admission, this is not the case. That briefing paper claimed:

Common sense would indicate that given a choice many people would not pay their taxes, even though they support the services and activities performed by their councils or other forms of government. This is also the case amongst students. Given the choice students will not pay fees, even though they may continue to want, support and make use of the services and representation provided by student organisations.

This seems to me a very illiberal and patronising view by the National Union of Students leadership of their constituency. Are they suggesting that all students—and I noted there was no qualification of the assertion with the words `some' or even `many'—are so irresponsible, so immature and so selfish that they would happily and, without so much as a twinge of conscience, use services they refuse to fund?
On 10 March I wrote to the National President of the National Union of Students and drew the plain implication of this assertion to his attention. I quote from that letter:

Twenty odd years ago when I was a student, we will liked to consider ourselves amongst the brightest and the best in the nation with keen intellects and probing minds. We liked to think that we were capable of making well-informed, independent decisions and certainly would have resented anybody (least of all our elected union leaders) portraying us as—
layabouts. The letter continues:

Have things changed so much in two decades that students today don't mind being so presented by their union officials? I would hazard the opinion that students today would consider themselves as we considered ourselves way back in the 1970s as intelligent and independent individuals.
I have not received any reply to that letter.

I am very proud to inform the House that the Queensland Young Nationals were the first youth political group to adopt voluntary student unionism as their policy. So, rather than hearing the hot air from the other side, let us hear from some of the young people who have actually written to me about this policy. Queensland Young Nationals, I might add, also draw their membership from throughout regional and rural Queensland and, of course, include a great many students at various tertiary institutions. Demonstrably, they are unimpressed by the views of the various student unions, by the leadership of the National Union of Students and by the opposition, who all believe that tertiary students need to be told by their elders and their union leaders what is good for them. I might add that all these students were happy to have their names and their comments reported in Hansard which shows how strongly they feel about this. One Young National in my electorate is George Christensen. He advised me:

After twice neglecting to pay my student union fees, I was sent a notice advising me that my enrolment would be terminated if I didn't pay up. If this occurred anywhere else, it would be considered blackmail and the author of the notice would go to gaol.
Mr Christensen has also observed:
Student unions make a lot of noise about HECS fees financially hurting students, yet the only compulsory up-front fee they are compelled to pay is their Student Union one.
Queensland's Young Nationals' Youth Ambassador, Mr Martin Klibbe, has written:

In a free, celebrated democracy like the Commonwealth of Australia, I find it incomprehensible and repugnant that student unions in concert with ivory tower academics can hold a gun to students' heads and demand payment. This undemocratic practice amounts to little more than extortion.

These are students saying this, not the opposition, not the government. They are students from families who have struggled to send them to university, who live in rural and regional areas and go to rural and regional university campuses. Mr Klibbe has quite rightly observed:

A $300 student union subscription is an unreasonable impost on students who are recognised as one of the most disadvantaged groups in our society. As a fourth year tertiary student, I can attest that I seldom get value for money from my student dues. Instead of serving the body of mainstream students, union services are geared towards the noisiest minorities. A university card that entitles me to discounts at the Gay and Lesbian Health Clinic and a recent student publication detailing how to shoot up heroin are cases in point.

That is how student compulsory union fees were spent at this university. How appalling. Another Queensland Young National, Mr James Lister, who has also welcomed this initiative by the government, has written:

Compulsory student unionism is as undemocratic as it is unproductive and it strikes at the heart of the very principles that the proponents of compulsory student unionism claim to espouse. Therefore, with the move to voluntary student unionism, students will at last be treated as customers rather than a captive source of funds.
Mr Lister made the observation about his student union—which provided him with a diary for his membership fee and little, if anything, else:
The ulterior motive of your average student union commissar is to keep democracy out of student politics and, by extension, to keep unionism compulsory.

These Young Nationals and young students reflect the views of a large number of students who want the freedom to decide how, when and where they spend a considerable slice of their generally meagre and hard-earned income.

In the opinion of the opposition, the student union elites and the education industry mafia, these views are regarded as immature, irresponsible, selfish, short-sighted and ignorant. However, I happen to believe these students are right. My view is reinforced by my own personal experience as a student at the University of Queensland way back in the 1970s. When I was studying electrical engineering, I was forced to be a member of the student union. I was in a financially precarious position and worked part time to support myself. I was a long way from home and my parents were not able to make much of a financial contribution at that time. With lecture, tutorial, work and study commitments—not to mention the daily grind of caring for a flat and purchasing groceries—and a rather limited off-campus social life, I had no real opportunity to participate in a range of so-called student services funded from compulsory student fees. Some I found politically and morally repugnant, some I regarded as irrelevant and some simply did not interest me.

talk.start.para: —Like the cafeteria?

—You don't want to pay for your lunch; is that it? You want a free lunch? Is that what you want? The Labor Party always wants a free lunch. I will tell you what; most people in Australia recognise that there is no free lunch and they are happy to pay for it.

speech.para: A chronic shortage of time and sometimes energy severely limited my enjoyment from these services. I felt then and I feel now that I was the best judge of how to spend my precious and limited income. I have had to wait 20 years to help deliver to students what I sorely wanted then—the right to choose. Better late than never.
The Queensland Labor Minister for Education, Mr Dean Wells, however, is an interesting case. He wrote to me on 16 March pleading the case for enforced conscription of students. He wrote:

The requirement for universal participation in the student organisation has significant benefits to the institution, and to students. In particular, it helps to ensure that all students can participate in their own representation, rather than allowing that process to become the captive to a small number of activists.

I seem to recall that Minister Wells, in his student days, raged against conscription to the Army during the Vietnam conflict because of his passionate commitment to, among other things, the principle of freedom of choice and association. As the years have moved on, it seems that Mr Wells's principles have moved on as well. He is now in the front line of those who like to think that they know better what students want and need than the students themselves. Clearly, Mr Wells is in the education mafia camp that regards students as irresponsible, self-centred layabouts.

There is an undeniable inherent contradiction in the twin arguments advanced by the opponents of this bill. On the one hand there is the strident claim that students themselves do not want this freedom of choice, yet on the other hand there is the gloomy forecast that the happy world on campus as we now know it will shatter into a million pieces once this bill becomes law. I wonder at the processes of intellectual rigour that allow this joint presentation. Minister Wells, in his letter to me that I referred to earlier, also wrote:

In 1973, the Commonwealth assumed responsibility for the funding of higher education in Australia. In doing so, it undertook to provide funds for the teaching and research activities of higher education institutions only, on the understanding that student representative and amenities fees would continue to be the responsibility of the student and that institutions would make these fees compulsory for all students.
Presumably Minister Wells thought that an appeal to me based on a decision taken 26 years ago by the Whitlam government would be massively persuasive. He could not have been more wrong.

He also informed me that student union fees were currently worth $24 million annually and that about 500 jobs were provided by these fees. It is a big business with a big self-interest. Judging by the evidence of the near-hysterical objections to this bill, this big business is staring collapse and ruination in the face when the bill becomes law. Yet we keep being told that students love, honour and respect services their unions provide but, unfortunately, do not have the decency and honesty to voluntarily and decently pay for them.

Students currently face compulsory up-front fees which exceed $300 in some cases, with the average fee being about $250. This is a considerable impost on students who traditionally are amongst the poorest. It is a reprehensible oppression to force low income earners to pay compulsory union fees, and I will not be a party to it.

Universities have a duty to prepare their students for the real world, and the real world today is one of free choice. Compulsory unionism is being discarded into the dustbin of history and the inexorable decline of unions—to the absolute horror of those on the other side—reflects the contemporary reality of people making their own independent choices. By resisting this bill, the Labor Party is making a last gasp try to keep alive the outdated notion of unionism that passed its heyday almost a generation ago. Students, like the rest of us, have the absolute right to decide how to spend their own money and whether or not to join any organisation. Surely we can rely upon the good sense of university students to make an informed choice about their own lives.

In Western Australia, tertiary student unions have been voluntary organisations for some time following state government legislation. The outcome is interesting. In the 1998 annual report, dated 18 September last, the president of the University of Western Australia's Guild of Undergraduates, Ms Rosie Dawkins, reported, amongst other things, that the guild had had a very strong year in terms of representing students on education issues. There had been an increased involvement in on-campus cultural activities and a strong commitment to social justice issues, including textbook subsidies for needy students.

The guild was still producing the weekly student newspaper and was covering production costs with advertising. The number of clubs affiliated with the guild continued to grow and 80 clubs claimed for grants in 1998 and 20 had club rooms. The guild introduced a large number of computer training courses at inexpensive prices for needy students and continued to provide services such as assistance in mediation and academic appeals. Overall, the annual report was a story of considerable progress and significant achievement. It illustrated how a practical, truly student oriented student union could attract voluntary subscriptions.

As I said earlier, if student unions are to be truly responsive to the needs of students, they should not have any fear of the future. I welcome this enlightened legislation and am very happy to support the minister on this very forward thinking initiative.

speech.para: What a disgrace for this House that the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs arranged for the gag to be imposed on a debate about voluntary student unionism and he couldn't even be bothered turning up for the vote.
