He couldn't even be bothered turning up to vote to guillotine debate in this House on a matter that is crucial to the future of campuses right across the country, a matter that is crucial to the future of the jobs of 2,500 people. This minister for education couldn't even be bothered to get himself here in this House. In moving the guillotine in this debate the people who say they are all about giving us freedom of choice are not prepared to have freedom of speech in this House. Twenty other members of the Labor Party wanted to speak in this debate. The Independent member for Calare, Peter Andren, also wanted to contribute to the debate. Yet we had the government coming in here using its numbers to guillotine and end debate.

I suspect the real reason they guillotined debate is that this minister was not prepared to come in to wind up the second reading debate. He did not have the guts to come in here and defend the indefensible. He is like a drowning man out there. His head has sunk below the surface of the water. The bubbles are drifting up towards the surface. We know this is a drowning man—a drowning man who has brought before this parliament legislation that is vindictive and destructive. It is vindictive because this is this minister's attempt to silence student organisations across the country because they had the temerity to oppose this government's $800 million cutbacks in federal funding for universities. That is why it is vindictive.

This is destructive legislation because this minister knows that, if the legislation is passed by the parliament, services right across the country will be hit. When the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs puts the boot into student unions, he also puts the boot into child-care services like the one at the Caulfield campus of Monash. When he puts the boot into student organisations, he puts the boot into the sporting facilities right across the country, he puts the boot into the theatre at the University of Melbourne, he puts the boot into legal advice, into sexual counselling, into housing assistance and into the right for student organisations to speak out and represent the interests of students in negotiating with the vice-chancellors. This minister, in putting the boot into student organisations, undermines the viability of dental services for students. He does not even understand that services like cafeterias and dental assistance to students are placed in jeopardy by this legislation.

We understand that the campuses that are going to be hardest hit by the legislation are those in regional areas and the new and growing campuses. That is why the member for Kennedy has been out there in the media saying he is against the legislation. But, when it came to a vote in this chamber, the member for Kennedy got gutless and voted with the government to impose VSU. That is why we have seen right across the country coalition backbenchers making statements in their local media expressing concern about the damage that the legislation will do. We have had at least four government backbenchers expressing concern about the damage of the legislation, telling us that the minister has misled his own party room—refused to answer questions in his own party room about the damage that will be done by the legislation.

But it is not just the students, the staff, the vice-chancellors, the members of the coalition's own backbench, the Labor Party and the Democrats who are against the legislation; the Tasmanian Liberal members of the Legislative Assembly, the New South Wales Young Liberals and great Australian sportsmen like Geoff Lawson are expressing concern about the damage that will be done by this government in its attempts to silence student organisations.

We know that this is a debate that the government are afraid to engage in. They have gagged debate here. Members of the government have refused to participate in debates on campuses across the country. This is the first minister for education who is not able to visit a campus anywhere across the country. When was the last time, Minister, you agreed to a debate with a Labor Party member about VSU? If you really do believe in this, why won't you debate me or any other Labor Party member on any campus across the country? We know that it is this minister who will be held accountable for the damage that this legislation will do. It is this minister who will do enormous damage to student services right across the country. We know that this minister probably will not nominate for the electorate of Goldstein at the next election because he has been so badly damaged by the policies that he has introduced not only on VSU but also on other educational matters. (Time expired)

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —What we are seeing on the part of the other side of the House is their classic willingness to defend the union interests behind the Labor Party. There is nothing that gets Labor members into this chamber quicker than their desire to defend their union mates. They are over there in numbers because probably every Labor member sitting on the other side of the House at the moment is an ex-trade union official. We know that 100 per cent of them are union members, and a very large proportion of them are ex-union officials. That brings them in in droves.

speech.para: I know that many of those opposite would like to have taken part in this debate and, as a parliamentarian and somebody dedicated to this parliament, I sympathise with their inability to take part in this debate. But any opposition member who would like to have taken part in this debate and who now does not have the opportunity should register their protest with the shadow minister, because the government gave the opportunity for an extra two hours debate on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 in the Main Committee and the shadow minister turned it down. So much for his dedication to have the VSU debated in this chamber. What we have seen is nothing more than the confected outrage of these union lap-dogs. Nobody displays this more than the shadow minister at the table who is essentially just the spokesperson in this House for the Australian Education Union. The Labor Party has no education policy. The member for Werriwa has made the chamber very aware of that. The education policy they tried to put forward at the last election was completely stuffed up.
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much interjection. I call on those on my left to observe the orders of the House—and those on the government side as well.

—Not only don't they respect the House; they don't respect the right of students to decide whether or not they will join a student organisation. They know that compulsory student unionism is the last bastion of the closed shop in Australia—the great ideal of the ACTU. This is the last bastion. We have rolled back the closed shop in every other area of Australian life, but the union officials are out there trying to defend this last bastion of the closed shop and trying to deny to students the right to decide whether they will join a student association or not.

speech.para: We hear all sorts of horror stories about the terrible consequences that will flow from freedom of association. We have even heard the nonsense from the shadow minister here today that freedom of association for students is in fact a threat to freedom of speech on behalf of students. What utter rubbish to say that freedom of association is a threat to freedom of speech. That is a new one in democratic theory.

These people have not got a clue about how democracy really works. All they know is the way the union movement has traditionally dragooned unwilling members into its ranks so it can use their money for its own propaganda, and of course that is what happens, year after year, on university campuses. The one huge gaping hole in the case that the Labor Party has put forward is the fact that in one state of Australia, Western Australia, we already have voluntary student unionism in the sense in which it is being moved in this legislation by the Commonwealth.

In that state we have vibrant student associations. You only have to read the information that those student associations put out to see how vibrant they are. We see how vibrant the sporting life on those university campuses is. In fact, the Australian University Games this year will be in Western Australia, hosted by the Western Australian universities. They make no secret of the fact that they are very vibrant these days and that they are much more responsive to students than they ever were. They know that they will not get student members unless they offer the services that students are looking for. So we have a pattern of student services in Western Australia which is much more responsive to the needs of students than we see elsewhere in Australia where students are dragooned to contribute. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —One has to wonder what horrible experience the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs had at university. Minister, why do you hate universities so much? Why do you refuse to visit campuses? Why are you determined to undermine the services that are provided to students on campuses these days? What horrible things did they do to you that you are determined to wreak this revenge on them? That is what we want to know.

speech.para: Listening to that speech, you have to understand that the minister squibbed a full debate on the second reading. He would have had 20 minutes to respond and then wind up the second reading debate but he squibbed that when he imposed the guillotine. Listening to that five-minute speech from the minister, I was reminded of that good Australian band—Not Drowning, Waving—only here was the minister not waving desperately at the dispatch box but drowning. Here is a minister who has abolished in this budget equity scholarships for students right across the country, a minister who says he supports Australia being a clever country but is going to deny clever kids from the bush and from low income families their chance to go to university—and he sits at the table here laughing.

talk.start.para: —That is actually so absurd.

—And he interjects and claims that the case is absurd. He says that abolishing the government's own scheme to benefit the kids from needy and rural families—to give them a chance to go to university—is an absurd case. Minister, that is just further evidence of how deep you are sinking as you drown in a sea of unfair policies.

speech.para: The minister claims that the University Games going to Western Australia proves that VSU is a great success in WA. Minister, the real test for you is: if this legislation is passed, will you guarantee that the University Games will be held the following year in Ballarat? It is already common knowledge that the viability of the games at Ballarat has been placed in jeopardy by your own legislation. Think of the `economic stimulus' that Ballarat and other towns are going to get if you succeed in putting the boot into student organisations and sports associations right round the country.

The minister claims that it is a great success in Western Australia, and at least he did not use the arguments of his favourite spokesman on this point, Senator Ross Lightfoot. The evidence that Senator Lightfoot quoted to demonstrate that VSU is a great success is this:

para.inline: VSU is such a great success the student unions are now providing services that are more relevant to students.

speech.para: That is why it is working well, according to Senator Ross Lightfoot, and his evidence is that at one campus they have closed down a child-care centre and opened a hairdressing salon. That is how Senator Lightfoot argues VSU is a success.

Minister, we just make the point to you that in Western Australia, as well as undermining not just the political activity of, and the rights to representation by, the student unions, they have undermined the ability of the student guilds to provide cafeterias, legal advice, housing assistance and counselling. In other campuses across the country unions also provide things like medical assistance and dental care. Minister, why are you trying to deny students at places like the Caulfield campus of Monash University the ability to get dental care? Why are you trying to deny those students the ability to get the housing assistance that they might need to get a unit organised or to get some accommodation fixed up? Right across the country this legislation, if it is passed, will do enormous damage.

Let me remind the House of the comments that the member for Higgins, the Treasurer of Australia, made when he knew a bit more about student organisations than he did today. When he was head of the Monash Association of Students, he said this:

para.inline: Since student unions do have a positive contribution to offer to student welfare and student education, they should be supported by all those who profit from them. The funding, and therefore the provision, of services would be impossible unless there was some requirement to pay a contribution.

speech.para: So the Treasurer—a long time ago when he knew more about student organisations—knew that you had to have a universal fee to provide universal services. You cannot afford to have free-riders—who use the services, the cafeterias and the sporting facilities and who get the dental care, the legal advice and the counselling—use the services and not make a contribution. It would be like saying that local government rates should be voluntary.

We all know what would happen if they were voluntary, Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker: you would pay yours but at least 80 per cent of people would not pay their local council rates and the council would have to cut back the money it spends on roads, garbage collection, looking after parks, building footpaths and so on. That is the reason why we say this minister's legislation is vindictive and destructive. It is going to do enormous damage to student services right across the country. This minister is the man that we are going to hold responsible for the enormous damage that is going to be done on campuses right across the country, and that is the reason why this minister will not be a candidate for the House of Representatives at the next election. (Time expired)

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —We have just heard the spokesmen for the policy vacuum on the Labor side of the House. We have not heard a single constructive comment on education from this shadow minister since he became a shadow minister. The only issue which attracts Labor members in droves into the House is the defence of union privilege, the defence of the closed shop. That can at least be guaranteed to get them up and get them into the chamber to debate some issue in education.

speech.para: You cannot help feeling a certain pang of pity for all those members to whom the shadow minister denied the opportunity to speak in this debate. As I said, the government offered two hours in the Main Committee, but the shadow minister decided no, he was not going to go down to the Main Committee, he was too big and important for the Main Committee, he is going to debate only in this chamber. So the member for Canberra, the member for Grayndler, the member for Braddon, the member for Bruce, the member for Chifley, the member for Kingston, the member for Calare, the member for Throsby, the member for Fremantle, the member for Sydney, the member for Batman and the member for McMillan were all denied an opportunity to speak for 10 minutes in the Main Committee by the shadow minister.

We made a very fair offer to the shadow minister, and he turned it down because he was not interested in giving those sitting behind him an opportunity to speak in this debate. Indeed, if the members on the other side had been willing to speak for five minutes in the Main Committee, we could also have had the member for Melbourne Ports speaking. As I recall, the member for Melbourne Ports was a strong opponent of compulsory student unionism in his student days. In fact, he attacked the thuggery of the union of students in his days.

He could have been accompanied by—and who knows perhaps some of these others are secret supporters of voluntary student unionism—the member for Burke; the member for Reid; the member for Shortland; the member for Werriwa, who could easily even now be a supporter of voluntary student unionism; the member for Isaacs, I do not know that he has views on anything very much; the member for Greenway; and the member for Corio. All these Labor members were denied the opportunity to speak on behalf of the closed shop. While I totally disagree with their views on this matter, in the words of Voltaire, `I defend to the death their right to say it.' That is why we offered you the opportunity to debate this issue in the Main Committee and why the shadow minister, who is far too grand for the Main Committee, decided to turn it down.

The great hole in the Labor Party's case on this is that we already have voluntary student unionism in one state in exactly the sense that the Commonwealth is seeking to legislate for, and in that state we have a very vibrant student life. All this scare talk about the termination of student services around Australia is shown to be totally fallacious by the experience in Western Australia. Indeed, I recently had the opportunity to see a presentation by the sports union at the University of Western Australia which made the point that they now had more income than they had in the days of compulsory student unionism. That presentation was making an argument to the sports associations at all the other universities that, with well managed sports unions under voluntary student unionism, it is quite possible to attract the members and the funding that will provide a vital sports life on campus. Those are the facts. The member for Dobell raised a lot of other matters which I may have the opportunity to respond to in a few minutes time.

talk.start.para: —As I was the next speaker to jump to her feet in this debate, I reject totally the comments just made by the minister. I was scheduled to have a 20-minute speech in this chamber on an issue of importance relevant to this chamber. I deplore totally his fallacious arguments just then when he said that we could have had a decent debate in the Main Committee.

speech.para: It is interesting to note that the temporary role model for many of those opposite in general political terms has been, and still is, the Thatcher government. The Thatcher government was also urged to take action to prevent compulsory student union membership but they very wisely decided against it. In 1983, Thatcher's education secretary, Sir Keith Joseph, argued:

para.inline: . . . the student union is not the same as an industrial union. What we have in the students' union is automatic membership and automatic access to facilities . . . And I do not see how we can therefore make membership voluntary.

speech.para: I would like the member for Forde, who gave a contribution of 20 minutes in this place earlier today, to think very carefully about that because she went to a great effort in her contribution to this debate to try to draw some similarity between union membership on the campus of a tertiary facility and union membership in the industrial sense. There is no connection; there never has been any connection. It is quite misleading for any member in this place, including the minister, to try to draw that conclusion.

In the Australian context we need look no further than the current Treasurer, Mr Costello, for the sound argument in support of universal membership. Our shadow minister has already made mention of his comments earlier in the historical sense—and I will not repeat them—but I can say that the Treasurer was absolutely correct then and he is absolutely incorrect now to try to change his mind and have it each way. All students benefit from the provision of services and facilities. The Australian parliament should not be encouraging free riding on Australian campuses.

I would like to commend the student body in Canberra for the active role that they have taken in this debate. Many of them have met with me and gone out of their way to make sure that I really understand the impact that this legislation will have on the very services that they enjoy within their campus life. It is fair to remind the House and those opposite of the sorts of services that these student union organisations provide within campus life—we need to say this over and over again—because these are the very services that are going to come under direct threat and will probably disappear in a great majority of cases.

In relation to the tertiary facilities within my electorate here in the ACT, which many of my student members of the community enjoy and use, are things like dealing with problems with Centrelink—we can all associate with that—with Austudy, with Abstudy, with the youth allowance and so on. They also provide free legal advice. The students association also has trained university mediators and sexual harassment contact officers. They have an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students association. They provide a parenting room. They subsidise photocopy use and fax use. They give financial advice and assistance as well as providing emergency grants.

They also provide sport and recreation programs. They help with grievances and mediation across the board, let alone provide access to coffee shops, nutritional food, and social life on campus, generally—all of which nurtures the non-academic side of the lives of these young people. These are the sorts of facilities and atmosphere that should exist, particularly today with the pressures of study and the pressures of achievement that these people are facing.

As I have said, I am very pleased that the young student body in the ACT have made the effort that they have in exposing this legislation for what it is. I have enjoyed meeting with them. I have enjoyed listening to their concerns, and I really regret that I have not had the opportunity in this chamber, over a 20-minute period of debate, to go to further lengths in explaining their concerns. I thank them, and I continue with my absolute opposition to the government's ideological and petty agenda on the student services issue driven by this ideological minister.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —It is interesting to think where ideology rests in this debate. The government is standing on behalf of a principle which I believe most Australians, except apparently those on the other side of the House, support—that is, the principle of freedom of association.
—What about freedom of speech?

—And freedom of speech, just for the benefit of the shadow minister. The government supports freedom of association, which is a fundamental support for freedom of speech. When you do not have freedom of association, when you have compulsory association—which we know now a very significant part of the Labor Party backbench still hanker after—you do not have genuine freedom of speech at all, because inevitably money is taken from students who do not agree with the student leaders spending it on behalf of their main political causes and their propaganda. That is what the Labor Party means by freedom of speech: you take money away from Liberal students or from students who do not have any particular opinion and you spend it on behalf of the opinions of the Labor Party's union mates.

speech.para: We know how far the Labor Party was prepared to go to defend that position of privilege. When the Labor Party was in power and a form of voluntary student unionism was introduced in Victoria, the member for Hotham, Simon Crean, introduced legislation into the parliament which allowed him to use taxpayers' money to pay these student unions if the students themselves refused to pay the money. Even if students did not want the leaders of these student unions to be acting the way they were on campuses, the Labor Party's attitude was: `Well, that doesn't matter to us. These are our union mates and, if you students won't give them money, we'll give them taxpayers' money.' That disgraceful, disreputable, undemocratic piece of legislation is still on the books, and it is going to be vigorously defended by the Labor Party.

In my former life I used to be a political scientist. One of the things that political scientists discover is that ideology is a great motivator in politics, that the most active are often the most ideological. When you see the level of activity in this debate and you look at the incredible list on the Labor side of the House and at the sensible and responsible number of speakers that the government has put up, you cannot help concluding that ideological motivation is certainly much heavier on that side of the House than it is on this side of the House. They poured into the House to justify privilege. This government is very proud to stand in this debate on the basis of freedom of association.

Yes, we are ideologically committed to freedom of association. We are ideologically committed to freedom of speech. We are ideologically committed to students having the right to decide whether their money is going to be spent on causes they support or on causes someone else supports. The irony of all of this is that the compulsory student fee is the largest up-front fee, in fact the only compulsory up-front fee, that students in Australia have to pay. If the government's legislation is passed, Australian students will be relieved of the necessity of compulsorily paying the Labor Party's up-front fee of around $300 a year just to support their union mates.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity, belatedly, to speak for a short time on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 today. Members on this side were gagged from debate. That is absolutely consistent with this government's attitude, which is all about silence: the silence of dissent from this government's reactionary, ideologically driven agenda. We have heard from the minister opposite all about the $300 compulsory fee. This is from the minister who has increased HECS by $2,000 a year. But that does not matter; we do not hear anything about that.

speech.para: This bill will decimate services to students on campuses—accommodation services, health, counselling, student loans, legal advice, orientation programs, social activities. All those organisations which contribute to campus life and contribute to the broader education of students will be decimated by this legislation. The second thing that the minister talks about is all these political causes. That is the real agenda here. It is about silencing democracy and silencing the voice of students.

Let us look at the role of student unions. We were in government for 13 years. What was the role of students during that period? Most of the time they were out demonstrating against us and against measures we were taking, because that is their role. A vibrant democracy requires dissent and requires representation of all groups in society, including students. But we did not shut them down. In fact, the minister is quite right that, when the Victorian and Western Australian governments chose to introduce legislation to take away student representation, the federal Labor government moved in to reinforce the fact that they had that right of association.

The freedom of association question is also worth addressing. The fact is that in a number of legal cases both here and internationally the minister is wrong—Clark v. The University of Melbourne; Harradine v. The University of Adelaide; and the case before the European Court of Human Rights, Le Compte v. Belgium, which was about the right of doctors to associate. The US Supreme Court, the Canadian Supreme Court, and even the UN Human Rights International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights very importantly draw the distinction between freedom of association and freedom from association.

That is why they chose those words carefully, because there is freedom of association on campuses. That is why on every major campus in Australia you will find a Labor club, you will find a Liberal club, you will find an environmental group, you will find a Greek society and other organisations, because that is where the freedom of association comes in. That is why you have elections on campuses which democratically allow students to elect their leadership to determine where those funds should be spent.

If we look back at the political role of students and the ability to question, we will see that sometimes young people in society do get it right when older generations have got it wrong. The issue of apartheid comes to mind. The student movement in Australia played a very important role in putting that on the agenda, let alone the Vietnam war issue. Historically, that was important in later governments. Of course, the current Prime Minister was a great defender of the apartheid system in South Africa, but most of the world came to the right conclusions before he did. Then there is the Deputy Prime Minister, who said that Soeharto would be remembered as one of the great statesmen of the 20th century. Students were pointing out the problems of a lack of democracy in places like Indonesia well before others. I defend their right.

It is consistent. It is why this government shut down AYPAC—young people were telling us it was ridiculous to treat them as dependent until they were 25. At least the student unions should be grateful we have not had dogs and men in balaclavas sent in, so I guess it is relatively moderate. This legislation is not about freedom of association; it is all about oppression, suppression, denying representation, silencing dissent, silencing democracy. In the long run, a strong democracy requires participation and requires the active support of government, not this attack.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —We have just heard a speech from a member of the Left faction of the Labor Party. It used to be called the Socialist Left.
—It still is.

—Oh, it still is called the Socialist Left. At least he is honest. This is the faction that, throughout the years of socialist governments in eastern Europe, never stood up to defend democracy. They were prepared to accept the empty rhetoric of the socialist movements around the world that these manipulated elections were somehow or other really democratic. That was the position of the Left. It has always been one of the great scars on the Labor Party that the Left faction has never been a supporter of true democracy, has never been a supporter of basic principles like freedom of association and freedom of speech; it has always been a supporter of the manipulated democracies overseas that finally collapsed under the weight of the outrage of their citizens. That, in a sense, is what is going on at the moment on university campuses. It is outraged students who are fed up with being compulsorily asked to pay up-front fees for student unions that are the strongest supporters of voluntary student unionism.

speech.para: The government is very pleased to take its stand on the basis of fundamental democratic principles. However, I must refute the extra ordinarily incorrect statement made by the member for Grayndler in this debate, which is again typical of the kinds of distortions you get from the Left, that the present Prime Minister was ever a supporter of apartheid. The present Prime Minister and, indeed, previous leaders of the coalition have been very strong opponents of apartheid. I remember when I worked for Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser that he was one of the people who foresaw, earlier than most statesmen in the world, the inevitable defeat of the apartheid system.

The Liberal Party and the National Party, the coalition, have been very clear-sighted throughout their histories as parties about the basic principles on which democracy rests. That enabled us to see clearly, in a way that the Labor Party Socialist Left never saw, through the spurious claims and empty rhetoric of the socialist movements around the world. It enabled us to uphold the torch of democracy at a time when capitulationism was ripe on the other side of the House. So I do not think anybody in this chamber will be terribly impressed when they hear the current defence of the closed shop on campus by a member of the Left faction.

This issue has been debated at some length in this House. It could have been debated at greater length if the shadow minister had not rejected the opportunity to debate in the Main Committee. He was not really interested in continuing this debate because he knows that any democrat who believes in freedom of association and freedom of speech will realise, having heard this debate, that the Labor Party does not have a leg to stand on. There has not been a single convincing argument against the government's legislation put up by those on the other side of the House. I think it is time to draw the debate to a close. I move:

para.inline: That the question be now put.

talk.start.para: —With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, we will not be forcing a division on this, but I make it clear that the Labor Party will oppose this on the voices. It is an outrage.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Dr Kemp)—by leave—read a third time.

para.inline: That standing order 48A (adjournment and next meeting) be suspended for the sitting on Thursday, 13 May 1999.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.inline: That the time for presenting the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector on the degree of industry concentration within the retailing sector in Australia be extended to 30 August 1999.

speech.para: Very briefly, this committee was appointed on 10 December 1998 but, for various reasons, the committee membership was not finalised until 15 February 1999. They did not hold their first meeting until 16 February 1999, effectively putting the committee two months behind schedule. The resolution of appointment for the committee provided a six-month reporting date from the establishment—namely, 10 June 1999.

The committee has received a large number of submissions. The first round of public hearings in capital cities commenced in April 1999 and indicated a high level of public interest in the inquiry. Because of the current parliamentary sitting pattern, it is not possible to conduct further public hearings until July, which will therefore further delay the schedule. It is proposed to hold these hearings in parts of rural and regional Australia.

Because of the importance of the inquiry, the complexity of the issues involved and the initial delay in getting under way, the government has accepted the advice from the committee that it would be appropriate for there to be this relatively short extension of the time in which the committee would report. I understand that it has the support of the committee. Given that it is very important that people have an opportunity to be heard, the government has accepted that recommendation. I commend this minor procedural motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 30 March, on motion by Mr Vaile:

para.inline: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 is the latest legislative response to problems in the wool industry by a government that has lurched from crisis to crisis in handling the future of this great rural industry. The opposition does not intend to oppose this legislation as we recognise the importance of putting into place these legislative arrangements for the benefit of those producers who still have equity in the stockpile and who seek a return on their past production. However, it is important to put on the public record the concern of many growers about the consultation processes surrounding the development of new privatised arrangements for Wool International.

speech.para: In response to those concerns, the opposition initiated a Senate references committee inquiry to allow public comment by producers with some concerns about elements of the minister's proposal. Should that inquiry report uncover further problems of substance with this legislation, the opposition reserves its right to consider appropriate amendments in the other place to ensure that the equity of producers and their right to have a meaningful say in the commercial structures developed to dispose of the remainder of the stockpile are adequately protected.

As we debate this legislation in the House today, one of the central problems facing wool growers and indeed the wool industry—the disposal of the wool stockpile—still remains. Because of the stockpile freeze initiated by the Howard government, there still exists a wool stockpile of around one million bales. The problem of disposing of this wool in a way that preserves the equity of the people who produce and own that wool, and minimising the impact of its sale on wool markets, still remains.

I remind the House and indeed the industry of the words of the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry in his second reading speech, which was delivered to this House on 30 March this year, in which he had this to say:

para.inline: This is a good outcome to a very difficult and longstanding issue which had become the Achilles heel of the industry.

speech.para: Minister, if the one million bales of the stockpile represent the Achilles heel of the industry, and indeed it does represent one of the Achilles heels of the industry, then the problem is still there. Wool producers have not been freed of the burden imposed by the presence in the marketplace of the wool stockpile. The wool stockpile still casts its shadow over a marketplace which is increasingly turning demand to synthetic and other fibres, and which is not generating sufficient demand to restore wool prices to anywhere near the levels required to maintain the viability of the many small farm units engaged in the production of this commodity.

This is an opportune time for us all to reflect on the circumstances that gave rise to this stockpile freeze, because they demonstrate the absolute incompetence and lack of political will by National Party ministers in this coalition government. The decision to freeze the stockpile was not made on the basis of any rational commercial imperative; it was made for political reasons as the Liberal and National parties cowered at the foot of One Nation before the last election.

We all know that most of the industry opposed this freeze. It is a matter of public record also that the minister for agriculture at the time also opposed the freeze, and he took that position to the cabinet table. But it was the National Party ministers, weak as they were, who got rolled over by a Liberal Prime Minister and a rural Liberal from WA who happened to have the Prime Minister's ear on this particular issue. Some claim to fame, isn't it? National Party Ministers Vaile, Anderson, Fischer and others around the table getting done over by the member for O'Connor and a bevy of urban lawyers and Liberal stockbrokers who could see the electoral fortunes of the coalition disappearing down the One Nation tunnel.

The wool stockpile freeze was no more than an act of political cowardice by an incompetent government that lost its political nerve in the face of the rise of One Nation which threatened its constituency in rural and regional Australia. It was one of the worst examples of political panic and `policy on the run' that we have seen yet from this ramshackle coalition. The simple fact is that the stockpile of around one million bales remains.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—The honourable member for Forrest certainly does not like hearing this, but it is the truth of the matter.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. This debate is to do with the legislation. The member for Corio is not addressing that issue. He is certainly way off the mark with his comments. I would ask you to bring him to the legislation.
—I call the member for Corio. I think he is talking about the issue, albeit in a way that probably gives some offence to the member for Mallee, but I think he is in order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I can understand the sensitivity of the honourable member for Mallee on this matter. I am sure that, if he was around that table, being the honourable man that he is, he would not have caved in like Ministers Vaile and Anderson did to the Liberal lawyers and the stockbrokers who ran all over them for political reasons and threw out the economic imperative in considering the future of this industry. If you cannot bear me on the floor of this House talking about the stockpile and the historical facts of the matter, then there is something wrong with the lot of you. As we debate this bill today, if the government permitted Wool International to continue the orderly sell-down of the stockpile, there would be a much smaller stockpile today to manage and the cost to wool growers of holding and storing the remainder would certainly be less.

speech.para: With regard to this legislation, the minister's second reading speech has outlined in some detail the process by which it proposes to privatise Wool International and the new commercial structure to be known as WoolStock Australia that will manage further sales once this legislation is passed by the parliament. I have already referred to wool grower concerns about the lack of consultation with industry during the process of developing the new commercial structure. That level of consultation improved considerably once the matter was raised by the opposition and other interested parties in the public arena. But there are some technical and other concerns that still remain.

Concerns have been raised about the 1.2 per cent of equity unit holders in Wool International who cannot be traced and the more substantial problem of the 25 per cent of unit holders whose equity is held in names that are not legal entities. This is a problem that will have to be faced by the new WoolStock Australia. At the Senate committee hearing evidence was given that these people certainly answered correspondence and bank cheques but so far have not responded to requests to provide correct legal names to allow their shares to be registered. I pass no further comment on the evidence that was given at that inquiry. This has had some implications for the structure of the new privatised entity with those shares to be held now under this legislation in a subsidiary trust company whose directors will be appointed by the board of WoolStock Australia, and who will be required to conduct their affairs in the interests of the beneficiaries of the trust as per normal commercial practice in these situations.

Some concerns have also been expressed by certain producers at their level of representation at the board level in the new commercialised structure. This has always been an issue which has confronted agricultural ministers of all political persuasions in attempting to marry the appropriate grower representation with commercial and marketing expertise at the board level. Indeed, I need to go no further on this matter than to reiterate the importance of appropriately balancing producer interests and commercial expertise in this matter with the confidence of growers and others in this industry.

One area of additional concern is the proposed power under this legislation of WoolStock Australia, in addition to selling down the wool pile and distributing the available proceeds to unit holders. The company has been given the power to spend $3 million, as the minister has put it in his second reading speech, to investigate and possibly support new business activities. There is a lack of clarity as to what sorts of business activities might become the subject of allocation from grower funds. One hopes that this $3 million will not end up lining the pockets of expensive consultants engaged to investigate new business activities that, at the end of the day, are not taken up by the company or are of little long-term value to Australian wool growers.

There has been little public discussion as to the type of possible new business activities WoolStock Australia might engage in in the marketplace, and care must be taken to ensure that any potential activity does not prejudice the commercial interests of growers currently holding new product on farm. This brings me to the sell-down strategy that might be pursued by WoolStock Australia and the potential for long-term harm to growers in the marketplace if this sell-down strategy is not handled correctly. This matter has not been aired or debated fully within the industry, in my view. When Labor set up Wool International to dispose of the stockpile, we set in place an orderly mechanism for the sell-down. That program was modified over time and made more flexible to take account of current market conditions and to protect the long-term interests of growers. The orderly sell-down principle introduced a measure of certainty and predictability into the wool marketplace and, over time, generated a degree of credibility and confidence in the ability of the industry and the government to manage a very difficult market situation.

The industry is aware of proposals by reputable players with strong financial backing to purchase the stockpile lock, stock, and barrel. In raising this matter, I do not wish in any way to prejudice those proposals, which have already been put on the table for consideration, as they have to be examined closely for their commercial viability and their long-term benefit to equity holders in the stockpile. However, the manner of disposal of the stockpile, should it be purchased by a single buyer, and its commercial implications for growers, needs to be thoroughly analysed and discussed at this stage of the debate.

May I conclude my remarks in this debate by restating my firm belief that this is a great rural industry with enormous potential to consolidate its position in the marketplace and, indeed, to expand its production. I am aware of the pessimism that currently pervades the industry. With flock numbers declining, low prices occurring in the marketplace, a decline in the industry's export performance and an oversupply of wool, many growers are naturally fearful for their future in the industry.

It does not help industry morale to have an incompetent government making decisions on the run that destroy the credibility of the industry in the marketplace. Nor does it help when articles appear in the daily press that quote members of the government's taskforce saying that half of the nation's 46,000 wool growers will be wiped out in five years. That report was contained in an article that appeared in the business section of the Age newspaper of 10 May 1999.

There have been many inquiries into the wool industry in recent times. One can forgive wool growers for the fair degree of cynicism that accompanied the government's decision to establish a wool industry taskforce to develop a future blueprint for the industry. It is not enough for this government to simply wash its hands of this industry with simple catchcries about putting the industry's future back into growers' hands. This is a national industry with many participants and large investments tied up in it. Its survival is important to rural and regional communities and its export success is important to the nation's global trading performance. On that basis, there is a responsibility on the part of national government to guide and assist this industry in a creative way to a greater level of prosperity than it is currently enjoying.

One does not need a bevy of reports to restate the obvious steps that must be taken for this industry to secure its future. In making that statement, let me say that there will be no simple solution, only a continuing effort by all participants in the chain to seek efficiencies, to improve productivity and to play their part in developing a secure future for this industry. One key to the commercial future of wool lies simply in the generation of greater demand for the product.

The industry is well aware of the competition it currently faces from synthetic and other fibres, and there needs to be a dramatic improvement in the industry's marketing efforts to stimulate a long-term improvement in the demand for wool. That will only come about through the development of new products and designs aimed at a much wider market than currently exists. In addition, the opening up of new geographical markets for wool will be important in sustaining demand in the longer term. It is pleasing to see that this industry is making some inroads into new markets in places like Turkey and India at a time of significant weakness in the international market in those traditional areas that we have exported to in Europe and North Asia.

It is clear that the wool industry has yet to come to terms with the need for a greater unity of purpose among wool growers themselves and among other players in the industry. I think the government does have an active role to play here in encouraging the development of an industry plan that sets out clearly where the industry wants to be in the next five-, 10-and 15-year periods and what needs to be done to secure the future of the industry over that time.

Labor governments know all about successful industry planning. In 13 years of government, we turned many industries in the manufacturing and rural sectors around from inward-looking industries to ones where we now have a very strong domestic production base and a good export performance. I refer here to the car industry, the pharmaceuticals industry and, of course, the dairy industry. These are all testament to Labor's capacity in government to get an industry into growth mode and to secure its future. That is the challenge for this minister and for this government as far as this industry is concerned.

It is also clear that the current production structure of the industry must change. Currently, it is estimated that the bottom third of farms are running fewer than 1,000 sheep and producing around 5.5 per cent of the total output of the industry. These growers produce a limited number of bales for sale in small lots, which creates additional handling costs further down the production chain. The task for government is to not only assist in the necessary changes that will see some producers stay and become more productive and more efficient, but also create a decent exit mechanism for those who choose to leave. We sincerely hope that it is not going to be at the level predicted in the newspaper article by some members of the government's task force, which stated that about half of the 46,000 wool producers in this country would go to the wall or withdraw from the industry in the next five years. It is also clear that at the moment there are far too many links in the production, distribution and marketing chain which effectively distort the price signals to producers. Rationalisation here will be painful but it will be required to improve the price and marketing signals that come directly to producers.

It is very clear that the culture of this industry will have to change for it to secure its future. I think producers are aware of what will be required of them in securing the future of the industry. Their task on farm will be to address the issue of greater productivity, to engage in the task of quality assurance, to improve their risk management procedures and to get into the greater use of information technology to improve their productivity and efficiency. The era of electronic selling of this product is certainly at hand. There are great efficiencies to be made not only through electronic selling but also in the handling task.

In conclusion, let me reiterate the point that I made earlier. The opposition does not accept the proposition that this is an industry in terminal decline. I believe that it has extraordinary potential to develop but that it is in need of radical change. There must be strong leadership from this minister and this government in securing the sort of change that is going to lead to this industry re-establishing itself in its pre-eminent place in the marketplace as one of Australia's major rural industries. The task will fall to producers in the manner that I have outlined to improve their on farm performance, and I believe they are up to the task. There are many shining examples in this industry of specialist producers who produce only wool; they do not rely on the production of other commodities. They are extremely profitable and able, through their own internal management and on farm practices, to read market signals correctly and produce their product in a way that is suitable for the next level in the chain of processing and handling.

This is an industry with exciting potential. As I said, governments must display leadership and the industry itself must come to terms with these great challenges. There will be some casualties in the wool industry over the next five years, but the task for government and industry leaders is to ensure that the productive capacity of this industry remains intact so that, when the winds of change sweep across the marketplace—when changes are made to the marketing of this product and when there is an improvement in demand—the capacity exists to meet it. The prosperity that will flow as a result of that to rural and regional communities can be secured.

I do not think this industry has really been given a fair shake from this government in the policy responses that we have seen over the last three years. The government has been elected for another three years; it may not last that long. If the GST does not get through the Senate, we might find ourselves in a situation where this government is retired earlier than expected. But it may well go its full term. I can only hope that the processes that it has set in place through this legislation and through the wool industry task force yield real fruit for this industry. The time for more reports on the wool industry in Australia is really over. It is time for the industry itself to come to terms with the real structural changes that are going to be required to propel it into a new era of prosperity. The task is there for government to provide the necessary assistance and support to this key rural industry to secure its future not only for the producers in the industry but also for those in rural and regional Australia—those communities that rely very much on this industry for their survival.

talk.start.para: —This seems a little like deja vu. I remember following the member for Corio in the debate on the Wool International Amendment Bill which was the enabling legislation—and this is the second tranche of it—in which he made some unfortunate remarks. He actually finished up much better than he started by sharing some of the aspirations that I have for the Australian wool industry.

speech.para: To make some allowance for the member for Corio, unlike me he does not have the personal contact and relationship that I have with 4,500 wool growers. In his contribution to this debate he asked what my position was back in October 1998 in respect of the future of the stockpile. I was one of the members who listened to growers at the coalface and advocated the freezing of the stockpile.
Mr Adams interjecting—

talk.start.para: —For the right reasons. I was delighted with the positive response that that had on the eastern market indicator immediately. The member for Corio made reference to a comment in the minister's second reading speech in respect of this legislation. He referred to the minister's comment that the stockpile was an Achilles heel for the industry. The point that the member for Corio seems to miss—and I would like the member for Lyons to take particular note of this—is that the stockpile itself is not the Achilles heel; it is the uncertainty of its release onto the marketplace. I hope that members of the Australian Labor Party can understand this. It has always been the uncertainty surrounding the release of the stockpile onto the market that made the market nervous.

speech.para: Prior to my entering parliament in 1993 the size of the stockpile had accumulated to 4.7 million bales. It was more than an Achilles heel; it was a sword of Damocles hanging over the market as to what would be the future of the stockpile. I am a little disappointed with the member for Corio's contribution and his condemnation of the government's leadership in respect of what has been done since 1996. He ought to check the history books to find what happened prior to that date throughout the late 1980s which allowed this huge stockpile to be accumulated in the first place. However, there is no need to repeat history. Let us focus on the positives now and the future of what is—and he at least agrees—one of Australia's icon industries and part of the backbone of rural Australia.
Mr Adams interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Lyons will get his opportunity, which I have no doubt he will take. This bill provides for the conversion of Wool International into a company operating under Corporations Law, WoolStock Australia. We have waited a long time to place that so-called Achilles heel into a commercial atmosphere so that releases from the stockpile from that point on can be based on proper commercial decisions, instead of releasing a valuable commodity at whatever price we can get. We can say, `We are sorry. This is the price at which we expect you to buy our product.' We do not need to just accept any price, which has been the difficulty over the years.

speech.para: I have brought along with me some evidence of what has occurred with the eastern market indicator and the tragedy of the wool industry going right back to the late 1980s and more particularly in the last eight or nine months since the debate about the current size of the stockpile has featured so much amongst wool growers and their representative bodies. From March 1988 until about August 1998 we suffered an absolute free fall in the eastern market indicator. The market had one million bales and was wondering whether it would be released and whether there would be change.

The government immediately showed leadership and declared its intention to freeze the stockpile and provide for what has occurred since, that is, the legislation before us today and a basis on which to commercialise the stockpile. This arrested that decline and in fact we saw some slight improvement.

Since the start of this year, and since the enabling legislation was debated in this House in November last year, there has been an improvement in that market price indicator from as low as 450c up to 550c or 560c where it currently sits. That is sufficient proof in the pudding. It has put a floor in the market for the wool industry and has given them something on which to build their future.

I repeat the remarks that I made in this chamber back in November. Here we have an industry that still has the capacity to grow, which the member for Corio thankfully agrees with, despite the cheap politics in the early part of his remarks. I expect him to unite with us and support this legislation in its entirety and support the public debate. If he wants to be the shadow spokesman on primary industries, he must learn the difficulty there always is in getting a single and sound voice from a dispersed rural electorate or any particular commodity industry because of the different commodities produced all over this diverse nation. He needs to develop the capacity to hear that.

I have listened to the people at grassroots level in my electorate—the wool growers who sent me to this place—and they applaud this legislation. They applaud the fact that, finally, after a decade of uncertainty, this stockpile will be predicted by commercial and not political decisions. The market can be more relaxed. They can cope with the uncertainties that they already have. Things were going not so badly until disaster struck Asia, particularly our valuable markets in Japan and other Asian locations. This will now put some certainty into the way in which these releases will be made from the stockpile.

I support this legislation in its entirety. I am very relieved that it is finally before the parliament. I hope that all members—not only in this place but also in the other place—will give it speedy passage to allow what needs to occur from now on to actually occur, that is, to determine a proper business plan and establish an environment in which we might be able to realise whatever commercial offer there could be to purchase the entirety of the stockpile. We need to test that. There has been plenty of discussion and suggestion, and that must be tested as soon as we can.

The minister has made some substantial announcements in respect of the various personnel who will be involved with WoolStock Australia. Mr Donald McGauchie will be chairman and he has my unqualified support. He is a person whom I know very well. He understands rural Australia and commodity issues. He is already demonstrating why the minister has selected him to be chairman of WoolStock Australia.

I will be looking forward to a comprehensive plan that establishes the future for our icon Australian wool industry. I look forward to working with my wool growers and their new wool growing and marketing associations and meeting the challenges with which they will be confronted. We have had decades of competitive fibres stealing the march on wool. We now have alternative fibres that blend wool. They have stolen the march because we have had this dreadful uncertainty with the stockpile which has hung over the marketplace and been responsible for a collapse in wool prices.

It has meant real and direct pain for my wool growing constituency of about 4,500 wool growers—and that is approximately 10,000 people or about 5,000 families. There have been repercussions to the wool industry through important provincial cities and townships in regions like the Wimmera, and certainly through the member for Wannon's region in south-west Victoria. I am delighted that the leadership shown by the government on this matter has put a floor on the price of wool. I am confident that in 12 months, if I look at a graph for the eastern market indicator for the sale of wool, I will see it increasing from its current level of 560c.

I take this opportunity to congratulate the government for a number of initiatives that they have included in this bill—particularly for exempting WoolStock Australia from income tax on its stockpile activities. I think it would be inappropriate for the government to try to take the opportunity to consolidate its revenue and to take the opportunity for the investment that exists in that stockpile. I congratulate the minister and the government for that initiative. In addition, measures will apply to exclude the application of capital gains tax to unit holdings. It is appropriate that, where growers have contributed their own money through compulsory taxation to support the stockpile, that they be given exemptions from capital gains tax. I congratulate the government for that.

In conclusion, let me go back to the comments made by the member for Corio in respect of the partisanship he is trying to engender in the debate today. He would have endeared himself much more to the wool growing constituency of Australia if he had come into the chamber and said that he fully supported this legislation and commended the government for its initiative rather than taking cheap political points about a decision that was made in respect of the stockpile—which was right and made for the right reasons. To suggest that it was because of some political opportunism of the day smacks of a complete misunderstanding of what is happening to wool growers at the coalface.

The proof is in the pudding—the proof is in the immediate impacts it has had on the price of wool. The shadow minister ought to be condemned for trying to make cheap political points. This industry badly needs bipartisan support and a united parliament to get it back on its feet so that, once again, it can be that icon industry. We often say how this nation was created by the wool that came from the sheep's back. We owe this industry because that is in fact true. I am confident that it will still enjoy, as the future will demonstrate, that status amongst our rural primary industry.
I am delighted to stand here today in support of this legislation. I urge all other members of this place and the other place to do the same.

talk.start.para: —I do not have very much time to remark on the Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 . This bill is finally tidying up the threads that the government left hanging before the last election when it instigated a freeze and then found that it had a problem. Wool International was required, under the previous legislation, to sell 90,000 to 135,000 bales per quarter, and the government got itself into a bind because it could not sell wool at that time.

speech.para: If I remember rightly, this was all brought on by One Nation making inroads into the National and Liberal Party territory before the last election—members totally panicked, ran off all over the place and made these silly decisions by freezing the wool stockpile. They wobbled all over the place and raced off to the Prime Minister. I understand the National Party minister stood his ground, but he was totally rolled. Again, the lawyers and stockbrokers of Sydney and Melbourne dictated rural policy to the National Party, and the National Party was knocked straight over and straight out of the debate. What was decided by the lawyers and stockbrokers of Melbourne and Sydney was run that day and won the day. It does not matter what the member for Mallee says, that is the position and that is what happened. The freeze was a mistake; it should never have occurred. If it had not occurred, about 300,000 to 500,000 bales of wool could have been sold and we would have continued to wind down the wool stockpile, going towards a new future in wool.

The member for Mallee did not mention the future except to say that it was going to be all rosy. He did not get into any of the issues that have to occur in the wool industry in order to make a future. Great structural changes have to occur and need to be addressed, and they are not being addressed by that side of the House in any way.

I say to the member for Mallee and to others on that side of the House: you have to start looking at the future of the wool industry and to start talking about it. I do not think that this bill has very much in it at all about the future of the wool industry; there is not much innovation in it at all. There is $3 million in it—some sort of investment direction. I think that is about giving mates a few more consultants' fees—that is all that is going to come out of that $3 million. I do not think anything constructive will come out of it. This freeze on the wool stockpile came about because the Liberal Party rolled the National Party. I see the minister in the chamber. I understand he stood his ground; it was the lawyers and the stockbrokers that knocked over—

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The member for Lyons will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Treasurer, do you recall criticising Labor's economic growth on the grounds that it was overwhelmingly based on consumption and lacked the necessary level of business investment to make it sustainable? Doesn't your budget growth forecast rely just as heavily on consumption and doesn't Treasury, in the budget papers, raise uncertainty about that consumption? If, as Treasury fears, consumption is weaker than forecast, just where is the growth going to come from?

—I am overwhelmed by the attack. The budget forecasts growth in 1999-2000 of around three per cent. Three per cent growth in 1999-2000, while down somewhat on this year, will be stronger than Europe, the United States, the OECD and G7. Consumption will be strong in the forthcoming year, and that is principally because of low interest rates. For the average Australian with the average mortgage, since this government was elected, interest rates have fallen by four per cent. That is a saving of about $320 a month, and I am sure that in the early days many people took the opportunity to reduce the term of their mortgages. But, now there is a bit more money around, obviously retail spending is strong, and that is keeping the Australian economy strong at a time of slow world growth. I think all members of the House would be pleased about that.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. What effect does the government's $5½ billion budget surplus for 1999-2000 have in assisting the economy generally and the lives of Australians individually?

—I thank the honourable member for Sturt for his question. The government is forecasting in 1999-2000 a budget surplus of the order of $5.4 billion. The $5.4 billion surplus will be used to repay Australian Commonwealth debt. In the last five Labor Party budgets, Commonwealth debt grew by $80 billion. We would have to run budget surpluses or asset sales of $80 billion to get back to where we were before the last five Labor budgets. The budget deficit in the year before this government was elected was $10.3 billion, and the then Minister for Finance is the now Leader of the Opposition.

answer.para: During the course of the 1996 election, the then finance minister, now Leader of the Opposition, claimed that the budget was in surplus; the outcome was a deficit of $10,300 million. In two budgets whilst he was finance minister, the now Leader of the Opposition produced a budget deficit of $10.3 billion and a budget deficit of $13.1 billion. In two years he cumulated budget deficits of $23 billion. In those two years when he served as finance minister, the Leader of the Opposition accumulated 25 per cent of Commonwealth debt—in two years.

The government set itself the task of bringing the budget back into balance, of producing a surplus whilst there was economic growth and of paying down Labor's debt. It is important that we do pay down Labor's debt and run a surplus budget at a time when Australia has a current account deficit of 5½ per cent or 5¼ per cent. It is important that we make sure that we run a strong budget policy to protect confidence in the Australian economy. The government will not be running down savings in the next year. We will be repaying debt, we will be building savings—and that is a strong insurance for the current account deficit.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed again to the Treasurer. Treasurer, why does your budget ditch your five per cent unemployment target, and why does it give up on lowering the unemployment rate over the next 12 months?

—The budget has forecast that in the next financial year, 1999-2000, we will consolidate the strong employment gains that have been made in the last year. In the last year in Australia, 180,000 new jobs were created—
—How many?

—180,000 new jobs were created—in the midst of an Asian recession. One of the things in Australia that you could always count on in the 1980s and 1990s was a booming Asia. What that meant was that, whatever we did to muck up our own economy—and we did a lot in the eighties and nineties—we were getting growth out of Asia for the Australian economy. That changed in the last two years. Asia went into recession. We had to do it ourselves—and we had to do it notwithstanding an Asian recession. We grew, we created jobs and we are going to consolidate those jobs. To make big new inroads into unemployment, what Australia needs is a program of substantive structural reform: a new tax system, new industrial relations and a reforming government.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order, and it goes to relevance. My question was very specific. It went to the unemployment target. And if his GST is so good, why is it not producing any fall in unemployment over the next 12 months?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. There is no point of order. Has the Treasurer completed his answer?
—Yes.

—My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of the budget's forecasts for growth? To what extent is Australia's strong economic position a product of good policy?

—I thank the honourable member for Cowper for his question. The government is forecasting in 1998-99—that is, the current financial year—growth of around 4¼ per cent. This will be one of the fastest growth rates in the developed world and certainly one of the fastest growth rates in the region. The government is forecasting that growth will slow somewhat in 1999-2000 to about three per cent. Three per cent growth will be stronger than Europe, North America, the G7 and the OECD. These strong growth rates have occurred at a time when Asia was in recession.

answer.para: When our government was elected, when the budget was $10.3 billion in deficit, when interest rates were four per cent higher than they are now, we said that we needed to strengthen the Australian economy and, if we strengthened the Australian economy, we would be able to withstand pressures from outside. It was that policy, that reform process, that was put in place three years ago which gave confidence and stability to the Australian economy now, just as it is the reforms that are put in place now that will enable us to meet the challenges of the future.

When this government was turning the $10.3 billion Beazley deficit into a surplus, we were opposed every step of the way by Labor. Labor opposed every step of the way this government's policy of putting the budget back into surplus.
Ms Hoare interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Charlton!

—Labor opposed every step of the way our measures to put the budget back into surplus. On Monday of this week, I was listening to AM and I nearly choked on my Weeties, because the Leader of the Opposition was asked what would he do in the budget on Tuesday night. He said, `Well, I would have a bigger surplus than the government.' Then the reporter said, `Well, what will their surplus be?' And he said, `I don't know, but mine would be bigger.' This was the Leader of the Opposition who fought every measure to bring the budget back into surplus. And all along he was actually in favour of surplus budgets. He was just fooling us. Now he does the same thing in relation to tax reform. He says he is so opposed to tax reform that, if he ever gets elected, he is going to keep it. He is going to fight us every single step of the way on tax reform and try to sneak into government and take the advantage of it.

answer.para: Why did the government put the budget back into surplus? To protect the economy. Why did Labor oppose it? Because Labor said if we put the budget back into surplus it would lead to an economic downturn.

talk.start.para: —That's rubbish.
—Oh, you didn't. The shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham, on cue. On 21 July 1998 he said:

answer.para: After three Costello budgets we have slower growth, and now we face the Asian economic crisis. It's not what I'd call a fireproofed economy . . . The Treasurer has fireproofed the economic car by taking out the petrol.
And listen to what he said in July 1998:
We do risk an economic crisis of major proportions, and the Asian impact will not be, as the Treasurer once stated, hardly measurable.
The economy was then growing at 4¾ per cent. The member for Hotham: WTG!

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Revenue Implications

talk.start.para: —He's gone mad.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will come to his question.
—WTG! He is into quizzes—more obfuscation of the budget.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will come to his question or resume his seat.
—My question is again to the Treasurer. Treasurer, isn't it dishonest for your budget to show the revenue implications of the GST but not the GST's inflation impact?

—The government has made entirely clear what the impact of its tax changes were. We said that it would have a 1.9 per cent effect on the CPI. As I recall, on the day before the election the Labor Party ran advertisements saying that secret Treasury documents would show that the effect was five times as great—on the day before the election. So we were expecting the Labor Party to produce some Treasury document which had a CPI impact five times 1.9—
—Mr Speaker—
—Oh, good, this will give me time to work it out.

—I raise a point of order, and it goes to relevance. If the Treasurer has said that he is still sticking to his 1.9 per cent figure, why is it not included in the budget? If you look at page 1-11 it says that the impact of prices has been excluded. What are they hiding?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

—Five times 1.9 is 9.5 per cent, and I thank the honourable member for Flinders for telling me. I know that the frontbench shadow spokesman on transport believes in truth in advertising and used to, in another guise, rail against political parties that would not practise it. The Labor Party having advertised, we would have expected a document to appear backing up the advertising, showing a 9.5 per cent CPI effect. Yet the two modellers that were commissioned by the Democrats and the Labor Party—Harding and Warren—went right through the package, and I think they said that the inflation effect would be two per cent. We said it would be 1.9 per cent. The Labor Party claimed on the eve of the election that it would be 9.5 per cent. Mr Speaker, WTG!
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My question is: why are those figures not included in the budget papers?
—The question has now been answered. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Lifetime Health Cover

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister inform the House of the benefits for the health system and the people of my electorate, next to his electorate of Casey, following the government's decision to introduce lifetime health cover?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Lifetime health cover is an important structural reform that will bring stability to the private health sector and also give some stability to the public health sector.
