It is part of a comprehensive series of reforms that include the 30 per cent rebate on private health cover, changes to reinsurance arrangements and changes to prudential arrangements that we have been undertaking over a period of two years.

answer.para: Very simply, it rewards young people with lower premiums for getting in early. It rewards all members of health funds, because premiums will be lower in the future than they would be had we done nothing by an estimated eight to 10 per cent. It will take some pressure off public hospitals by providing stability to both sectors. And it is fair and equitable in that it does not change the basic fundamentals on which community rating has always existed; that is, you cannot discriminate on the basis of age, health status and claims history. The only discrimination, in effect, is for those people who delay until later in life taking out private health insurance. We propose to start it on 1 July in the year 2000, 13 months away. That will give us plenty of time to explain the changes and will give a one-year period of grace so that all Australians will have the chance to come into private health insurance under the present arrangements. Also, anyone over 65 years of age or who was born before 1 July 1934 will effectively be grandfathered for life, and at any point in the future they can join a health fund as if they were 30 years of age.

I understand the Leader of the Opposition is concerned about what might happen to people who leave for a period of time or lose their job. This was considered, and health funds will be able to give a period of grace for two years for any person who may leave a fund to travel overseas, study or who may lose their job. Of course, funds may have discretion beyond that on an individual basis. This is an important reform, one that is long overdue. I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —My question is again directed to the Treasurer.
—Why? Why do you keep on?
—The Minister for Sport and Tourism will exercise some more restraint. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has the call.

—I refer to the fact that you have signalled again at the National Press Club today that you and the Prime Minister are willing to contemplate `finetuning' of the GST package. Will you rule out further reducing the surplus in order to bolster the GST compensation and, if not, how much of the surplus are you prepared to spend to increase GST compensation?

—This budget is a budget for 1999-2000, and the surplus of $5.4 billion is for 1999-2000. The new tax system applies from 1 July 2000 to the financial year 2000-01. If you want to know what the surplus in 2000-01 is, I suggest you come down here in May 2000 and listen to the next budget. The member made a point earlier, asking rhetorically, `If your GST is so good, why won't it create new jobs in the next year?' The GST will not be introduced in the next year. It will be introduced in 2000-01. The period 1 July 1999 to 30 June 2000 is this budget year. We are forecasting a surplus of $5.4 billion. The new tax system comes into effect in the next financial year.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. In light of the government's historic commitment to double the funding for health and medical research, could the minister inform the House of the implications of this decision for the future of research in Australia?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. I think the single most memorable thing that will come out of last night's budget is the fact of our commitment to medical research. I suspect that long in the future when people look back at this part of history the 19th century will be remembered as a century of industry, the 20th century will be remembered as a century of technology and communications and the 21st century will be a century of healing.

answer.para: What we can do now with the understanding of the human genome was unimaginable when I was in medical school 20 years ago. The discoveries over the next decade or two many people believe will cause biotechnology to be as significant to the world economy as information technology is today. There are only eight countries in the world that have any capacity to be a part of this—in North America and Western Europe; and Australia. We are on the cusp of a great future wealth for this country through biotechnology. But, unless we react quickly, we lose our capacity to be part of what is the world's next great industry.

When we came to government in 1996, the NHMRC's base funding was $110 million. Far from cutting it, we have actually tripled it over the period 1996 to 2004. The NHMRC's base funding will go from $110 million to $330 million in constant dollar terms—a tripling that is completely unprecedented in any other country anywhere in the world. The Leader of the Opposition talks about smoke and mirrors. The real smoke and mirrors were in the absolute dishonesty in Labor's budgets in their last term of government, when they pretended to be increasing the NHMRC's funding but actually made it short-term hot money that did not extend beyond the forward estimates. In 1997 and 1998, so that we could continue to keep funding medical research, I had to take money out of radiology and pathology to prop up the holes you had left by pretending that you had actually increased funding whereas you had put short-term hot money in to try and con the medical research community. They will not be conned. They know this is a genuine change. They know it is historic and it is one that will determine Australia's economic future.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Is it not a fact that Greg Smith from the federal Treasury confirmed, in testimony to the Senate GST inquiry on 8 April that, `It is likely that at some point the pensioner compensation would erode to zero'? Is it not a fact that, using the forecast of average wages provided in the budget papers, the compensation for pensioners erodes to zero within four years of the implementation of the GST? How do you justify a compensation package that has an in-built self-destruction mechanism leaving pensioners worse off after only a few years?

—There is no compensation mechanism that self-destructs. There is a compensation mechanism which, as I asserted during the election campaign—and nothing that was contained in the Senate hearings altered this fact—that the pension would always be guaranteed 1½ per cent in real terms above increases in the cost of living. It is no blinding revelation out of the Senate hearings that this government was the first government in the history of Australia to legislate that pensions would always be 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings. That was an additional measure that the Labor Party had 13 years to introduce but they never introduced it. We were the first government to legislate it—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. The Prime Minister was asked a very specific question about the erosion of the compensation. He knows very well that that 25 per cent was—
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Prime Minister is being entirely relevant and he is called.
—Four questions and they are off the budget. No wonder you are off the budget. You are the bloke who kept saying you believed in surpluses. In May of this year there should be a budget—

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister will resume his seat. The House will come to order. The Leader of the Opposition has the call.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: he was asked a specific question on the budget numbers in relation to the wage arrangements and the effect of the compensation package also in the budget.

—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition earlier raised a point of order which I ruled out of order. I will concede that the Prime Minister in his more recent reply is not directly addressing the question. I now invite him to return to the original question.

—The Leader of the Opposition asked me a question about the GST—about the tax reform package. He asked me about compensation. I repeat that what we said during the election campaign was that the compensation for pensioners would always be in real terms 1½ per cent above the CPI. That was the commitment I took to the Australian people, that was the basis on which the government was elected and that has been the underpinning of the taxation package so far as compensation is concerned.

answer.para: It is also an undeniable fact that we were the first government in the history of Australia to provide a legislative guarantee that the pension in this country would be a certain percentage of male average weekly earnings. There has never been any secret about that. There has never been any denial of the fact that you have not only the guarantee of compensation but also, running parallel to that, the guarantee that the pension would always be 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings. We have honoured our promises in full.

I take the opportunity, in the context of the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition because it relates to commitments I made in the last election campaign, to say that one of the proudest features of last night's budget was that every single promise I made on behalf of the coalition is being implemented in full in this budget. That document entitled Keeping our promises for a stronger Australia sets an absolute Australian record for speed, totality and faithfulness. A party that went to the Australian electorate with a courageous and comprehensive program not only has had the courage and the capacity to win on that program but has the integrity to honour it in full.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Can the minister outline how the budget will help improve the services avail able to people living in my electorate of Riverina and to rural and remote areas of Australia?

—I thank the honourable member for her question, knowing her very real interest in these matters—an interest shared by a lot of people on this side of the House. The government's regional Australia strategy is about understanding and addressing the needs of regional Australians. The budget reflects a coordinated, across-government approach to providing rural and regional Australia with, on the one hand, the services they need to keep their communities intact and, on the other hand, the tools they need to maximise the performance of existing industries and to enhance to the greatest degree possible their chances of attracting new economic opportunities and therefore new job opportunities.

answer.para: There is really quite an endless list of the initiatives that have been put together across the government. They are, in my view, well summarised in the statement Regional Australia: Meeting the Challenges. I commend it to the House, and I know that people will find it of very great interest. I could not hope to list everything that is in it, but particularly in the area of rural health, which is acknowledged right across rural Australia as an area of enormous concern, I would like to pay tribute to my good friend and colleague the Minister for Health and Aged Care, who has worked very, very hard in this area.

There are some initiatives here which are going to make a tremendous difference, whether it is the 30 new regional health service centres for small centres, which worked very, very well indeed; whether it is the very substantial amount of money for the retention of the best doctors and the easiest doctors you will ever get to attract to rural Australia, the ones who are already there; or whether it is the $8 million or $9 million for enabling female doctors to fly in or fly out. And there is a small one, indicating that it is often not about sheer money but about good policy: $4 million for a system of scholarships to get country kids through our medical schools, because we know that they are the kids who will go back to the bush. You had all of those years to do something about this. Every year there were fewer and fewer bush kids in our universities studying medicine—
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for the Northern Territory.
—and here there is an enormous opportunity—

answer.para: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for the Northern Territory is warned.

—without involving a huge amount of money, to simply put in place sound strategies for the future that can make a very real difference. I can go on and on in the area of health. But there is a whole range of other areas. Face-to-face services: we have committed an initial $9 million to get Rural Transaction Centres off the ground. That has been very well received. Rural apprenticeships: $51 million to meet our commitment of 30,000 new places. There is $40 million for regional assistance programs, the area consultative committees, real assistance in the area of isolated children's education, call centres in Maryborough and Port Augusta—both areas facing very real economic and social difficulties at the moment—and Work for the Dole.

answer.para: Interestingly, I reckon that before we won government in 1996 if you moved around rural Australia there were three things that always came to the fore when people asked us to act when we got into government. One was to get interest rates down; the second was to end this overvalued dollar; and the third was that people really will be better off if they do something when we support them when they have not got a job. We have delivered on all three in spades. They are the things that rural and regional Australia said that they wanted as their great priority.

I could go on. What we are doing in the area of roads has brought absolute delight to people all over this House, representing many parts of Australia. This is a coordinated, well thought through process of meeting the needs of rural and regional Australia, and it is no wonder that it has been widely welcomed.

subdebateinfo.title: Skill Shortage Initiatives Scheme: Rural and Regional Australia

talk.start.para: —My question without notice goes to the Prime Minister. It concerns keeping your word to regional Australia. Prime Minister, is it not true that at the October election the government promised $91.5 million for a regional skill shortage initiatives scheme? Given that the budget only delivered $51.4 million over five years, hasn't the Howard government, yet again, short-changed regional Australia by $40.1 million?
—Oh, Howard won't answer it.
—I call the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.
—I've got good ministers.

—It would be great for you to go out into the bush and ask who has really delivered for rural Australia—you in 13 years or us in the last 3½. What we did in the last election was promise an extra 30,000 positions in terms of assistance for rural apprenticeships. We have met that commitment. We found that, fortunately, it did not cost quite as much as we anticipated. We have fully delivered on the commitment for 30,000 places.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table an extract from a promise to regional Australia of $91.5 million for a regional skill shortage scheme—another broken promise.
—Leave is not granted. The member for Batman will resume his seat.
—Order! I call the House to order.

subdebateinfo.title: Education and Training: Standards and Skills

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. What is the government doing to lift standards, widen choice and create skills in education and training? Is the minister aware of any alternatives to the government's approach, and what are the governments responses to these alternatives?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Forrest for his question. This budget recognises that education is going to be a key to Australia's prosperity as we move into the next century. It delivers on all our commitments in the election campaign to lift standards of literacy and numeracy, to build opportunities for the 70 per cent of young people who leave school and do not go direct from school to university and to address the skill shortages, and it promotes outstanding research on which the jobs of the future will be based.

answer.para: One of the historic decisions of this budget was to put fairness back into funding for non-government schools. Governments provide some $5,000 a year for every government school student. At present the neediest students in non-government schools receive only 56 per cent of this sum. This budget lifts that to 70 per cent. This is a budget that will extend choice to low income families in Australia in a way that no previous measure has done and that gives some educational equity to these families. The government is committed to the right of all families to choose the appropriate school for their child.

Government school students are also very big winners in this budget. It is worth noting that the Commonwealth provides only 15 per cent of the funding for government schools. The principal responsibility for funding government schools falls on the states. Of course, the Commonwealth has significantly lifted moneys to the states which are available for education, and the GST will give the states enhanced revenue from government schools. But, even given this, in this budget the government has provided $131 million to raise literacy and numeracy standards, $78 million for teacher professional development, $90 million for Asian languages and, it is worth noting, $238 million above last year's forward estimates for disadvantaged indigenous students. The vast bulk of this money will flow to government schools.

In the last 24 hours, we have heard what can only be described as a statistical babble coming from the Australian Education Union and its lap-dog over there on the front bench of the Labor Party—the member for Dobell. We have heard again and again over the last 24 hours from the media this notion that somehow or another, government schools benefit by $10 per pupil. We decided to ring the Australian Education Union and ask them how they calculated that figure. We discovered that they had left out all the commitments to which I have just referred—none of those are relevant to the calculation of this figure. On the same principle, they might have left out our non-government funding, but they included that so they could provide a totally distorted picture of the impact of this government on school funding.
Mr Lee interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Dobell will resume his seat.
—The psycho-babbler—the statistical babbler—is rising to his feet now, because they do not like the truth. His only adviser is the Australian Education Union.

answer.para: Let us put the facts on the table. Next year, the year 2000, government schools in this country will be receiving 25 per cent more funding from the Commonwealth government than they received from the Labor Party in its last year of office—$382 million more than the Labor Party provided. Over the next four-year funding period for schools, government schools will receive almost $1 billion more than they are receiving in the current quadrennium of funding. So let it not be said that this government is not committed to quality education for every child. It is, and that quality doesn't just come from money. That quality comes from programs such as the literacy and numeracy programs which establish standards that every child will be assisted to reach. The literacy programs of this government are the greatest equity programs that we have seen in this country for three decades. They are lifting standards of education for every child. This government is committed to a quality education for every young Australian.
Ms Hoare interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The chair has exercised a good deal of tolerance towards the behaviour of the member for Charlton because she is a new member. That tolerance is running out.

—My question without notice is directed to the Prime Minister. Why has the government reneged on its commitment to fully compensate families punished by the Youth Allowance by offering a maximum of just $18.75 a week to families who lost up to $88 a week for a son or daughter living at home or $133.70 a week for a son or daughter living away from home? Why does your budget link this new payment to the passage of the GST? Prime Minister, how do you explain your broken promise to the Australian people, let alone to Senator Harradine?
—We have not broken our promise to the Australian people.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Can the minister inform the House what steps the government has taken in the budget to assist in the development of Australia's primary and rural industries—industries that are the backbone of my electorate of Eden-Monaro?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and recognise the work that he has done as part of the government in developing this budget. The first and most important element of this budget that absolutely delivers in spades for the rural sector is the continued sound economic management of our government. The $5.4 billion surplus underpins our strategy of a low interest rate regime in Australia, a regime that has delivered, in the life of this government so far, $580 million worth of savings to the farm sector every year in low interest rates. That is the most important thing that this budget delivers, and we aim to keep it there.

answer.para: As the Prime Minister has already indicated this afternoon, we have delivered on all our election commitments from last year, as far as this budget is concerned. We have delivered on all of them. One of the most important commitments we have made is to work in partnership with rural industries in Australia to develop a bio-tech strategy to ensure that we maintain ourselves at the leading edge of the use of this technology as we move into the 21st century. It is absolutely important that we maintain that leading edge to maintain our competitive technological edge. We have put $17.5 million towards developing and implementing that strategy.

We have bolstered, improved and expanded our Supermarket to Asia program that has been so successful over the last three years. We are going to continue and expand it with more programs such as the food and fibre chain program, which will assist Australia's food and fibre industries to build more competitive supply chains into the global export marketplace. We will continue to work in partnership, through the Supermarket to Asia program, with rural industries across Australia. We have announced new funding for the ovine johnes disease campaign to work towards the eradication of that disease in Australia.

One of the most significant announcements in this budget, as far as the rural sector is concerned, is our responsible attitude towards the management of our natural resources in Australia. I am talking about the Great Artesian Basin strategy. We are allocating $31.8 million of new money to start implementing that strategy. The Great Artesian Basin covers 22 per cent of Australia's land mass. It contains the same volume as 17,000 Sydney harbours. There are 850 uncapped bores wasting that water in the Basin. We are allocating almost $32 million over the next period of time to cap those bores and make better use of that resource.

All this is being done in conjunction and in partnership with the rural industries in Australia. Those rural industries have indicated quite clearly today that they support these government initiatives and they support the direction this government is taking in delivering on our commitments and delivering on our promises at the last election.

The National Farmers Federation has welcomed the budget outcome of an underlying surplus of $5.4 billion compared with the forecast. NFF President, Ian Donges, said the government should be congratulated on its economic management. We accept those congratulations. The President of the New South Wales Farmers Association, Mr Cobb, said today that the federal budget has addressed significant problems faced by Australia's rural industries, while maintaining the underlying low inflation and low interest rate strategy that has helped to curb the rise in farm input costs in recent years. We have the support of our rural industries. We will continue to work in partnership with those rural industries, to take our rural industries to the leading competitive edge as we move into the next century.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. Deputy Prime Minister, do you recall promising at your election campaign launch last year that you would say no to the full sale of Telstra unless a full inquiry satisfied the National Party on future service levels? Why did you allow the full sale of Telstra to be included in this budget, in breach of your commitment to regional Australia and your own party?

—The member for Perth is wrong. He should study the legislation currently before the parliament. If he had any interest in rural and regional Australia, he would get on with allowing the passage of that legislation which provides for a three-step process: 16.6 per cent, benchmarking and then a further decision. It is true that, if at the end of the process that leads to the sale of all of Telstra, it would have the desired effect on the retirement of debt. But, first and foremost, we are delivering in absolute terms for country Australia and for all Australians a budget surplus.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You do not like this, but we have actually put $8.2 million of the transaction centres commitment on the budget separate from Telstra, separate from any other factor, to get on with that task. There is more to come when you get on with the job in the Senate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment Services. Can the minister outline the meas ures contained in last night's budget that will improve employment services and those opportunities for job seekers? What indicators are available regarding the effectiveness of such measures?

—I thank the member for Wentworth for his question and for his interest in the Work for the Dole team which is helping with the hail storm clean-up in his part of Sydney. This budget is unambiguously good news for job seekers. There is an additional $220 million for employment services over the next four years. Next year, we estimate that 860,000 job seekers will be assisted, and that is 80,000 more than this year.

answer.para: The budget means more money and more places for job seekers. Within the Job Network, it is estimated that job matching places will be up from 345,000 to 400,000 and Jobsearch training places will be up from 75,000 to 90,000. It is true that intensive assistance numbers are estimated to fall slightly from 325,000 to about 300,000, but there will be more community support program places, more indigenous employment assistance and, above all, more Work for the Dole places.

Work for the Dole has been one of the outstanding successes of the Howard government. The latest figures indicate that 11 per cent of participants go on to education or training and 34 per cent have paid employment outcomes. It is better for job seekers and it is better for taxpayers than comparable Working Nation programs under the former government. Briefly, Mission Australia's press release last night stated:
We are encouraged—
Mission Australia says—

by the expansion of work for the dole. Mission Australia has had great success so far in operating more than 50 Work for the Dole programs. In Sydney alone, we have achieved almost 40 per cent success outcome rates. This is on top of Mission Australia placing almost 12,000 people into employment in the first 12 months of Job Network.

I am proud of these great organisations that are making a success of Work for the Dole and of Job Network. They deserve the support of all members of this House, including the Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, do you recall your comments about the sale of Telstra on Meet the Press last Sunday:

question.para: We're asking for 16 per cent. We're not saying at this point in time that we are going to sell more than the majority shareholding that we've got. There will still be a majority shareholding in the hands of Government.

Is it not the case that last night's budget assumes the full sale of Telstra without any independent inquiry? Why did you allow the full sale of Telstra to be included in this budget without even a note on budget risk that this would be subject to a full inquiry?

talk.start.para: —I am fascinated to get a question from the shadow minister in relation to an asset sale. He was part of a government that included the sale of Qantas in three consecutive budgets. They threw it in and nothing happened. The Left fought the Right and they just could not manipulate it through the process. Ultimately they got smart: they asked the then Leader of the Opposition, who is now the Prime Minister, to do what was right for Australia—and he always does what is right for Australia.
—Mr Speaker, I have a point of order on relevance. I am happy to read the question again for the minister if he would like me to read it again.
—The member for Melbourne will resume his seat. The minister is being relevant to the question.

—So from the party that had three goes with their budgets at bringing home the proceeds—which of course they wanted to waste—from the sale of Qantas, they ask a question about Telstra. Quite clearly, quite consistently, from the time at which we announced the policy on Telstra, the budget reflects that policy. We will sell 16.6 per cent of Telstra when the legislation is passed. That legislation gives us the right to sell 16.6 per cent of Telstra, and we seek legislation to sell the balance of Telstra when we have an independent inquiry and that independent inquiry indicates that the service levels are of a standard that is acceptable, particularly in respect of rural and regional Australia.

answer.para: So consistently our policy has been reflected in the budget. This is a transparent and accountable government, unlike the government of the past that snuck through three potential sales of Qantas to shore up those deficit budgets. Heaven forbid what the deficits would have been if they actually had to include that sale of Qantas only once back in the eighties.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can the minister outline to the House how veterans throughout Australia will benefit from government initiatives announced in the 1999-2000 budget?

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Gilmore for her question. This is a very good budget for veterans. It is a very good budget because it consolidates the gains of our first term in government which saw the extension of the gold card to Second World War veterans with qualifying service. It saw the commitment of 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings being extended to the veteran community, including our war widows. This budget also delivers on the commitments the coalition gave to the people of Australia before the last election.

answer.para: This budget will produce in the next 12 months $7.6 billion of expenditure on our veteran community, and that will grow to $8.2 billion by the year 2002-03. This budget for veterans represents a 21 per cent increase in expenditure on the last Labor budget, which I think underpins our commitment to look after our veteran community. In the next 12 months and in coming years, we will see an increase in expenditure on health. In the next 12 months, there will be an increase of $240 million, and that will grow to nearly $710 million by the year 2002-03. We are responding to the ageing veteran population, to whom we have given a commitment to ensure that their health needs will be met as they grow old.

This budget also expands the HomeFront program, which will be extended to all white card holders. That will see an extra 63,000 veterans, war widows and widowers accessing the very successful HomeFront program. We are delivering on $12.6 million of new veteran commemorative programs, including a documentary on Australians at war. There will also be new commemorative activities, including a new Anzac commemorative site at Gallipoli. The Regional War Memorials Upgrade Program has received new money as well. Because of the good economic management of the coalition, we are able to assure the veterans that their future is secure. It is secure in the hands of the National and Liberal parties in coalition in government.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Minister, is it not a fact that the budget does not allocate any funds for upgrading the Princes Freeway between Melbourne and Geelong? Is it not also a fact that in your letter to me on this matter of 27 April 1999 you stated that `its upgrading is the responsibility of the Victorian Government'? Is the Victorian government prepared to upgrade the Geelong road following the Prime Minister raising it directly with Premier Kennett? If it is no longer the view of the federal government that this is solely a state responsibility, when will you allocate the matching $118.5 million required to jointly fund this vitally needed upgrade to the Princes Freeway?
—The government has no plans to make any announcements in relation to matters that are not included in the budget for this year.
—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Can the minister outline to the House how small business will benefit from incentives in last night's budget?

—I thank the member for Wannon for his question. One of the most important things you can do for small business is keep interest rates down, keep inflation down. No-one should ever forget that, when Labor was running the economy, we had interest rates of over 20 per cent for small business, and it sent thousands of small businesses broke and gave us a record unemployment rate of 11.2 per cent. So we continue to see good economic management, which is good news for small business.

answer.para: We have also got some particular programs for small business—one of which is the Small Business Enterprise Culture Program starting in July. It is not the money that is important here; it is a means of providing assistance to small business, with management skills to make sure that small business is on top of the issues and to help them manage their business. We think mentoring, for example, is a good idea. When a retired accountant can help out an existing firm, that is good for small business, a practical measure.

We are also going to go ahead with our business entry point. The budget has got money for that. That is a great idea too, because that is part of our attack on red tape. If we can cut the level of red tape, that means business can get on with doing what they want to do—which is to run their business instead of filling out forms.

talk.start.para: —What about the GST?

—I get the interjection about the tax package. An average firm has 32 relationships in an average year with the Taxation Office. Under the tax package, which the Labor Party is opposed to, that will be reduced from about 32 to four, so that is a massive attack on red tape and definitely worth supporting.

answer.para: Lastly, we are also going on with the other reforms which are so important for small business—for example, reforms to the unfair dismissal law. Not only is this a good deal for small business but, if we can have a better system for small business, they will go out and create more jobs. On the unfair dismissal alone we think there are another 50,000 jobs that could be created. This government is unashamedly pro small business. What is good for small business is good for the country, and this budget has been a tremen dous boost again to the small businesses around Australia.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, on that very positive note I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

subdebateinfo.title: Presiding Officers Information Technology Advisory Group

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I do not want to raise the current problems members are having with Outlook but, rather, to draw your attention to the fact that you have not so far reconstituted the Presiding Officers Information Technology Advisory Group, POITAG, that you and your successors going back some years formed. Could you advise honourable members whether your intention is to do so? If so, when? If not, would you be able to outline to honourable members the reasons for such a decision?

question.para: Mr SPEAKER—I will happily respond immediately to that question. The member for Chifley first raised, I think, the difficulty some members are experiencing with email today. That seems to be something that is rather more the unfortunate coincidence of members having a large email load following the Budget coinciding with the workplace relations negotiations that are currently going on also overloading the email. I am told the matter should be cleared this afternoon. So far as POITAG, as it is known, goes, I have already taken steps to reconstitute the POITAG committee.

talk.start.para: —I raise under standing order 150 a request to you to write to the Minister for Health and Aged Care to respond to question No. 71 relating to health funding in Tasmania's public hospitals that has been on the Notice Paper since 12 November last year.
—I will take that matter up on behalf of the member for Denison.
—Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings .

speech.para: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
That the House take note of the following papers:
Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration—February 1999
Supporting Applications of Issues from the advances to the Minster for Finance and Administration during February 1999
Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

talk.start.para: — I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hotham proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The failure of the government's budget to address the real priorities of the nation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —The fourth Costello budget is a budget of missed opportunities, wrong priorities and it is not the real budget. It is not the real budget because it is based on three assumptions, any one of which could fall over. The first of those assumptions is that the GST will get through, even though no additional compensation is provided for within it. Everyone knows this GST is deficient. We have had evidence before the Senate inquiry demonstrating that there will be significant losers. The Prime Minister went to the electorate seeking a mandate for the GST on the basis that there would be not one loser. Yet there is no additional compensation in this budget for the GST. That is the first assumption which could fall over.

speech.para: The second assumption is that it is based on 100 per cent sale of Telstra. We have heard the weasel words today in the parliament, but the truth of the matter is that the Leader of the National Party, the coalition partner, had to ward off the palace revolt within his own party about the further sell-down of Telstra. He has made a commitment not just to his own party but also to regional Australia that there will not be 100 per cent sell-off of Telstra until such time as that can be justified through a full public inquiry. Yet this budget dishonestly includes the full sale of Telstra as the basis for its forward estimates. That is the second assumption that could fall over.

The third is that the growth in this budget is heavily reliant on consumption. There are two aspects of this. One is that the Treasury itself casts serious questions over this assumption of continued strong consumption. In the budget papers there is heavy qualification by the Treasury of this assumption. It says on page 2-14:

One important uncertainty surrounding the outlook for household consumption is the . . . downward trend in the household saving ratio and rising household debt. . . . consumption expenditure could be weaker than forecast.

Yet this is the basis upon which the budget projects stronger growth continuing. That is the first point—the Treasury itself not sharing the Treasurer's optimism. We heard the Treasurer today reinforce that optimism about strong growth. Also, the growth is wrongly structured, with its heavy emphasis on consumption. We do not deny that consumption—expenditure, if you like, turning the economy over—is an important contributor to growth, but consumption as the predominant driver will not sustain growth because you need investment, you need exports.

In other words, you need balance and structure in underpinning that growth. We have argued that this government has taken its eye off those important drivers of growth—the things that will really encourage stronger investment, the things that will drive our exports. But it is not just Labor that says that the structure and the emphasis on consumption is wrong to justify continuing optimism about stronger growth; the Treasurer himself has said that. I will quote what the now Treasurer said in 1994. This is criticising Labor's growth. On page of 1207 of Hansard, he said:
What we need is sustained recovery built on sound foundations . . . But, as the Treasurer himself—
that is, the Labor Treasurer—
admitted in his press conference earlier this afternoon, it is a growth—
that is, Labor's growth—
based on consumption . . . It is not growth which is soundly based on business investment, on new plant and equipment or on industry and business picking up, investing and employing.

So here you have the Treasurer criticising Labor budgets for their heavy reliance on consumption, and yet his own budget, his own confidence, is built on the same heavy reliance. The Treasurer cannot have it both ways. He cannot say Labor's growth was bad, but his growth was good. The truth of it is that Treasury itself does not share the optimism about that growth.

What we have before us is not the real budget. If the GST does not pass, if they do not sell 100 per cent of Telstra, if they do not get the consumption that they are looking for, this budget will fall over. What we have got is a phantom budget, a dishonest budget. It is dishonest for this reason: it is structured on claiming all of the revenue gains from a GST, yet none of the economic impact of the GST. Take prices for example—the point of the question that the Treasurer would not answer today. We know from Treasury evidence before the Senate inquiry that the first-year effect of the GST coming in will be to lift inflation by an additional 3.1 per cent, not 1.9 per cent.

talk.start.para: —Nonsense.

—Are you saying that Treasury is talking nonsense, my friend? Are you saying Treasury is talking nonsense? They have given this in evidence. The Treasurer will not even answer this question in this parliament. I will tell you what I would rely on: I would rely on that which is said in evidence because those people know the consequences of not telling the truth. This government has not learnt from the fact that it does not tell the truth; it continues to perpetuate the dishonesty. But this is what the budget actually says, on page 111:

speech.para: The impact on prices of the tax reform under a new tax system is not—
I emphasise `not'—
included in the projections.

Why not, Mr Deputy Speaker? They have included the revenue. They like to take the good parts to bolster the justification for their surplus and put the pressure on in the Senate. They want to grab the gains but they do not want to identify the economic impact. They have deliberately ruled out the inflation impact. Nowhere in here do we see the employment impact. Nowhere in here do we have the consequences for wages growth—which, as demonstrated in evidence before the Senate process, could increase. Nowhere is that factored into this. That is why it is a dishonest budget. But it is not just that they are claiming revenue off the GST without balancing that with the downside of the GST; they are also claiming the revenue from the full sale of Telstra, even though they told us in the House today they are only going to sell 16 per cent. How can you believe this document? This document is a joke. It is not the real budget. It is a dishonest budget. The truth of the matter is that the GST is bad for the economy.

I will tell you why those figures are not in the budget. It is because Treasury disagrees with the political rhetoric that this government has been running. The Treasurer has been out trumpeting this great GST, saying, `It'll be good for jobs, good for growth, good for this. It's snake oil—it'll fix everything.' Yet not one piece of evidence has been produced by this government to justify those claims. To the contrary: we have produced evidence in the Senate that refutes those claims, that says it is bad for the economy. It is not just unfair to pensioners and those people on low incomes; it is actually bad for the economy. It destroys jobs. It is a new tax.

The government waxes lyrical at times about how good it would be for the states to abolish payroll tax because it is a tax on employment. They are introducing a new goods and services tax, a value added tax, on the biggest growth employment sector in the economy—the services sector. Labour is the value added in the services sector. The goods and services tax is a massive tax on employment. If you do not believe that, look at what the European Commission has now recom mended to its member states. It has recommended that they experiment with reducing the goods and services tax as a means of generating employment, particularly in the services sector. In other words, they believe that the GST is harmful to employment in the services sector—the very point that we have been making. Also, interestingly enough, they say that it has created a huge new black economy in the services sector, something that this government has argued would be corrected.

The other thing about this budget is that it breaches election commitments. We saw that unctuous Prime Minister get up and say again, hand on heart, `The greatest thing, the proudest moment, I had last night was knowing that we had honoured every election promise.' As soon as he was asked by the member for Batman to justify why he had ditched one, he would not answer the question.

talk.start.para: —He would not have the courage.

—He does not have the courage because he has not got the answer. This bloke is a fraud and this budget is a fraud on the Australian people. He went to the last election and said there would be no losers. We have identified the losers and he has done nothing to compensate them—one broken promise to start with. He and the Leader of the National Party of Australia said they would not sell the whole of Telstra, yet this budget says they will—another broken promise. And this was the grandmother of them all today: he told the Australian public, in response to Senator Harradine, that there would be full compensation for the youth allowance and yet the budget does not even half-compensate it. When he was asked the question, he was whispered in the ear by the Treasurer—who by the way set him up again—to say, `We have honoured our commitment to the Australian public.' He did not say that he had honoured his commitment to Senator Harradine. Where does this Prime Minister get off? Isn't a promise given in good faith to whomever something that must be honoured? This Prime Minister does not believe so. So there are huge broken promises in this budget and the Prime Minister's unction just confirms the fact that no-one can believe him when he says he gives his word.

speech.para: The other interesting thing—and I think this is important because it is a real embarrassment for this government—is that the budget, for all the hoopla that surrounds it, demonstrates you do not need a GST to secure the revenue base. That is what it shows. The contribution to the revenue base will increase by $5.1 billion this year and $9.5 billion over the coming year. In fact, this year the total revenue to GDP is the highest it has been in 10 years and next year it will go higher again, I think, to probably the highest in recent recorded history. This from a system that is supposed to be broke? Give us a break!

The truth of the matter is the system is not broke. One of the great lies that you have perpetrated is that we need tax reform because the current system is not up to it. This budget confirms it is up to it. The truth of the matter is—and this is the point that the Leader of the Opposition has made—the Treasurer still stupidly does not understand that if you did not have your GST you would end up with a bigger surplus. That is the truth, and the reason is that to buy your GST you have dip into the surplus to the tune of $5 billion to $7½ billion just for the tax cuts—forget the states and forget the additional compensation—in your ANTS package.

Do you know where the great bulk of those tax cuts go? To the top 20 per cent of income earners, the high rollers in this nation. This is a budget that wants to slug pensioners and low income earners with a new, insidious tax that is going to destroy jobs, yet it is going to give the great tax breaks to the high rollers and the casino owners in this country. This is a government with priorities so skewed it does not deserve to occupy the benches opposite. We will be doing whatever we can to ensure this GST is defeated, and when it is we will see the real budget. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —While I am delighted to participate in this debate, I spent 15 minutes trying to see what the substance of the matter of public importance was by listening intently to the spokesman on the economy from the opposition and I have to say I am none the wiser. He puts forward a matter of public importance that says we should debate:

speech.para: The failure of the government's budget to address the real priorities of the nation.

In the 15 minutes from the matter of public importance being brought on I went to the transcript that I got from his interview on the Ray Fewings program on 5DN Adelaide this morning. If you read that transcript, you just simply shake your head and say, `My God, what chance has the opposition got of having any coherent economic policy at any time in the future whilst ever the member for Hotham is their spokesman,' because in that interview he says such things as, `You've got to look below the surface in terms of the surplus; they have not delivered on their promise.' That is the statement this morning. We have not delivered on our promise for a surplus? What seems to be more of concern to the member for Hotham and the Labor Party at the present time is that we actually have achieved a surplus. In fact, they seem to have had this modern day conversion that supports surpluses. Later in the interview he says to Matt Peacock of the ABC, `Let's secure a higher surplus.'

Today, of course, the Treasurer has made it abundantly clear that the party in opposition that believes in surpluses had absolutely no belief in them when they had hold of the purse strings on the treasury bench. They did not know the meaning of surpluses and in their last five budgets they added to general government debt to the tune of $70 billion, to the extent that we as a government have had to pay month after month to the bank the interest on that debt through those deficits which Labor ran up. Yet the member for Hotham and the Labor Party now talk about the virtues of surpluses and say such things, as the member for Hotham did this morning, as, `Let's secure a higher surplus.'

This matter of public importance relates to the budget. Yet for 11 of the 15 minutes all we heard from the member for Hotham was about the tax package, which he referred to as the GST—he said it was deficient—then he went on to talk about the sell-off of Telstra and then, of course, he tried to give some figures on how we will not get our growth because it is too reliant on consumption. The GST, and the component of that tax package that represents the GST, was announced long before the last election. The figuring on that came in the Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook. That was tabled in this parliament after its release in December last year. It is on the record.

It flows throughout the budget papers on this occasion, as it should, because it does have an impact—not in the next year, as again we have had to point out to the opposition today, but commencing on 1 July 2000. It is not relevant to the budget that was delivered by the Treasurer last night other than to the extent of the projections in the forward estimates, which every budget contains. Those opposite say, `The only reason that you are able to get a GST in place is that you are taking the revenue, but we don't need a GST for the revenue.'

We agree with that. We as a government have recognised that all Australians are paying too much direct tax. What we want to do through a new tax package, as has been announced and as has received the support of the Australian people, is to give some of that tax back to Australian taxpayers. We want to give $13 billion a year in tax cuts. We do not want more revenue; we want to give it back to the Australian people. Not only do we want to give $13 billion—we do not want that revenue—but also we are prepared to add to that to the tune of another $2½ billion per year in additional benefits for families. In those areas where there is the need, that new tax system will provide a total of $15½ billion a year in benefits to the Australian people.

Yet we have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ranting and raving in here today about the only way in which we will get growth is if it is based on consumption. He then proceeds to say that we have a softening on consumption and that all of the revenue and growth is driven by domestic consumption. I would suggest to every member of the House that when we forecast, as the budget papers do, the growth in domestic consumption of 3.75 per cent, that is extremely robust. It is down slightly from the 4.5 per cent that is estimated to be the growth in domestic consumption for the 1998-99 year but it is still very healthy.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition suggests that we will not have the capacity for further healthy domestic consumption, but I would simply point out to him that, from 1 July 2000, we as the government want to top up the extra $320 per month off disposable income in the pockets of families—the benefits that the lower interest rates delivered under this government have meant to the mortgage payments of those average families—and at the discretion of those families by giving significant tax cuts to those average families. This will give them more flexibility and more discretion to use the funds that they receive with the income and the pay packet that comes in each week. That is what the new tax system delivers.

But it seems to me that the best that Labor can do within the early hours of this particular budget being brought down is, firstly, to ignore the budget and, secondly, to go back to some of those other issues—such as the new tax system which has been done to death. We have had more inquiries and investigations carried out by the Senate than the average state homicide squad over the past few months. None of those inquiries have brought about any conclusion that supports the rhetoric we constantly hear from Labor to suggest that there is not sufficient compensation in the package or that there are losers.

What Labor should do is take some advice on those issues—they are not relevant to the budget but, clearly, Labor do not want to talk about the budget—from some of their own. They should take some advice from Mr Hogg, their former Secretary; they should take some advice from the guru of campaigning in New South Wales, Mr Della Bosca, who was seen to be a dud when it came to the federal election six or seven months ago but who is now a genius when it came to the state election—because they have made it very clear that it is about time Labor got on with it.

The best thing Labor can do—if it is interested in growth, if it is interested in jobs and if it is interested in complimenting the very good work that this government has done for the economy—is to start looking to the future and forgetting about the past. They should support those provisions that are before the Senate at the present time in respect of tax and allow this country to grow at an even greater rate than it has in the past, because that is the opportunity that is there. That opportunity was enhanced by last night's budget.

The opposition's suggestion that this government wants to take the benefits of the revenue from the GST once again shows its complete ignorance of what the legislation is about, because we do not want that money. We do not want any of the revenue from the GST. The legislation gives all of that revenue to the states. All of the states' premiers and the territories' chief ministers think that it is absolutely fantastic.

When they came down here six or seven weeks ago, I think I heard that Treasurer in New South Wales say on that occasion that the current Prime Minister of Australia has been the best Prime Minister that Australia has had since Ben Chifley.

talk.start.para: —Who said this?

—That came from one Michael Egan, the Treasurer of New South Wales, as a result of this package of tax reform that this government is implementing—if we can get the support of the Senate—because Mr Egan knows that all of the revenue of the goods and services tax goes to the states. Mr Egan knows that, for the very first time in this process of Commonwealth and state relations, the states have a growth tax built in. Instead of coming down cap in hand year after year—and God knows I did it for a while—asking and hoping that there is some benevolence in the Prime Minister of the day so that you can go back and start doing some proper plans for your hospitals, your schools and your roads, they are guaranteed all of the goods and services tax. That goods and services tax means that, with the increase over the years, there is growth built in. The states can then make some definite plans for the future to provide those needs that state governments are responsible for.

speech.para: We have seen the focus in this debate this afternoon not on the budget—even though that is what the matter of public importance is about—not on the benefits that are in the budget, and there are significant benefits in there, but on the so-called deficiency of the GST that Labor state premiers think is fantastic and on the other issues which relate to legislation before the Senate; namely, the sell-off of Telstra.

Labor say, `The budget is only good if Telstra is sold.' Let me say this: we are not going to spend the money we are getting from the sale of Telstra. Not like Labor who, in the early 1990s, actually threw in the benefits of the Qantas sale in three budgets. They indicated budget after budget after budget that there was some money coming from the sale of Qantas. We know those figures go into the contingency reserve and they cannot be identified; they are mixed up a little for commercial-in-confidence reasons—quite legitimate. But Labor tried it three times.

Each time, having built those figures into that budget bottom line, Labor said, `We're going to bring in a responsible and prudent budget.' We know what happened in those days when those opposite were going about the sale of Qantas: they brought in five successive deficit budgets. Heaven forbid what the true story might have been if they had not kept putting figures from the sale of Telstra in and trying to hide them and putting figures from the sale of Qantas in and trying to hide them.

We know that those opposite did not believe in using the proceeds of an asset sale to retire debt; they used it for current programs and ran up that debt I spoke of a little earlier—$70 billion. We were paying $9½ billion in interest on that $70 billion instead of providing $9½ billion to those in the welfare sector, those needing some requirements in health. I would like to give that money to health, to education, to welfare—the true priorities, the real priorities of the nation, the priorities that have been ignored in the contribution to this debate by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He is not interested in the budget. He would hope, as would all members of the Labor Party, that the great benefits that will flow, the consolidation that will continue, the fiscal responsibility that will continue for the fourth successive year will be forgotten very quickly. Well, it will not. I say that because this morning I addressed 700 people at a breakfast held in the Sydney Town Hall on whom a survey was undertaken. The people were surveyed on how they had reacted to the delivery of the government's budget last night. From the survey passed around the breakfast table, the results of which were collated later, it was found that this government's budget had been endorsed with overwhelming support. And why wouldn't it be?

This is the government that in four consecutive years has not borrowed one net dollar; not one net dollar has it borrowed in four years of managing the national accounts. What we have done in those four years—and this is reflected in this year's budget—is paid off some $24 billion of Labor's debt. As the Treasurer said last night, not only have we addressed debt and, through that process of addressing debt, ensured that those factors, that very good set of conditions all Australians benefit from—low interest rates, low inflation, high growth—continues but we want to go further and get rid of the rest of Labor's debt.

I must say that it is a bit galling to spend years working—although I do enjoy the capacity in which I work very, very much—simply to get rid of the waste and mismanagement of your predecessor. That has been to the forefront of all I have had to do in the context of my portfolio for the past several years. Notwithstanding that, we will accept it for the Australian people; we will pay it off. As the Treasurer said, if we get the opportunity to sell all of Telstra, and we want to do it, we will pay off the residue of Labor's debt by 2002-03. As a nation, Australia then can enter the 21st century in exactly the same fashion as we entered the 20th century—with no debt.

We are not interested in spending and squandering—as did those opposite with their asset sales—when we sell Telstra. We are interested in clearing their debt. That is good for the Australian people, and it is good for the growth that we are experiencing and that we will experience in the future. With the exception of the reference to domestic consumption as being `a little flat'—still robust, I have to say, but a little flat—no other reference has been made about growth. We have good growth in this nation, and it will continue while we are in government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This budget is living proof of what Labor repeatedly said during the election campaign, and that is that the government does not have a plan for the nation; it has a plan for a tax. Australians are crying out for a plan to reduce unemployment permanently, but in the budget unemployment is stuck at 7½ per cent. I wonder whether the Prime Minister recalls on 18 February this year in this chamber making the comment:

speech.para: In terms of an individual policy, our top priority is to reduce unemployment.

I wonder whether the Prime Minister can explain why the budget forecast has no reduction in unemployment below 7½ per cent; indeed, why the budget contains no mention of the five per cent unemployment target; why unemployment got a mere five paragraphs on page 8 of the Treasurer's budget speech; and why the government has allocated more in the 1999-2000 financial year for Taxation Office computers to implement the GST than for job creation programs to get unemployed people back to work.

Fleetingly in February of this year, we had bipartisan support for Labor's unemployment target of five per cent—if only because the Treasurer did not want his leadership rival, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, to steal the march on him. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 February 1999 that begins:
The Treasurer, Mr Costello, has held out the prospect of Australia slashing unemployment to near the United States "full employment" level of 4 to 5 per cent.
It goes on to state:
Mr Costello said the GST would boost employment, giving a fiscal stimulus, reducing income tax rates and producing a better balanced tax system which would lead to higher economic growth.
Then on 2 February, the West Australian reports:
Treasurer Peter Costello said the Federal Government could cut unemployment from 7.5 per cent to less than 5 per cent, but only if the Senate agreed to introduce a goods and services tax.

The budget does contain a goods and services tax, but we have been unable to find any reference anywhere in the budget to the five per cent target. In fact, Treasury expects employment growth over the next three years to slow down and it foresees no improvement in the unemployment rate. This means that the benefits of economic growth are not being shared fairly. I would point out that, compared with Labor over an equivalent period, this government has created less than half as many full-time jobs and only two-thirds as many part-time jobs as Labor. Long-term unemployment has increased to 212,000 since the government began to slash Labor's job programs three years ago.

Where are the jobs in this budget that the Treasurer said would be created by the GST? There are none. Professor Dixon of Monash University in reporting to the Senate GST inquiry described the GST as `job destroying'. Even Mr Murphy, the Prime Minister's preferred modeller, could find no jobs from the GST. For the unemployed and regional Australia, this budget is a budget of despair. It is not a plan for a nation, it is not a plan for jobs; it is a plan for a tax. It is a consumption tax that will affect consumer spending. I point out in the budget documents that very point:
There is also likely to be some net increase in household consumption in the latter part of 1999-2000 ahead of the introduction of the A New Tax System package.
So the GST will affect consumption. But, interestingly, the budget says that the GST will not affect prices. We are assuming that away. On page 1-11 it states:

The impact on prices of the tax reforms under A New Tax System is not included in the projections. However, this impact has been taken into account separately in projecting the revenues and expenses affected by the tax reforms.

So they are going to take the revenues but we are assuming away any impact at all on prices. So they get an inflation figure of 2½ per cent in the year 2000-01. The reality is that Treasury has revealed that the inflationary impact of the GST alone in that year will be at least 3.1 per cent, and it could be more than four per cent if all the indirect tax reductions are not passed through immediately. We know that will be the case. So what we are really looking at is price rises in that year of around 6½ per cent. The government is saying in these documents that it is 2½ per cent.

I would have loved to have been in the cabinet room when this was being discussed. I can see what would have happened. The government would have said, `If we put the true price effect of the cost of living increases from the GST in this budget document, we'll get killed.' Treasury would have said, `Well, you're the ones who put 1.9 per cent out during the election campaign, which is a dodgy figure. You would have to put in 3.1 per cent at least.' The government would have said, `We can't do that, so we'll just assume it away.' In question time today the Treasurer was asked by the shadow Treasurer:
Will you rule out further reducing the surplus in order to bolster the GST compensation and, if not, how much of the surplus are you prepared to spend to increase GST compensation?

It is a pretty straightforward question. The Treasurer replied that we only have one surplus; that is the surplus for the coming year. We only have one surplus in the budget. That's all we've got. I draw your attention again to page 1-3, which projects the surplus figures over three years. I can see what has happened here. The Treasurer has carried the lawyer's brief into the parliament. He has said, `Look, I am not very good at numbers, so just give me one number. What is the surplus this year?' His staff would have given him the number. When the shadow Treasurer asked him about the impact on the surplus in the coming years beyond the first year, he said, `No, we don't have those figures in the budget.' They do have the figures in the budget, but obviously the Treasurer cannot recall those figures. We need to know how much GST compensation is going to be taken off those surplus figures which the Treasurer is saying do not exist in the budget. Clearly they do.

With unemployment stuck at 7½ per cent in this budget, it is timely to remind ourselves of what the five economists have been saying: that is, by economic growth alone we will not get unemployment below 7½ per cent—much or anything below 7½ per cent. What is needed is a comprehensive jobs plan. Labor is advocating a comprehensive jobs plan. It is a plan that involves tax reform without a GST. It involves tax credits. It involves improving the incentives to move from welfare to work. It is a plan that includes active labour market programs. It is a plan most fundamentally that invests in people and ideas.

We can build on a jobs plan on these ideas by investing in the talent of Australia and investing in ideas, by investing in education and in Australia's research and development effort. The Treasurer said on radio today, `Look, you won't get unemployment down if you do nothing.' Well, in the budget unemployment is stuck at 7½ per cent. It is obviously a do-nothing budget. All it does is impose a $32 billion new tax and sell Telstra. It is not a debt reduction strategy; it is a sell Telstra strategy.

We point out that there is a $40 billion undervaluation of Telstra in this budget because of a convenient accounting standard that they are citing—a $40 billion undervaluation that is designed to make the sale of Telstra look attractive. But the sale of Telstra is not attractive. It is clearly better to hold on to Telstra to get the dividends from Telstra and to get the growth in the value of Telstra for the Australian public. It does not make sense to sell Telstra, and they have had to manipulate the figures to try to create a case for selling it.

Again, I would be very interested in the cabinet discussion where the Deputy Prime Minister would have said, `Look, if we are putting all these figures in the budget about the full sale of Telstra, what about my inquiry?' They would have said, `So much for your inquiry. That one is biting the dust.' Obviously he got rolled.
This is a budget that is built almost totally on consumer spending. It is built on the Bankcard. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I could not resist a double-take when I read the opposition's so-called matter of public importance. It seemed to be such a point of breathtaking hypocrisy for the opposition led by its former Minister for Finance that it was hard to believe the opposition was suggesting that the government's budget had failed to address the real priorities of this nation. I have been in this House for nearly six months now, and I have yet to hear what the opposition considers to be a priority, any priority, let alone a national priority.

speech.para: But then I appreciated what a golden opportunity I had to pay tribute today to the Howard government, to pay tribute to the Treasurer for his outstanding effort in producing a budget that is reassuring to all Australians in its commitment to sound economic management, that delivers on election promises and that is positively inspirational in its vision for the Australia of the future, with its commitment to education, science and medical research, health, small business and the like.

By any measure, pitted against any key performance indicators, this is an outstanding budget designed to be a true investment in Australia's future. This government's repair of the budget and policy measures have enabled Australia to be one of the fastest growing economies in the world despite the Asian crisis. The opposition talks of national priorities. A priority for the federal government is to manage the economy in good times and bad, responsibly and fairly for the ultimate benefit of all Australians, and we have done that. No less than the Sydney Morning Herald editorial labelled it `Responsible and fair'. `A triumph of a determined focus on economic policy,' it said. `A striking testament to the focus policies of governments taking rational economic decisions.'

What does the opposition know of sound economic management? The Leader of the Opposition professes to be an advocate of budget surpluses, yet he is seemingly incapable of giving any credit to this govern ment's ability to deliver a budget surplus for the third successive year—not just talk about it. The opposition steadfastly ignores the fact that, when we came to office three years ago, we found we had inherited a $10 billion underlying cash deficit.

Members might recall the pattern of deceit over the true status of the Labor deficit, a deceit that became a hallmark of Labor's economic management. They boasted of budget surpluses. Members will recall that at budget time in May 1995 Labor trumpeted that they had brought down a budget surplus. After all, the Leader of the Opposition was the then finance minister, and he says he believes in budget surpluses. But at the mid-year review in December 1995 it was revealed that perhaps it was not such a budget surplus. `Perhaps we will downgrade it a little,' he said.

When this government came to office all was revealed. The 1995 budget was in fact in deficit, had always been in deficit—not just a little—for we inherited a $10 billion deficit. Under Labor the underlying deficit blew out beyond all proportions, notwithstanding public statements by the then finance minister, now Leader of the Opposition, that, `We're operating in surplus and our projections are for surpluses in the future.' Wrong. We were not operating in surplus; we were in deficit. In 1991-92 there was an $11.5 billion deficit; in 1993-94, a $17 billion deficit; in 1994-95, a $13 billion deficit; and in 1995-96, a $10 billion deficit. Members will recall Labor's refusal to release updated budget data during the 1996 election campaign. We all know why: because that data was a damning indictment of Labor's fiscal and monetary policies.

The last term of the Labor government failed the Australian people in ways none had done before. At a time when Australia's fortunes could have been on the rise, when it had everything going for it in terms of the global and regional economic environment, when the economic stars were all in place, Labor failed the people of Australia. We had a $10 billion underlying cash deficit, a serious erosion of Australia's savings, and a huge foreign debt. And don't forget that under Labor over a million people were unem ployed, with the unemployment rate peaking at 11.2 per cent. Deficit and debt—that is how Labor treated the Australian economy. Deficit and debt and deception—a novel three dimensional approach.

I recall an article in the Economist in late 1995 headed `Australia: Lucky or Broke?' as it proceeded to damn Labor's record with the prediction that they were sending the country broke, comparing the downward spiral Labor put us into as akin to the worst times in the Mexican economy. I am not aware of an economic theory or policy that suggests sending a country broke or bankrupt should be a national priority.

The priority this government gave to our economy, to our fiscal position, was to focus on the deficit and to work to implement the necessary changes to bring the budget into surplus. We focused on underlying surpluses, for it is this surplus, before asset sales and loan repayments by the states, that builds our savings, builds our economy and provides an investment in our future.

Labor can make all the hollow promises that it likes, that it would have delivered a bigger surplus, but when it had the chance to deliver it failed to do so. We had our priorities right. In just two years we turned that $10 billion deficit into a $1¼ billion underlying cash surplus. And now, by maintaining a consistently disciplined approach to financial management, the surplus is predicted to grow in both cash and accrual terms to more than $5 billion in 1999-2000. With the budget in surplus the government is saving enough to finance all its investment needs. Indeed, we are actually adding to the pool of savings available to finance private investment. This means more projects, creating more jobs and greater opportunities for Australia, and it can be financed with our own savings instead of foreign debt. Is that not a priority?

We have been reducing the massive debt run up by the Labor Party during its profligate days. You would be forgiven for thinking that Labor was running the economy on a perpetual Visa card—run up the debt and the interest and hope it becomes someone else's problem when the time comes to pay it off. That is what this budget and previous Costello budgets have delivered.

In the last five years before the coalition was elected, Labor ran up Commonwealth debt by nearly $80 billion. We had to find $9 billion just to pay the interest bill. Reducing government debt was and is a national priority. Since 1996 the government has reduced the Commonwealth's net debt by around $24 billion. In 1999-2000 we expect to reduce debt by a further $20.5 billion. That is the largest ever reduction in Commonwealth net debt in a single year. In 1995-96 the Commonwealth general net debt was equal to 19 per cent of GDP. In 1999-2000 that is expected to fall to just 8.2 per cent of GDP. That is a $44¾ billion reduction in net debt in just four years. We have the lowest interest rates in nearly three decades underscoring continued strong growth in spending and an all time low in maintaining low inflation. Since early 1996 inflation has averaged two per cent, compared with five per cent over the previous decade.
