The other possibility is that we are not moving in a free market system here, that we are moving in an oligopolistic market system, and maybe you need intervention in the marketplace to get a fair go. Or maybe collectively selling your product is a hell of a lot better than 50,000 of us individually selling a $6,000 million a year commodity, as it was at the time.

An argument put up is that there was a hole in the buy-in policy because there were no controls on production—and it was not possible, I would have thought, to get legislation through the House, even in those days, for controls on production, and most certainly getting agreement from the industry would have been impossible—so there was a tendency to overproduce and when the minimum price scheme was kept fairly moderate it did not stimulate overproduction. That is the argument. But on the production levels in the late 1960s, we overstimulated by one hell of a lot because we almost doubled our production of wool when the price went up 300 per cent. You can say, `Why weren't the world markets swamped, and why didn't the price collapse?' I will tell you why: because we advertised.

For those of you who like reading important books, I strongly recommend—the author was reviewed in Time magazine as being by one of the most important men of the century, John Kenneth Galbraith; whilst he was not noted as one of the top 100, he most certainly got mentioned as one of the also-rans—The Affluent Society. He puts forward the proposition—and you cannot read this book without accepting the proposition—that you can affect supply by advertising. There is about a $3,000 million a year industry out there at present in Australia that says, `Yes, you can influence the demand for a product with advertising.' Of course, Doug Anthony also put in the advertising element as well.

When I buried my father I gave a speech at the funeral. One has to give a lot of thought to what are the really important things to say. At that funeral I said, `Really, the most important thing that ever happened to us west of the Great Dividing Range, in inland Australia, was the introduction of the statutory marketing arrangements in the wool industry.' For the first time in my family's lifetime, in 110 or 120 years in Australia, we saw really solid incomes, the sorts of incomes that meant we could reinvest our money with some degree of confidence in inland Australia—that was for the first time ever.

We look across the range to the sugar industry, where they enjoy an income of $89,000 per farmer per year. They have had some terrible times, believe me—they are probably going through one now—but their average income has been $89,000 for the last seven or eight years. And our average income in the wool industry is $13,000 or minus $2,300, depending on which set of figures you want to look at. I read in one recent report that in Queensland we are averaging a suicide every two months in the wool growing areas. Most certainly I know a number of people involved in the industry who have taken that terrible option.

For 18 wonderful years, we enjoyed a safe and secure income. Our little towns showed the first modicum of prosperity probably in 60 or 70 years since the Second World War. Then the terrible times occurred. A government and a Treasurer were elected in Australia that believed in this wonderful free market system. I think every intelligent person believes in the free market system. But I think also that every intelligent person realises that certain markets are oligopolistic markets that are controlled by very few buyers and that you are not normally dealing with a free market system. Where you have, as you do have in the wool industry, a market that is dominated by five or six players, and where you have in Australia some 30,000 or 40,000 sellers, then you clearly have an oligopolistic marketplace. Evidence of that fact is that when the minimum price scheme was introduced the price went up 300 per cent over the next two years and when it was removed the price went down 300 per cent. I always enjoy getting into arguments when you produce that simple fact, which everyone is well aware of. Really, there is no argument that one can sustain against that very simple fact.

Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, you yourself did a very wonderful job, in my opinion, of chairing the wool subcommittee of the coalition. You called the 17 members together on the issue of the price freeze which was criticised by the last speaker. I think there were 17 of us on the telephone hook-up that day. All 17 voted—some not—with enthusiasm maybe but most certainly with great aggression for the freezing of that stockpile. One of my great bitches—in fact, I made a very unrestrained attack upon the leadership of my own party at the time over this most important issue; that was the main burr under my saddle at the time—was the failure to freeze the stockpile. Itoh is the biggest buyer of wool, arguably, in the world. Their buyer in Australia said, `If you do not freeze the price, it is going to go down 20 per cent.' If your buyers are saying to you that you should freeze the stockpile, then I think you should really seriously look at freezing the stockpile. I thought that if we froze the stockpile the price would still go down significantly and people would say, `See, it is your fault because you froze the stockpile.' But I was absolutely confident that it would not go down anywhere near as badly if you took 15 per cent—arguably, maybe 20 per cent—of the world's supply of wool off the world's market.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as chairman of that committee, you would be well aware that that is what we did. We froze the stockpile and— miracle of miracles as far as I was concerned—not only did the price not go down but it actually went up four or five per cent. I deeply regret that one of our ministers made remarks—which I hope he now regrets—that undermined the confidence in the marketplace. Then the head of Wool International made a second statement which said that it was not fully legal and undermined the confidence in the marketplace again. And then the spokesman for the wool industry councils throughout Australia made a third remark which pulled the price down again. So I hope each of the people making those remarks deeply regrets what they did to the confidence of the industry.

Let me come back to what actually happened with the collapse of the price. There was overproduction because the price had gone very high—it went to 1,200c at one stage there—and there was pressure upon the buying group at the time to put the minimum price up to 1,000c. In fact, the New South Wales farmers demanded, at one of their conferences, that it go to 1,000c. They fought off that temptation, but they had to yield a bit, so they went to 870c a kilo. Mr Kerin and Mr Keating had three infamous press conferences. At each of those press conferences—and I watched all three of them—they clearly indicated to the world market that the Australian government would no longer stand behind the price for wool. Mr Keating was very ideologically driven. The member for Petrie suffered his violence. So also did Senator Button, who was a very great loss to this place. But by making those statements they undermined the confidence in the marketplace. You have to understand that what happened here, Mr Deputy Speaker, was like a service station owner putting up a big sign saying that petrol was going to be 30 per cent a litre cheaper next week. So everybody stopped buying petrol, because they were going to fill the tank the next week when it would have been 30 per cent cheaper. That is exactly what the world wool buyers did. They said, `These blokes are not going to stand behind the minimum price scheme. Clearly the Australian government thinks the price is going to go down. We had better stop buying here.' So, of course, they stopped buying, and the price went through the floor because the confidence in the marketplace had been broken by Mr Kerin and by Mr Keating. They were the people who were responsible.

Before those infamous press conferences, the price of wool was 890c a kilo and the minimum price was 870c a kilo. We had about a 20 per cent buy-in, if my memory serves me correctly. Whilst 20 or 30 per cent, whatever it was, was a high buy-in level, there was nothing dramatically wrong with the system. But after those infamous press conferences, of course, there was a hell of a lot wrong. The buyers just withdrew en masse from the marketplace. Then Mr Keating used his own destruction of the confidence in the marketplace as an argument—which he intended all the time of course—to dismantle the minimum pricing arrangements because of his profound, blind, ideologically driven belief that everything had to be determined by the marketplace. Someone should have explained to Mr Keating about oligopolism and the influence on the marketplace of a few buyers meeting so many sellers.

This brings me to the final point I want to make. The United Graziers Association has been a very conservative body that really always tends to favour a free trade position. John Hamilton from Nelia in North Queensland said to them, `Mr McGauchie, I am not interested in this buying group providing shares and great share value. I am not interested in share value. I am interested in the value of the price of the wool. I am not a share trader. I am a wool producer.' Almost every single one on that council backed Hamilton very strongly. I would hope that the minister and Mr McGauchie take into consideration that there is a group out there—as Mr McGauchie, strangely enough, said in his own speech that day—who prefer to sell into the spikes rather than into the troughs. If they perform in the marketplace, they most certainly can affect it and they can move back towards the sort of situation which kept us a very happy industry and in prosperity we had never dreamed of for nearly two decades in the bush. I would plead with everyone who is a decision maker involved in this to look back to those golden years and to learn the lessons from the history of this industry.

talk.start.para: —in reply—Firstly, may I thank all members who have participated in the debate on the Wool International Privatisation Bill 1999 . It is a historic and quite significant bill in terms of the wool industry in Australia and exactly where we are as far as the wool industry in Australia is concerned at the moment.

speech.para: This bill, which provides for the conversion of Wool International into a Corporations Law company—WoolStock Australia—has received the closest scrutiny through a lengthy consultation process. As the previous speaker, the member for Kennedy, indicated, the chairman of the Interim Advisory Board, Mr McGauchie, has been consulting widely across Australia with wool growers, the shareholders and the entitlement holders in the stockpile.

It has received the closest scrutiny through a lengthy consultation process at a number of different levels. I am confident it enjoys the strong support of the wool industry. Wool International unit holders will retain their rights to share in the equity from the stockpile sales and will additionally be issued shares in WoolStock Australia. The new company will operate on a commercial basis, independent of government control, and will have a fully commercial board of directors. Importantly, WoolStock Australia will be exempt from income tax on its stockpile activities.

The rights of Wool International equity holders will be protected, although there is scope for the company to take new directions if there is strong support from shareholders to do so. Up to $3 million can be used by the company to investigate and possibly support new business activities.

Over the past few months, there has been widespread debate within the wool industry on this issue. One thing is very clear: the wool industry supports the privatisation of Wool International and can see the many benefits of a fully commercial operation free from the constraints of government influence and control.

I recently announced the appointment of Mr Donald McGauchie as chairman-designate of WoolStock Australia and Mr Reg Clairs and Mr Brian van Rooyen as directors-designate. I am particularly pleased that these prominent commercial directors have agreed to participate as members of the board at the launch of this new company. The Interim Advisory Board's work so far in developing a business plan for the new entity has been invaluable. They are well placed to manage the new company to maximise the benefit to unit holders and shareholders. Stability is the key to a profitable and successful company in the future, and these appointments provide that stability. I also believe that the unit holders have the right and the obligation to make decisions on who runs their company.

Under Corporations Law, a further three directors will be appointed by the board of WoolStock following consultation with industry. Their appointments will be subject to shareholder endorsement at the inaugural general meeting of the company, which will be held soon after conversion. As is normal Corporations Law practice, the terms of one-third of the board will expire each year. I firmly believe this process strikes a balance between the interest of the shareholders in choosing a board accountable to them and the need for stability in the critical first months of the company's existence.

The role of the trustee company received considerable focus in recent weeks during that extensive consultative process that I indicated had been undertaken. I hope that the number of shares managed by TrusteeCo will fall quickly. I am aware the board-designate of WoolStock sees as a priority the need for those unit holders whose names are incorrectly registered to be encouraged to properly record their details before the first general meeting of the company. I can confirm that the role of TrusteeCo will be an independent one. The chairman or directors of WoolStock Australia will not sit on the board of TrusteeCo. The TrusteeCo board will act only in the interests of its beneficiaries. Mr McGauchie fully supports this approach, and this should dispel any concerns that may be raised.

The government is aware of the considerable interest in increasing the depth and liquidity of the market for WoolStock shares. While WoolStock Australia will not, at least initially, be a listed company, it is the intention of the board-designate that exempt markets for the units and shares be developed. Mr McGauchie has, therefore, initiated investigations into the development of such a market for WoolStock equity with a number of potential sponsors.

Some in the industry have indicated that some shareholders may wish the company to conduct business activities beyond selling the stockpile. This is a serious matter for the shareholders to decide and is not something for the government to be involved in. It should be decided by the new board after serious consideration of the wishes and rights of all shareholders. I believe the wool industry will support the protection being written into the company's constitution.

In conclusion, I wish to acknowledge the considerable contribution made to this process by the Interim Advisory Board, headed by Mr Donald McGauchie. The Interim Advisory Board has worked very hard not only in developing a draft business plan for the new company but in liaising and consulting with the wool industry throughout the process. The appointment of Mr McGauchie to the chair of the WoolStock board-designate and of Wool International in the period until 30 June will facilitate the transition to a private sector company. I am very conscious in particular of the uncertainties that have faced the staff of Wool International about their future, and this arrangement will assist in the bedding down of the new organisation.

We have before us this evening a new era in stockpile management. I certainly consider it a privilege to have been involved in this process of taking the decision that was taken by the government prior to the last election to the point where we are now on the verge of taking this legislation through this House and through the Senate so the rightful owners—the shareholders and entitlement holders—in that stockpile will take control in the ultimate destiny of that stockpile. I look forward to the active participation of those shareholders and the new board in the management of that stockpile beyond 30 June. On behalf of the government, I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebateinfo.title: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr Slipper)—by leave—agreed to:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration moving an amendment to Schedule 1 of the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 during the consideration of amendments made by the Senate to the Bill.
Consideration resumed from 18 February.

talk.start.para: —I would like to indicate to the House that the government proposes that amendments Nos 1 to 20, 22 to 25 and 27 to 34 be agreed to, that amendments Nos 21 and 26 be disagreed to, but that amendments be made in place thereof, and that an unrelated amendment to schedule 1 be made. May I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the House to first consider Senate amendments Nos 1 to 20, 22 to 25 and 27 to 34 and, when those amendments have been disposed of, to consider Senate amendments Nos 21 and 26 individually and then the unrelated amendment which I propose moving.
—Is the house in agreement with that proposal?
—Yes.
—I move:

speech.para: That Senate amendments Nos (1) to (20), (22) to (25) and (27) to (34) be agreed to.

The Senate debated the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 in February 1999 and passed the bill with 34 amendments. It is obviously clear that the government would have preferred the bill to pass unamended. However, upon consideration, the government is moving to accept the majority of the amendments made by the Senate to the bill.

In those instances where the government is not agreeing with the amendments adopted by the Senate, the government is moving its own amendments which better achieve the aims the bill sets out to accomplish. As I have foreshadowed today, I am therefore moving government amendments to replace Senate amendments 21 and 26 and correct an anomaly resulting from the Senate amendments, as well as an additional amendment to correct two technical drafting errors.

talk.start.para: —The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 has been around for too long. It was first introduced into the Senate on 14 May 1998. It did not get through the last parliament because the bulk of its proposed measures were devised with the sole intent of providing political advantage to the conservatives. Of course, the parliament saw through why the government was trying to ram it through on the eve of the election. In particular, the legislation as proposed by the government encapsulated the Liberal Party's long obsession and paranoia about unsubstantiated electoral fraud, measures to disenfranchise large numbers of electors, and massive increases in electoral funding and disclosure thresholds to allow large sums of money to go undisclosed.

speech.para: The Senate was very effective in eliminating most of the negative, partisan and politically motivated measures contained within this legislation. In fact, the Senate has actually eliminated most of the legislation. Of the 70 items contained in the legislation, only 26 remain unamended. These are mostly non-controversial. But perhaps, more importantly, the Senate also approved opposition amendments to close the Greenfields loophole once and for all.

So what are we actually left with in the legislation? Items 1 to 9 deal with electoral roll information and penalties for misuse. As we have said previously, we do think it is useful for parliamentarians to have access to further electoral roll information, such as electors' date of birth and salutation details, in order to more accurately address constituents and target information more directly. We also think it is useful to extend the range of permitted purposes for use of the electoral roll information to research regarding electoral matters. However, given potential privacy concerns, the sensitivity of this information and its value to commercial marketing companies, it is important that there exists sufficient penalties for misuse of such information.

As we have argued earlier, 10 penalty units or $1,000, as it currently stands, is clearly inadequate as a deterrent against misuse of this sensitive and valuable information. The government's proposal to increase the penalty to 100 units or $11,000 was a step in the right direction. However, we believe that a more severe penalty should be imposed, given the increased access to electors' information and the sensitivity and value of that information.

Labor amendments to increase the number of penalty units to 1,000, or $110,000, for disclosure or using for a commercial purpose electoral roll information were successful in the Senate. Despite the parliamentary secretary's remarks in this chamber last year that `The increase proposed by the Labor Party is inappropriate. It is a stunt. The government's increase is adequate,' I am glad that his senior minister, Senator Ellison, saw the wisdom of our arguments and pulled the government in behind the Labor opposition to support our amendments.

The Senate rejected the government's attempts to remove the voting rights of all prisoners. The legislation will remain with the current five-year rule, whereby only prisoners serving a sentence of five years or longer do not get a vote. However, they retain the right to remain on the electoral roll.

The Senate also rejected the government's proposed changes to the enrolment period. More importantly, the Senate saw through the government's attempts to disenfranchise thousands of voters at each election with the early closure of the rolls. The real devil of these measures was in the detail. Not only did the government want to close the roles three working days after the issue of the writ, but they also wanted to prevent first-time voters from getting a vote at all by preventing new names being added to the rolls at the issue of the writ. This would have affected about 80,000 people at each election, mostly young Australians and new Australian citizens.

The Senate also recognised the precedent for avoiding transparent funding and disclosure by the conservatives and rejected the government's attempts to increase the funding disclosure thresholds. The changes would have increased from $1,500 to $10,000 the amount above which a donor to a political party must furnish a return for the financial year.
Honourable member interjecting—

talk.start.para: —John Howard thinks you are conservatives. They would have also increased from $1,500 to $5,000 the amount that political parties are required to disclose during a financial year for funding received from a person or organisation.

speech.para: The Senate deliberated for some time on the issue of assisted voting in the marking of ballot papers. The government's proposed changes provided that a presiding officer at a polling place is the only person who can assist a voter to mark their ballot paper. Voters' friends may still be present. However, for the first time scrutineers would be required to observe the process. On the surface this may seem a reasonable proposition. However, if you consider a scenario where someone needs an assisted vote—they either have a disability, English language problems or they are illiterate—as the Electoral Act currently stands, this person would take just their friend in to help them vote.

The government was proposing a situation where at least four people are in the compartment of the booth—the voter, their friend, the presiding officer and scrutineers, which is pretty intimidating for voters with a disability, literacy or English language difficulties and certainly not in the spirit of the act that a person's vote should be personal and confidential. Now your secret ballot would be shared by at least three others. Clearly, this would be particularly intimidating for Aboriginal voters in the Northern Territory, Western Australia and regional Queensland.

For these reasons, the opposition supported Green amendments to omit items 32 to 35 and items 37 to 42 in the Senate. Unfortunately, the Green amendments neglected to pick up the important equivalent amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984—that is, items 55 to 58 and 60 to 65. We acknowledge that the government has taken on board some of the concerns of the Senate and tried to offer amendments which embrace some of the amendments which embrace some of the suggestions made by Senator Harradine. However, the government's amendments on assisted voting still contain some provisions whereby party scrutineers will have a right to actually witness people voting. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I take this opportunity to speak now and I also want to speak to the next part.
—You can only speak for three minutes by agreement.

—We will see. I may need more than three. I do want to make mention of the suggestions made by the honourable member prior to me about the question of assisted voting. I think it would be more appropriate that I speak to the next element of the amendments, which is one we will oppose.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That Senate amendment (21) be disagreed to and Government amendments (1) and (4) be made in place of it.

At the outset I want to reject the suggestion made by the honourable member for Melbourne that what we wanted to do with this legislation prior to the debate in the Senate was in some way to rort the electoral system. What the coalition has sought to do in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 is to make sure that we have integrity of the electoral roll and of the electoral system so that the result as declared on polling day after an election represents what the Australian people wanted to happen. It did not do any credit at all for the Labor Party in this place and in the Senate to seek to undermine the safeguards of electoral integrity, which the government was seeking to build into the legislation.

I think it is a matter of eminent regret that all of the legislation, all of the provisions of the bill that were originally moved and carried in this place, was not supported by the Senate. We are all about openness and fairness. We are not about disenfranchising people, except those people who do not have a right to be on the electoral roll or those people who do not exist. All we seek to do is to make sure there is integrity in Australian elections, integrity in the electoral rolls. We want to make sure that our Australian electoral system remains fair and open and is honest and accountable. The opposition in the other place sought to thwart that very laudable aim by the coalition. They defeated some provisions of the bill with the result that the bill ultimately enacted will not be as good as the bill which was originally proposed by the government. Having said that, the majority of Senate amendments are being accepted as a matter of reality. The legislation after it does pass both houses will not be as good as it would have been, but it certainly will be better than the law as it currently exists.

I would like to explain for the benefit of honourable members why the coalition is not accepting Senate amendment No. 21. Senate amendment No. 21 would leave the assisted voting provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act as they currently stand. Yet, ironically, the Senate passed revised assisted voting provisions to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. This would mean that there would be different rules applying to Commonwealth elections to those which apply to referenda. This disparity would lead to elector confusion at referenda and also at elections. Secondly, there has been considerable concern expressed about the current procedures for assisted voting.
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You ought to know, my friend, because a lot of the rorting occurred in the Northern Territory. You know it and everyone knows it. The reality is Nick Dondas should have been elected. People in the Northern Territory wanted Nick Dondas, but because of rorting in voting in that place we find that the parliament is saddled with your presence rather than the continued sterling, diligent, impressive service of our former colleague the Hon. Nick Dondas.

speech.para: Mr Snowdon interjecting—
Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I call the minister to order, as well as the member for the Northern Territory. I advise the parliamentary secretary to take the debate through the chair.

—Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, I point out that it is because of rorting in the Northern Territory that we see the return of the gentleman opposite and the loss of a person for whom I believe you and all of us had a high regard, the Hon. Nick Dondas.

speech.para: As I was saying before I was diverted by my colleague opposite, considerable concern has been expressed about the current procedures for assisted voting, and the government believes that the most appropriate solution to these concerns is to provide that only a presiding officer may assist the voter to cast his or her vote. Government amendments 1 and 4 also address concerns about assisted voting raised during Senate debate on this issue. We are all about making sure the electoral system is fair. Australians are citizens of a nation which has a very strong and highly developed sense of fair play over 99 years of federation. What we aim to do through this bill and its provisions is to make sure we have integrity in the electoral system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We will be opposing this proposal from the government. Section 234 of the act and other related legislation currently provides that, if a voter's sight is impaired or if they are incapacitated or illiterate, the voter can appoint a person to assist them in voting. The voter has a say in who helps them. That is appropriate and that is what the legislation currently says. It is something which I think should be retained. The government's bill in its original form proposed to radically change this, as mentioned by the member for Melbourne. I will not repeat what he said. Quite rightly, the Senate rejected that approach. But what the government has now come back with in terms of assisted voting is that the presiding officer marking the paper and the scrutineers will be able to watch. Generally, scrutineers will now be able to watch if the voter is happy with that, but the government has left in scenarios where scrutineers will be able to watch whether the voter wants them to or not.

speech.para: This is about the rights of the voter—not the rights of the Labor Party or the rights of the Liberal Party, but the rights of the voter. What we are seeing here is an unprecedented move by the government to remove the rights of illiterate voters, voters with English as a second language and visually impaired voters to vote with the assistance of a friend without some galah from the CLP, the ALP or anywhere else oversighting their vote and pressurising those people to vote in a particular way.

Madam Acting Deputy Speaker Crosio, the way in which this is being used in the Northern Territory is something for you to understand. I want to make it clear that the Northern Territory CLP has made complaints to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on a number of issues. It has made complaints about what they say is the improper use of voters' friends by voters. I think it is extremely relevant to point out that, in paragraph 30.3 of the Australian Electoral Commission submission to the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters on 4 May, it says:

At the outset, it should be noted that: (a) The AEC has received no formal complaints from Aboriginal voters themselves about the conduct of assisted voting in remote mobile polling in the Northern Territory or elsewhere in Australia; (b) The AEC does not accept that there is any balanced or credible evidence to support generalised claims that assisted voting in remote mobile polling in Aboriginal communities has been conducted improperly or illegally, either at the last federal election or at previous federal elections; (c) the NTCLP did not put its allegations about illegalities under the Electoral Act before the Court of Disputed Returns for judicial consideration following the 1998 federal election.

This is a scurrilous attempt to deny people the right to a secret ballot and ensure that they are pressurised either into not voting or making a vote which suits the CLP or any other scrutineer who might be present. We should not be arguing for an approach where the presiding officer, or anyone else other than the voter's friend, is the person who assists the voter with the vote. A proposal has been put up which would suggest that the voter's friend be allowed into the booth, but that the presiding officer should accompany them. I make an observation: paragraph 7.5.13 of the submission by the Australian Electoral Commission—submission No. 88—this year makes comment about this suggestion:

It has also been suggested that the nominated friend might remain to facilitate assisted voting but with the addition of a presiding officer or other polling officer in attendance to strictly ensure the integrity of the process. However, the effectiveness of such a process in many circumstances will be limited by the language abilities of these officials—
self-evident, I would have thought—

that is, in some Aboriginal communities, as well as in metropolitan areas with high non-English speaking populations, it is difficult to see how polling officials who only understand English could monitor a conversation between voters and their friends in another language.

This is about the right of individuals to cast the vote they want to cast, and not a vote which the CLP, the ALP, the Liberal Party or any other particular party wants them to vote, and not be pressurised in the booths.

I would like to go into some detail about the approach adopted by the CLP in the Northern Territory to try and prevent Aboriginal people in this instance from casting a valid vote by the use of intimidating tactics—calling police into booths; not by informing the presiding officer, but by using a voter's friend to call police into the booth and intimidate voters. These are the sorts of tactics which they are using to try and deny people their right to vote and thereby try and ensure that they return a member of their political persuasion. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to return to my observations on the matter that the member for the Northern Territory has just been dealing with. So much for a secret ballot. The government's amendments on assisted voting are still unacceptable. It remains our position that we would prefer to consider this quite difficult and complex issue in some detail through the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and, in the interim, omit the government's proposed changes and leave the Commonwealth Electoral Act as it is.

speech.para: We would like to consider the issue of assisted voting with the benefit of the views and advice of officers of the AEC from the Northern Territory and other regions with high numbers of assisted voters. We would also like to hear what representatives of those groups in the community who have a high number of assisted voters—namely, indigenous and ethnic communities, as well as people with disabilities—have to contribute about their experiences.

The only measures the opposition was not successful in defeating in the Senate were the imposition of changes to enrolment witnessing and proof of citizenship procedures. However, we note that Senator Allison gave commitments inside and outside the chamber to include the opposition in consultations regarding the make-up of the final regulations. We intend to hold her to that commitment. This takes me to perhaps the most controversial of amendments adopted by the Senate—the opposition's Greenfields amendments. With government support, our amendments to the definition of `associated entity' were successful. The definition will now read `operates wholly or to a significant extent for the benefit of one or more registered political parties', omitting `mainly', to be replaced by `to a significant extent'.

Amendments to the disclosure period for gifts were also accepted with government support. The opposition's changes will close the loophole in the event of a loan being forgiven ultimately becoming a gift. The disclosure of loans was the critical amendment. Opposition amendments will prevent loans from being received from anyone other than a registered financial institution unless certain information such as terms and conditions of the loan are disclosed. We also inserted a definition of a loan as per Income Tax Assessment Act section 109D, subsection 3.

The primary problem we have with the $4.65 million Greenfields loan is that we have no evidence to suggest or prove that it is a loan given on commercial terms—in fact, to the contrary: we do know from their annual return that the Liberals made annual payments of $100,000 to the Greenfields Foundation. A $100,000 per annum repayment on a $4.65 million loan is certainly a very lucrative rate—about 2½ per cent. There does not appear to be any indication that there would be any commercial rate of interest or that the loan was made on a commercial basis.

The evidence mounts that this loan has been forgiven. The loan would then constitute a gift. During questioning in Senate estimates, the AEC conceded that a 2½ per cent interest rate on a loan would give reasonable grounds to assume that the loan was not on a commercial basis and possibly even constituted a gift. Well, of course it is. It is $4.65 million that the Liberal Party will never have to repay in full. That is just the $4.65 million that has been disclosed so far, up until the end of the last financial year. We do not know what money changed hands after that, in the lead-up to the October election.

Our amendments would prohibit a loan from being received from anyone other than a registered financial institution—thereby guaranteeing its commercial nature—unless certain basic information was disclosed, such as the terms and conditions of the loan and details about the individual or organisation from whom the loan was received. I believe this information would greatly assist the AEC in their investigation and pursuit of possible or suspected associated entities. The amendments do not prohibit loans from being received. They just say that if you get a loan from an organisation other than a registered financial institution then you have to disclose enough about that loan to inform the AEC as to whether it is on a commercial basis or not or, indeed, if it would actually constitute a gift.

The minister, Senator Ellison, flagged some concerns with these amendments. Initially these were about certain credit cards such as Diners Club and American Express being caught up by not fitting our definition of registered financial institutions. So credit card debts may need disclosure. This is clearly not the intent of the amendments, so we offered to work with them to find a suitable form of words to close that off. We altered our amendments to insert, after `loan', `of $1,500 or more' to eliminate minor credit card transactions. We were also advised by the AEC that significant payments to credit card companies such as Diners Club and American Express are not featuring in the annual re turns. So either the government were looking for problems where there were none or the Liberal Party is not disclosing its payments to American Express or Diners Club.

The minister also indicated the government had concerns about there being no definition of a `loan' in the Commonwealth Electoral Act which may present problems for our amendments regarding loans. That is why we inserted in our revised amendments a definition of `loan' lifted directly from the Income Tax Assessment Act. The government have been peddling the pathetic lines of their national director Lynton Crosby, who has been making a fool of himself in the national press by trying to set his own definitions of a loan versus a debt. Hopefully, this definition as set out in the Income Tax Assessment Act will help Lynton Crosby and Ron Walker, along with the Special Minister of State and the Prime Minister, to understand exactly what constitutes a loan. Senator Ellison has finally worked out that there is no support for their position on Greenfields. There is no point trying to defend the indefensible. He has swallowed humble pie on behalf of the government and the Liberal Party of Australia and is now trying to work with the opposition on these amendments. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to add a few more comments to those I made initially. We need to understand what this debate is fundamentally about. I have expressed a view that it is about the rights of people to cast a valid vote. The proposition being put by the government that the presiding officer and/or his delegate should be the voter's friend for the purpose of being the voter's friend in terms of these amendments is actually quite impractical. The fact is that in some Aboriginal communities—certainly in my electorate—where you might get some hundreds of people voting, generally early in the morning, it is quite likely that 50 or 60 per cent of those voters will need assistance and they will require a voter's friend.

speech.para: Madam Deputy Speaker, I do not have to tell you that the resources of the Electoral Commission are not that great. In this instance, we would have the prospect of persons unknown to the people in that community trying to assist them to vote, possibly not being able to speak or understand their language or understand the cultural imperatives that might prevail in those situations. This is not only a circumstance which arises in the Northern Territory; it arises elsewhere in Australia and it arises in urban situations.

We have here a proposition by the government that the person who should assist that voter will be the presiding officer, with the possibility that scrutineers could oversight how the vote is being cast. That is a recipe for ultimate disaster. The way to deal with this is to leave the legislation as it is, to educate party scrutineers on how they should properly operate within and around booths and to ensure that the presiding officers have the means and the mechanisms at their disposal to ensure the appropriate observation of the rules within the area of the booths.

In the case of the Northern Territory, they would like to amend the legislation so it mirrors the Northern Territory legislation which, as the Australian Electoral Commission observes in its submission, is unfair. The ultimate reason is they are concerned that in election after election that I have contested I have received between 75 and 80 per cent of the vote of Aboriginal people who live in rural and remote areas. That is what this is about.

talk.start.para: —Do they know they are voting for you?

—This is the arrogance—and ultimately a racist sentiment—which is being expressed by my friend opposite. That mirrors what is being said by the CLP in the Northern Territory that somehow or another these voters are incapable of determining who they want to vote for.
—They are being led astray.

—That is the attitude which is being adopted by the government in putting this proposition forward. The fact of the matter is these people know exactly who they want to vote for. When they go into a booth and they hand the presiding officer or the voter's friend a card and they say, `How do you want to vote?' and they say, `I want to vote for the Labor Party' or `I want to vote for the CLP,' that is an indication of how they want to vote. But what we see happening time after time on these booths is CLP scrutineers muscling in and trying to tell these people that is not the way they want to vote.
—Rubbish!

—I can tell that these people opposite have no idea what happens in these booths. I have had experience of this operation for over 25 years. I can tell you, without a shadow of a doubt, that the issue which is at the forefront of people's minds when they go to have a vote is to do what you and I do when we go and have a vote: that is, cast a valid vote for the party or persons of our choice and not be intimidated by overbearing standover merchants and goons who come to these booths with the intention of trying to prevent people from voting.

speech.para: I had the experience of taking affidavits from people who were involved in the Ernie Bridge case in Western Australia where conservative party scrutineers almost physically intimidated people at booths to prevent them from voting. They did so because of their concern that these people would not vote for their candidate. This proposal, if it were to get up, would be a recipe for disaster. It would be a disaster on two levels. It would not reflect the views of the population, but most importantly it would deny Aboriginal people their legitimate right—in this case in the Northern Territory—to vote for the candidate or party of their choice.

talk.start.para: —I have a couple of words to say in relation to what the member opposite has said. I believe that the member for the Northern Territory has been exceptionally offensive in the comment that he just made. As a government we are not seeking to intimidate people. We are trying to bring about a system whereby the people of the Northern Territory, whether Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal, or the people in other parts of the country, have a mechanism for assisted voting which will help them to cast their votes in accordance with their wishes so that their vote goes to the party or candidate of their choice.

speech.para: Regrettably, there is widespread abuse under the current provisions of the Electoral Act in that many people in the Northern Territory who wished to vote for one party or candidate may well have ended up having their votes cast in favour of the member for the Northern Territory, when the last thing those people wanted would have been for their votes to be put against the tally of the member for the Northern Territory. We are seeking to bring about a system of fairness and a system of openness—a system where we put in place provisions for assisted voting that genuinely do assist people.
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —At the moment there is provision for widespread intimidation. One simply cannot say that the result as declared in the Northern Territory represented what those people in the Northern Territory actually wanted to do on polling day.

speech.para: With this legislation we aim to bring about openness, fairness, accountability and integrity not only of the electoral roll but also of the result which stems from the way in which people vote. We just want their votes to be cast in accordance with the way they want to vote. At the moment there is intimidation, which largely happens through the offices of people who support the Australian Labor Party in the Northern Territory. But what we are seeking is not party-political advantage; we are simply seeking integrity of election results.

It should also be noted that section 327 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act makes it an offence for a person to interfere with the free exercise by another person of his or her political rights, and the penalty is $1,000 or six months imprisonment. So there is a current provision which imposes a penalty. We believe that the legislation, as we are proposing it, will greatly assist the integrity of the electoral result. It will mean that people can go to the polling booth with confidence that they will genuinely be able to receive assistance when they require it, and that is assistance to vote in the way in which they, the voters, wish to vote.

talk.start.para: —It was not my intention to get up on my feet again, but I cannot let pass the comments made by the honourable member. He is saying that the vote of the people of the Northern Territory who voted in these remote booths was not an accurate expression of their will. There is absolutely no evidence of that, nor is there any Aboriginal person I know of in the Northern Territory who voted in one of those booths who would say that. The parliamentary secretary comes from somewhere around Brisbane. He would have absolutely no idea of the conditions which prevail in the Northern Territory, let alone in the rest of remote Australia.

speech.para: I think it is an absolute scandal that the government should have this person, as a parliamentary secretary representing the government, standing at the box today and saying that the way in which people voted in the Northern Territory was not an accurate reflection of their will and then saying that somehow or other this vote was rorted by the ALP. I find that absolutely offensive. I am sure that the voters in the Northern Territory will find it offensive, because I will let them know that the attitude of this government—as represented by the person who spoke before me—is that they have not cast a valid vote, that somehow or other their vote was interfered with, and that somehow or other they did not express their will. I have to say my comments about you earlier are accurate. Your arrogance, your demeanour, your attitude is one—

talk.start.para: —Order! You will take it through the chair and you will stick to the debate.
—I will take it through the chair. The attitude of the member who spoke before me is one of arrogance. The arrogance which he represented in his statement—

—I will ask the honourable member for the Northern Territory to come back to the debate, which is on clause 21 of the Senate amendments being disagreed to. I ask you to stick with the debate before the House.
—I am, Madam Deputy Speaker. This person who arrogantly got up and spoke said that in relation to this particular amendment—

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The member for the Northern Territory is clearly not sticking to the line of the debate. I would ask that you bring him back to the debate before the House—not simply a whole line of slur and innuendo in the course of the process.

—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker: I find it extraordinary that the minister rises to make that point of order, when the parliamentary secretary charged with the conduct of this legislation has made damaging allegations that go to the legitimacy of the vote in the seat that the member for the Northern Territory holds in this House. I would have thought that no more serious allegations could have been made. To hold that the member cannot respond in the powerful and passionate language that he is would be entirely unworthy.
—Order! There is no point of order, but I will ask the member for the Northern Territory to stay with the debate that is before the House.

—Absolutely, Madam Deputy Speaker. I am referring to the comments which were made by the previous speaker. I think it is a scandal. I want to know whether his party endorses the view he has expressed here this afternoon: that the people who voted in the poll last year did not cast a legitimate vote, because that is what he is saying.

speech.para: That is what this amendment is about. This amendment is about the government trying to pressure people to vote in a way or to vote informally. They know what this is about. You have only to read the submissions made by the Northern Territory CLP to the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters to understand what they are about. I might add that the submissions which the Northern Territory CLP made to the joint committee have been responded to point by point by the Australian Electoral Commission, which has rebutted every argument they have put up.

I made the observation earlier on that, in the context of the allegations that have been made, they have not substantiated any of them—not one of them. What they have demonstrated is their own ignorance and their incapacity to deal properly with the rights of people to cast a valid vote. They should stop interfering with this process and allow people to determine who it is they want to assist them in the voting process. What they should do is ensure that that happens so that these people—that is, the government—do not have their will and deny people their legitimate right to express their will and their view as to who they want to elect either individually or as a party. I think this House deserves an apology from the member who spoke previously for the way in which he represented the voters of the Northern Territory in this House.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I am quite interested in the remarks of the member for the Northern Territory simply on—

speech.para: Mr Kerr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I only had to have one or two minutes of his speech. I have known him for longer than you have. But I too have lived in the remote areas of Western Australia for a long time and the proposals, as I understand them from reading the briefs on this legislation—

speech.para: Mr Kerr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Oh yes, we get people from New South Wales who went to Tasmania to get elected—

speech.para: Mr Kerr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You had to move back, didn't you.
—No, I did not. I will remind the minister, I never moved to Tasmania, nor did I move back again.
—I am sorry, Madam Deputy Speaker, you are quite right. But, on the other hand, there are processes by which you might discipline members for interjecting.

speech.para: However, all we are saying in this legislation is that there is a simple way of maintaining the reputation of the voters of any part of Australia; that is, to make sure that they personally cast their own vote and that they are not helped by certain people. That help can be given in an appropriate way where the actions, for instance, of the returning officer or the polling officer are overseen by someone else, a proper witness. But you seem to tell us that that is inappropriate.

We have two options in all of this. The first option is for people—and most people are capable of handling the ballot paper which is written in English—to go into a polling booth and privately cast their vote. There are some who request assistance from the returning officer, and this legislation says that there should be a process for that. If you suggest that is wrong, then you have a worry—you have a little worry that, in fact, you might lose some votes.
Mr Kerr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The reality is that, if you object to a proper process—and a proper process simply saying that there will be proper supervision when a voter requests assistance—you have a problem; if a proper process is put in place, you will have a problem that your current arrangements will have to confront. You can explain to us the process that you now practise. But I ask you: why are you frightened of a process which simply says that, if someone seeks assistance, there will be arrangements whereby assistance will be properly looked at and properly overseen?

speech.para: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It does not.
—It does; read the act.
—I have read the act.
—Are we going to go into debate across the floor or through the chair? I remind the member for the Northern Territory that he has had his say; the minister has the call.

—There is considerable criticism of the current arrangements and they need to be improved. Why are you so committed to the present arrangements and so worried about those as proposed? Only because you see that you have something to gain by remaining under the current arrangements.

speech.para: The reality of all this is that people's voting intentions go to their personal choice and should not be manipulated by others, and we are proposing a very sensible process that puts that above criticism. Anybody who objects to it, in my mind, does so because they believe that they are advantaged by the present system.

You cannot criticise this process; it does not offend anybody. It just says that, if you make a request to be assisted with your voting, that process should be properly overseen by other people because that is not the way we vote normally. Once you ask for the arrangement to be abnormal, then it is fair enough for the interested parties to have some involvement. You are saying that they should not have that involvement. I think you realise the benefit it brings to you electorally and not to the voter.

talk.start.para: —I wish to conclude my remarks. As the parliamentary secretary pointed out, I have been speaking in globo on the amendments. But that essentially has been to assist the government with time rather than for any other purpose.

speech.para: Since the Senate debate, Senator Ellison has raised some concerns about potential unintended consequences arising from our amendments. We are happy to work with the government to overcome these concerns, provided that what is done does not detract from the intent of our amendments. The government is proposing to insert a point of clarification about credit cards to ensure that only individual transactions above $1,500 are reported rather than cumulative transactions to that value. They have also inserted a definition of a credit card from section 12DL of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 1989. We are happy to incorporate these amendments.

The government is also proposing to insert a further point (e) into our definition of a financial institution to allow entities as prescribed by regulation. This is intended to pick up mortgage originators and credit facilities such as Diners Club and American Express. Again we are happy to incorporate this amendment. It is not the intent of our amendments to force disclosure of a personal or home loan or credit card just because they do not come under the Australian Financial Institutions Commission's code as a registered financial institution.

The government has proposed a couple of technical amendments relating to drafting inconsistencies arising from omissions by the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997. We will support these non-controversial amendments. That concludes my formal comments on the various amendments.

May I add to the comments of the member for Denison my disgust at the reflection on the legitimacy of the member for the Northern Territory's position in this place as expressed by the parliamentary secretary, and the reflection that has been cast by him and effectively by the Minister for Forestry and Conservation on the legitimate voting intentions of those people who have elected the member for the Northern Territory. I think some of the comments we heard here this afternoon were pretty disgraceful.

talk.start.para: —I need only a couple of minutes. I heard the debate and I want to add a couple of things which I think are quite important. In the electorate of Grey, there is a significant Aboriginal population, and significant remote polling booth apparatuses set up by the AEC. The important statistic to remember in all of this is that informal voting in the electorate of Grey and nationally is around 3½ to four per cent. Informal voting in the remote polling is 1.4 per cent. The comments made by constituents who witnessed events at some of these remote polling booths were of alarm. When they challenged the AEC officials, they were abused.

speech.para: We have a very strong democratic system in this country run by the Australian Electoral Commission. It is essential to the integrity of the system that the AEC be accountable. That is why I support the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 . There is enough evidence to suggest that there are some anomalies. I repeat: just over one per cent informality compared to four per cent for the national average in remote booths. I simply make the point that, for the sake of the AEC itself, there should be an accountable system. They need to be accountable, in my opinion, to the extent of how many people are actually assisted and who assists. In the report on each electorate, that should be very clearly spelt out. It is very important for the essence of our democracy itself, and it is very important from the perspective of the AEC.

talk.start.para: —I want to add a few notes. When the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 was before this place in December last year, it contained some positive measures aimed at improving our democracy. They included various steps to reduce the possibility of fraud, allowing the presiding officer to help the sight impaired and physically disabled vote, and requiring people to notify the Electoral Commission within a month when they change address. But there are also various measures contained that I could not support because, in turn, they infringed citizens' human rights and were possibly unconstitutional or they invaded the privacy of citizens or generally weakened our democracy.

speech.para: Back in December the measures I objected to in the bill were the removal of the right to vote from imprisoned people, permitting MPs access to the birth and salutation details of electors for research purposes, increasing the threshold at which political parties must count individual donations from $500 to $1,500, and increasing the threshold at which political parties are required to disclose amounts received from individual organisations from $1,500 to $5,000 and increasing the threshold from 1,500 to $10,000 the amount above which a donor to a political party must furnish a return for a financial year.

I am pleased to see the first of these—a proposal to disenfranchise anyone serving any period of imprisonment—has been removed by the Senate by omitting proposed new section 109. I am glad also to see the Senate has rejected this proposal because, as far as I am concerned, the right to vote, to have a say in who governs the country, is a basic human right. As I said in December, to take away that right is to say you do not believe in the concept of rehabilitation. Unfortunately, the Senate has not dealt significantly with the other measures of concern. No amendments have been made to proposed section 91, which gives MPs access to birth and marriage details of electors for so-called research.

These changes on their face might seem insignificant, but they will see the privacy of electors invaded. If these proposals go through, they will open the door for more and more targeted mail-outs from MPs, especially during elections. With regard to proposed increases in disclosure thresholds of political donations, I note that the Senate has made detailed amendments. However, they certainly do not throw out or even scale back the large increases in donation thresholds proposed in the original bill. They simply add sections to include loan arrangements—I presume loan arrangements like that entered into between the Liberal Party and the mysterious Greenfields Foundation.

What the Greenfields exercise shows is that, for whatever reason, the major parties—and One Nation is showing a trend towards this—simply do not want their funding sources identified. The threshold increases contained in the bill may not seem significant in real terms, but in percentage terms we are talking about massive increases: 300 per cent for the threshold before which one-off donations to parties have to be counted, 330 per cent increase for donations received over a financial year and over 600 per cent for the donation threshold above which a donor must lodge a return to the AEC.

The Senate amendments do not address these increases. The amendments to the relevant sections simply bring under the scope of the new threshold loan arrangements which, under the current legislation, have effectively disguised the true source or nature of the donation. No wonder there has been little, if any, opposition to the proposed increases to the disclosure threshold contained in this bill by either or any of the major parties. These changes will make political parties less accountable.

The simple fact is that, for a strong and accountable democracy, electors have to know as much as possible about which individuals, companies, unions or other organisations are funding political parties or their associated entities. We might be talking only about $1,500, $5,000 and $10,000 at the moment, but inevitably if these changes go through in a few years time we will be voting on $3,000, $10,000, $20,000 and so on. For all these reasons at the moment, until I look a little more carefully at the amendments, I cannot support this bill even in its amended form.

talk.start.para: —This exercise is about ensuring people can cast a valid vote and not be pressurised into voting a particular way. I have a view on the role of scrutineers in these particular instances where a voter's friend is assisting a voter. Sometimes, indeed often, the presence of scrutineers looking over the shoulder—and I have experience of this—of voters to ensure that the voter's friend casts the vote in the way in which the voter intends is an absolutely intimidating experience.

speech.para: What we have here is a proposition that this will happen again, not only with the voter's friend but that the voter's friend be the presiding officer. Frankly, that ignores all of the realities that exist in remote communities and, I dare say, in communities in Sydney where there are people for whom English is a second language. How the hell is the presiding officer going to communicate with someone who does not speak English? You do not have to be Einstein to work it out. There are many Aboriginal communities in remote Australia where people cannot read English; they find it difficult to express themselves in English. When they go into a voting both and can articulate the person they want to vote for—because they have seen a photograph out the front, they may have had discussions with party scrutineers or people handing out how-to-vote cards beyond the six metres—they come in with a view. What is being proposed will expose them to the fact that they will not have a secret ballot, because it will potentially be observed by three, four or five other people. That opens up the question of how people who vote in a particular way might well be intimidated after the event.

I suggest that honourable members opposite—I take note of what the member for Grey said—read the submissions from the Electoral Commission to the joint committee. I think they carry a lot of weight because of the logical way in which they have represented the arguments and the logical way in which they have rebutted the views expressed by the CLP in its submissions to the inquiry. They have rejected the proposals put by the government and demonstrated clearly that we have here the potential for the abrogation of people's rights. That is what this is all about. Unfortunately, I think some people on the other side have confused that issue with their own political imperatives. What we should be about in this place is what is good for the people of Australia. We should give them the right to express their will freely. The proposal which is being canvassed by the government and which we will oppose does not do that in any way, shape or form.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That Senate amendment (26) be disagreed to and Government amendment (2) be made in place of it.

In relation to the matters raised by the member for the Northern Territory, there have been allegations with respect to electoral fraud. The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 is simply aiming to improve the integrity of the electoral system to make sure that each of us, when declared to be elected, has genuinely been elected as a result of the wishes of the voters in our individual electorates.

I have moved that the House disagree to amendment No. 26 because it has the potential to have an unintended application to certain loans and to loans from certain entities. In particular there is uncertainty over the treatment of credit card debt and concern that credit providers, such as American Express and Aussie Home Loans, were not included as financial institutions. To correct these deficiencies government amendment No. 2 provides a definition of credit card, expressly provides that each credit card transaction is to be treated as a separate loan and provides for an entity to be prescribed by regulation as a financial institution for the purposes of sec tion 306A. I think my friend has already spoken to this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (3) Schedule 1, page 10 (before line 3), before item 47, insert:

para.inline: 46B Paragraph 314AEA(1)(b)

speech.para: Omit ", together with the details required by section 314AD".

para.inline: 46C Subsection 314AEA(5)

speech.para: Omit ", 314AD".

para.inline: 46D Subsection 314AEA(5)

speech.para: Omit "314AB(1)(a)", substitute "314AB(2)(a)".

para.inline: [technical correction]

speech.para: This is essentially a technical amendment, and I am quite certain that all of us on both sides in this place will be more than happy to see this technical amendment carried by the parliament. Government amendment No. 3 removes redundant references to section 316AD in section 314AEA. Section 316AD was repealed in July 1998 by the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act 1998. It also amends the reference in subsection 314EAE(5) from 314AB(1)(a) to 314AB(2)(a). This corrects an oversight in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act 1998 that renumbered paragraph 314AB(1)(a) to 314AB(2)(a).

This bill will improve the level of accountability governing our electoral system, which in turn is a protection for democracy and our way of life. I commend the motion to the chamber. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum and the further supplementary explanatory memorandum.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Mr Slipper) agreed to:
That in the message returning the Bill to the Senate, the Senate be requested to reconsider the Bill in respect of amendment No. 3 made by the House of Representatives to Schedule 1.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 31 March, on motion by Mr Hockey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I invite the House to cast its mind back to this day exactly one year ago, 12 May 1998, to budget day of last year. In that budget the Treasurer announced a range of initiatives relating to changes in the regulations of do-it-yourself superannuation funds. These changes included the transfer of superannuation fund regulations to the Australian Taxation Office, a lowering of the regulatory charge for DIY super funds, a new definition of the DIY superannuation funds to be called self-managed funds, changes to the penalty regime and new investment rules.

speech.para: Many members may recall that there was an enormous public outcry from small business owners that run a do-it-yourself superannuation fund over the issue of the investment rule changes. The government caved in before the month of May was ended and announced that the proposed changes would not be made retrospective as was proposed by requiring funds to unwind investment decisions that they had already made.

It was, I dare say, the fastest government backflip on a budget announcement in the history of the Commonwealth parliament. It was also an example of policy making on the run and by press release. But it is an indictment of the government that we are debating this bill today on the first anniversary of the 1998 budget announcement. It indicates the contempt with which the Howard-Costello government has treated superannuation fund members, the trustees and the fund administrators, beginning with the superannuation surcharge tax in the 1996 budget, the abandonment of Labor's superannuation co-contribution in the 1997 budget, and now it is the turn of the DIY superannuation funds, courtesy of the 1998 budget. Indeed, it is my intention to move a second reading amendment which indicates our concern about these things. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for the financial uncertainty and hardship it has caused Do It Yourself superannuation fund trustees and fund members, many of which are operated by small businesses, in taking nearly 12 months since it announced its changes to introduce and debate this legislation.

On the subject of the government's superannuation initiatives, the government has pulled around $5 billion out of superannuation since it came to office. The surcharge tax alone pulled out around $1.4 billion which the government claimed would be paid by higher income earners but which is actually paid by all superannuation fund members through higher administration costs and by those fund members who are under the threshold but who have not provided their tax file number to their superannuation fund.

The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has estimated that surcharge tax administration has cost superannuation funds some $190 million to collect, that is, $190 million less in retirement incomes that working Australians on low and middle incomes will have to spend when they retire. That is a $190 million cost to the funds themselves. I have, in fact, asked the Treasurer a set of questions on notice about how much it is costing taxpayers to collect all this. So far he has not responded to that question. I might have to have a word to the Speaker about that in due course.

Senate estimates last week revealed that some 65,000 surcharge tax assessment notices would be sent to fund members who have not provided their tax file numbers to their fund or to the tax office. I expect that many of those members would not be high income earners at all.

Last night's budget quantified the backflip made by the government in abolishing the advance instalment of the superannuation surcharge tax. The government will lose $120 million in revenue in the year 2000-01, $10 million in 2001-02 and $5 million in 2002-03. The government's 1997 budget decision not to proceed with the superannuation co-contribution ripped a further $4 billion from the superannuation accounts of low and middle income earners. So that is over $5 billion taken from superannuation accounts of Australian workers in just two measures. Throw in the damage caused by a flawed choice of funds policy, an announcement—but as yet no legislation—about allowing opting out, and the inclusion of superannuation assets in the means test for over 55s, effectively forcing older Australians to fund their own unemployment benefits, and you get a picture of the disdain with which this government has treated superannuation and collective savings vehicles in general.

You also get a picture of a government which has no retirement incomes policy of its own and one which is trying to tear down the world-leading, best-practice policy established by successive Labor governments. Having done that damage, ringbarking Labor's superannuation tree, this government then turned its beady little eye to the excluded superannuation funds.

This bill gives effect to the government's 1998 budget changes to the regulation of small superannuation funds and to a recommendation of the financial system inquiry known as the Wallis inquiry. It amends the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act of 1993, or SI(S) Act, and a range of other related financial services, taxation and superannuation acts, firstly, to establish a new category of small superannuation fund with fewer than five members, to be called a self-managed fund, where all the members of the fund must have a business or family relationship, that is, a non-arms-length relationship, and all of them must become trustees of the fund.

Secondly, it transfers the regulation of self-managed funds from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, or APRA, to the Australian Taxation Office, with effect from 1 July this year—so it is coming up very soon. Thirdly, it provides for a reduced supervisory levy, from $200 to a maximum of $50, to be payable by self-managed superannuation funds.

I have already said that this government ought to be condemned for the delay in introducing this measure which was first announced on 12 May last year—so its anniversary this year—but was not introduced to the parliament until 31 March. The generous Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp—and more on him later—released an exposure draft but provided only two weeks for interested parties to comment: a measly two weeks, when the government took almost a year to produce and release an exposure draft. That is nothing short of contemptuous. This delay has caused unnecessary uncertainty especially amongst small business owners.

Let me turn firstly to the new definition of self-managed superannuation funds and fund membership changes. The DIY superannuation funds are currently subject to less onerous prudential regulation than larger funds, which come under control of the SI(S) Act and its regulations. This is based on the presumption that most DIY fund members are closely associated with the fund and its trustees and are likely to be able to represent their own interests as non-arms-length members. Some 16 per cent, or approximately 30,000 of the 180,000 DIY funds, contain arms-length members—that is, members who are not closely related to the fund sponsors—who might not be able to protect their interests in the superannuation fund and who do not have the prudential protection of the regulator, APRA.

To overcome this potential problem the bill requires all members of a self-managed fund to be family members or business relations, on the assumption that family members or business partners will be able to look after their own interests. In addition, all fund members will be required to become trustees. A member who does not into one of those categories will be transferred out of the fund. Alternatively, the fund may not wish to be a self-managed fund, in which case it either has to appoint an independent trustee and be regulated by APRA or has the option of winding up.

The government has not provided any evidence in support of this change which will inconvenience many small superannuation funds, many of which are run by small businesses. While anecdotal evidence exists that some arms-length fund members may not have adequate protection of their interests, the government has not provided evidence of this. In addition, the bill will also force fund trustees to expel some arms-length fund members, potentially incurring substantial costs to the funds, its members and the transferring member.
