This has caused considerable consternation amongst those small businesses which operate a DIY fund.

However, there is also anecdotal evidence which suggests that some DIY funds may be using their fund assets for investments which are not in the long-term interest of arms-length members. So, in that instance, you have arms-length fund members having little protection, and they may benefit from these changes. We think that the government needs to justify its decision to change the status of self-managed superannuation fund members.

Secondly, I want to address the regulation transfer from APRA to the ATO. This has been described, let me say, by one highly regarded superannuation commentator as `like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank'. I have to say that the Taxation Office, for its part, has been at some pains to assure us that this is not the case. Small superannuation fund operators and their accountants or administrators are worried that the ATO not only will crack down on people allegedly rorting the system but also may take a stricter line with funds which appear to be operating within the law.

While this measure is in line with a Wallis inquiry recommendation, it appears to be based on the fact that it is impractical for APRA to do anything but superficially regulate these funds. APRA generally conducts field audits and would require large additional resources to have any hope of auditing the 180,000 DIY funds it currently regulates. By way of comparison and contrast, there are only 5,000 industry, retail, corporate and public sector funds.

The fact is that APRA, and the ISC before it, could not effectively regulate DIY funds which did lead to anecdotal evidence of abuse of investment rules and possible taxation rorts. Transfer of the regulation power to the ATO may curtail this if it is occurring. How ever, it is up to the government to provide evidence that it is in fact occurring.

Before the Wallis inquiry, superannuation funds were only regulated by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, or ISC. The transfer of prudential regulation for self-managed super funds to the tax office will result in superannuation being regulated by three different entities—APRA, ATO and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, or ASIC. This, in my view, is in direct contrast with the main Wallis recommendation that essentially only two bodies—APRA and ASIC—should be responsible for the regulation of the financial services sector.

The third issue is that of a reduced supervising levy to be payable by self-managed super funds. Until the formation of APRA last year on 1 July, all superannuation funds paid $200 and larger funds paid a percentage of their assets to cover the costs of their regulation. APRA claims that the $200 paid by DIY funds cross-subsidised the prudential regulation of larger funds. Changes to the levy structure within APRA and the removal of the supposed cross-subsidy by capping the amount payable by the DIY funds to $50 have led to larger superannuation funds now paying substantially more in their prudential regulation levies. That means lower retirement incomes on the part of members of larger superannuation funds, who are more likely to be low and middle income earners. Very few low and middle income earners are in DIY funds, which are predominantly recommended to persons with more than $100,000 to invest, although some may be arms-length members.

There has been little evidence produced to date to support the argument that DIY fund levies were subsidising larger superannuation funds. The government is using the lowering of levies for self-managed funds as an offset to other changes, including changes to investment rules which are the subject of a draft Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1999, the one which deals with the investment rules. This bill raises more questions than answers. It should be subject to a thorough investigation by a Senate committee. The principal aims of the bill are to protect arms-length members, essentially by eliminat ing them, and to bring self-managed funds into closer tax scrutiny. However, it is still not clear whether this change is necessary.

I have received correspondence from a range of industry practitioners, who have raised some technical deficiencies, which I will touch on here but which may best be raised and considered by a Senate committee inquiring into and conducting hearings concerning the bill. One of the key issues appears to be that if a fund is forced to transfer an arms-length member out of the fund because that person is not a trustee it could trigger a capital gains tax liability for the fund, the member or both. The question arises as to whether the government should provide rollover relief if a capital gains tax liability is triggered.

In addition, the Australian Taxpayers Association has raised the issue of the size of the self-managed funds being less than five members. What if a family has three members who are members of the fund? This could present problems in certain situations. The issue has also arisen as to whether there could be a clash with another piece of legislation, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , which provides provisions for fund trustees to accept binding death benefit nominations. Under the current law governing excluded funds, a same sex partner may be able to be nominated as a dependant for the purposes of receiving death benefits. However, under the new rules the same sex partner may not be able to be nominated in the same manner. This issue has been raised by the private member's bill of the member for Grayndler and is one which perhaps should be examined further in the context of this bill.

The issue of single trustee funds has also been raised as an issue which is worthy of further examination. The explanatory memorandum states that changes to the superannuation supervisory levy are expected to have a budget revenue cost of around $19 million on each of the financial years 1999-2000 to 2001-02. However, the Treasury stated in a briefing on this bill that they expect this revenue to be recouped through user charging principles applied by the tax office and by APRA. So the opposition will not be oppos ing the government's bill. Instead we will refer it to a Senate committee for examination. Whatever the merits of this bill, it is disappointing that the government has kept the DIY funds waiting for so long on an uncertain footing. The government ought to be condemned by this House for doing so.

In the period since the government made its announcement—back in the budget of last year, in fact—there was evidence that the rate of increase in the establishment of do-it-yourself superannuation funds had declined by half, from 1,000 to 500 each week. This was reported in the 1999 edition of Superfunds in an article by Susan Hely which went on to say:

The main reason behind the decline is the new investment rules announced in May 1998, according to Daniel Butler of Daniel Butler and Associates, who . . . said that the superannuation surcharge had also been a significant factor.

So it is significant to note that there has been that dip in the growth of DIY funds since the government made this announcement. I also draw the attention of the House to a report by Michael Laurence concerning the issue of changes in the superannuation rules. This article was entitled, Super rules, super anger . He stated:

North Queensland financial planner Kevin Hardwick is deeply disturbed by successive federal coalition proposals that are eroding the tax advantages of all super, particularly DIY schemes. "What is happening is a tragedy for country towns," says Hardwick . . .

"In rural Queensland, self-managed funds invest in the local economies," Hardwick says. "They buy the premises of the local panel-beating shops and banks to act as landlords. The funds buy blocks of land to develop and to generate eventual retirement income. Local builders and other businesses get all of the associated work."
They were very concerned about the impact of government changes. I will quote once more from Michael Forsdick who said:

The tax breaks of super are simply disappearing. The tax package all but removes the tax benefits of super for those earning less than $75,000; those earning above $75,000 already get precious few tax breaks from super anyway. Superannuation is being hammered.
The article continues:

In interviews with eight super specialists, highly emotive words were used to describe the coalition's super measures since coming to office; for example, `attack by stealth', `doesn't realise the implications of what it is doing', `another nail in super's coffin'.

This is the very strong language used by those who are familiar with the changes made by this government to superannuation. In addition, in this area, I received—and no doubt other members received—correspondence from a number of bodies which are familiar with and concerned by these changes. For example, in March of this year I received correspondence from Managed Superannuation Services with the heading `Proposed changes to superannuation fund investment rules creating confusion and eroding confidence'. They said:

We are writing to you because we are concerned about and committed to encouraging growth, competition and confidence in our superannuation system—concern and commitment that we fear are not shared by the Federal Government.
They then talked about their own company, and said:

By way of background, we are a superannuation administration and advisory company providing services to and representing the trustees of more than 2,000 superannuation funds, which in turn comprise in excess of 10,000 members. The majority of those funds are representative of the small business community, with a substantial exposure to the regional and rural sector.

We are disheartened and frustrated by the Government's apparent lack of regard for such an important issue as superannuation. This was exemplified last May when the Government announced in its Budget that new investment rules would apply to superannuation funds.

That is an example of the concern which they were expressing. They pointed out that, in the 10 months since those measures were announced, there had been no supporting legislation and it had put fund trustees in a most invidious position. They said:
. . . it is unclear exactly how the measures are intended to apply and superannuation fund trustees have been left with the following options:
. to defer any investment decisions until the relevant legislation is introduced;
. to only invest in areas that are potentially beyond the scope of the new restrictions; or
. to continue to make investments in line with an existing strategy but in an environment of total uncertainty.
None of those options is desirable.

It was really unfair to trustees that the government was putting them in that position for a period in excess of 10 months. It was quite unconscionable putting fund trustees in an impossible position, not knowing whether to continue their investment strategy or change it. This problem was also described by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants as requiring the small funds to drive blindfolded:
Businesses and families have been unable to make sound decisions about their savings because they haven't been able to see everything that the Government is planning to do to their super funds.

Eventually, what we got was a backflip on those aspects of the budget announcement. It was quite clear to those of us who had been following this debate that Treasurer Costello had been rolled by small business minister Peter Reith. Frankly, the Treasurer had only himself to blame, given that the delay in acting on the budget announcement was quite unconscionable and trustees had been put in that situation. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business could not resist visiting the scene of the crime. One day after the Assistant Treasurer put out the press release indicating the backflip, the minister for small business put out his own press release regarding the small business superannuation backflip.

I think one of the difficult things about superannuation that we are experiencing in Australia at the moment is that the minister responsible for superannuation, the Assistant Treasurer, simply does not have the credibility in the superannuation community or the standing within the government to ensure that superannuation is treated with proper respect and proper accord.

I note, for example, that recently in the Financial Review, concerning the disastrous handling by the government of the high rollers amendment for casinos in relation to the GST, the Assistant Treasurer was described as `pleasant but lightweight'. I think that a lot of people in the superannuation industry would prefer to have a minister who was unpleasant but heavyweight—and there are a few around the parliament on both sides, I have to say!

One of the problems for superannuation in Australia in the last couple of years has simply been that the minister has been incapable of having superannuation treated appropriately seriously by this government. Indeed, in recent times the Assistant Treasurer has become something of a laughing stock as a result of his defence on the 7.30 Report and in other places of the government's GST legislation in relation to casinos. People like John Laws made him an object of contempt and ridicule, frankly, for his weak defence of what the government was doing in relation to the GST.

To conclude, we will not be opposing this legislation in the House. We will be supporting its referral to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, with a view to considering the technical issues which are raised by it and giving anyone who is concerned by any of its provisions the opportunity to appear before the Senate committee and raise those issues so they can be properly considered before the legislation is finally passed.

talk.start.para: —Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—In opposing the opposition's amendment and in speaking to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1999 , I start by referring to last evening's budget. It was amply demonstrated last evening when the Treasurer delivered his fourth budget that this government is committed to ensuring that Australia provides a financially secure environment that will prosper, grow and provide greater opportunities for all Australians both now and in the future.

speech.para: The Costello budget also demonstrated this government's commitment to reform—reforms in the tax system, in health, in education, in the workplace and in the financial system. Our commitment to regulatory reforms in the corporate and financial sector has already paid dividends in the ability of our financial institutions, including our banks, to withstand the Asian downturn. Our emphasis on the financial services industry, with a budget commitment of $7 million of funding for initiatives to promote Australia as a centre for global financial services, is a testament to the reform agenda that was undertaken as soon as the coalition came into government.

It was back in June 1996 that the Treasurer established the financial systems inquiry with a mission to provide a stocktake of the results arising from the financial deregulation of the Australian financial system since the early 1980s. The forces driving further change were to be analysed and recommendations were to be made on the nature of the regulatory arrangements that would best ensure an efficient, responsive and competitive financial system to underpin strong economic performance consistent with financial stability, prudence, integrity and fairness.

The report that resulted from this inquiry into the finance industry made a series of recommendations in the area of financial regulation designed to improve market conduct, disclosure, safety, stability, competition and competitiveness. Pertinent to this bill before the House, the inquiry made a number of recommendations concerning the regulation of superannuation funds. Not surprisingly, the administrative complexity of superannuation arrangements and compliance costs had been a matter of serious concern to both the industry and the consumers.

Given the expected growth in superannuation as a proportion of household and financial system assets and given the fact that superannuation is the largest component of the funds management industry in this country, reforms leading to improvements in the regulatory framework for superannuation funds have been a priority of this government. Australia finds itself in company with all other industrialised nations where ageing populations are placing increasing pressure on government funded pensions and programs. We are about to experience a huge demographic shock as the population over the age of 65 increases and the population paying tax decreases, and the consequential number of retirees in our society will have profound implications on the economic and fiscal wellbeing of our ageing population.

The government's commitment to superannuation reform is a response to this situation and is designed to encourage individuals to take greater responsibility for their retirement funding and to ensure that their retirement security is adequate to meet increases in life expectancy and to meet the saving challenges on those who retire early. We have the opportunity now to make changes to our superannuation legislation in order that individuals can take this greater responsibility for the management of their funds and can protect their particular interests. The timing is opportune as the baby boomer generation swirls the ranks of the aged and the retirees simultaneously deplete the ranks of the working population as they resort to their retirement funding.

The government has acted on the recommendations of the inquiry and, in the 1998-99 budget, announced changes to the regulation of self-managed superannuation funds known as excluded superannuation funds. An exposure draft was released for public comment and industry consultation and numerous responses were received. This bill—No. 3—to amend the superannuation legislation gives effect to the 1998-99 budget announcements. It reflects the government's response to the financial systems inquiry as it pertained to small superannuation funds and the regulation of those funds. It takes account of the views of the large number of industry bodies who made submissions to the draft bill.

The issue addressed by this bill relates to excluded superannuation funds. The government's aim is to ensure that all members of excluded superannuation funds are able to better protect their interests. The objective is to amend the definition of an excluded superannuation fund. Put simply, it is a fund with fewer than five members. Excluded superannuation funds are subject to less onerous prudential requirements under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, the SI(S) Act. This act regulates all superannuation entities, including industry funds, public offer funds, employer related funds as well as excluded superannuation funds.

Excluded funds are exempted from onerous requirements, such as the requirement to establish internal complaints resolution systems, the requirement to have a registered company auditor and many other detailed requirements for the reporting to members. Excluded funds are exempted from these requirements on the basis that members of the fund are capable of looking after their own interests. This is on the assumption that they are related—husband and wife or business partner arrangements and the like—and this is normally the case. In these situations, the members usually act as trustees and therefore have control or can manage the administration of the fund.

This is all well and good, but a situation has arisen over time where excluded superannuation funds have included members who are not in any position to protect their own interests, in that they have no control. This is because the definition of excluded funds does not currently require a relationship or a particular common interest between members, and it does not have any requirement or does not ensure that all fund members have equal power or influence within the fund.

The obvious examples where an excluded fund can include members who are not in a position to protect their own interests are where a family fund has been extended to include a non-related employee of the fund's employer/sponsor. The employee becomes an arms-length member. This person generally has no relationship with the other members and thereby lacks a commonality of interest with the other members. The situation also arises that, as the employee is not normally a trustee or related to a trustee, that person lacks the equality of influence or power within the fund and therefore is not able to be involved in trustee decision making and, consequently, is not able to adequately protect their interest, or is at least exposed to that very real possibility.

This bill amends the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act to establish this new category of small superannuation fund with fewer than five members, to be called a self- managed superannuation fund. The new definition of a self-managed superannuation fund will require that, in addition to the fund having fewer than five members, all members of the fund have a business or family relationship and be trustees of the fund.

According to the bill's explanatory memorandum, at present the number of excluded superannuation funds has grown rapidly from around 60,000 in 1991 to a current estimate of 180,000, representing some $42 billion in assets under management. Excluded superannuation funds comprise 97 per cent of the total number of funds but account for only 12 per cent of total industry assets and 1.8 per cent of fund members.

The annual return data from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority indicates that approximately 16 per cent of excluded superannuation funds contain arms-length members, that is, members who are not relatives or associates of trustees of the fund—so people who are not in a position, as we put it, to look after their own interests. Being excluded superannuation funds, they are exempted from the prudential requirements which in other circumstances would give the protection of additional prudential requirements which are otherwise available to protect members in such a situation.

Therefore, the amendments will ensure that an excluded superannuation fund—to be renamed a self-managed superannuation fund—will contain only members who have a commonality of interest, either related or business partners, and that all members be trustees, and it provides the mechanism for all members of such a fund to be involved in trustee decision making. The amendments also ensure that any current excluded fund containing arms-length members who would be in need of prudential protection and do not choose to transfer those members out of the fund will not be classified as self-managed superannuation funds. They will remain regulated by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and, therefore, the prudential requirements from which small funds are usually exempt will apply to protect the interests of arms-length members in such funds.

The amendments provide an alternative, whereby such funds can transfer an arms-length member to a prudentially regulated fund in order to satisfy the definition of a self-managed superannuation fund with all members having commonality of interest. In essence, what this will mean is that members in excluded funds who are not trustees will be required to either transfer the arms-length members to another fund or have these members become trustees where it is possible in accordance with the act, or the excluded fund could cease to be an excluded fund and appoint an approved trustee within the meaning of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act or have the existing trustee become an approved trustee within the meaning of that act. It may well mean that approved trustee companies will see an increase in the number of small funds under their trusteeship. Arms-length members of an excluded fund can have their benefit transferred to a prudentially regulated superannuation fund and thus receive regular detailed reports, access to complaints resolution schemes and the like.

The regulation of self-managed superannuation funds will be transferred to the Australian Taxation Office from 1 July 1999. That is very soon. The regulation of all others remains with the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. The change in the definition will not impose a cost on all self-managed superannuation funds—rather only on the trustees of excluded superannuation funds that currently contain arms-length members. So it is confined to the 16 per cent. The extent of these costs will depend on whether the trustees decide to transfer the arms-length members to a prudentially regulated superannuation fund or whether the trustees wish to keep arms-length members in the fund and appoint an approved trustee.

As we move into the 21st century facing the great challenge of an ageing population living longer, we must focus on retirement savings and the protection and enhancement of them. This bill is another step in delivering an efficient, responsive and progressive framework for the regulation of self-managed superannuation funds with minimal prudential regulation, but is designed to protect the interests of fund members, to encourage involvement in the management of funds and to encourage savings for retirement with a view to increasing the returns to retirees as the fund members take responsibility for their investments.

The proposed changes give arms-length members far greater access to information about their superannuation benefits, whichever option an excluded fund takes in order to satisfy the new definition. These members will receive regular information about the operations and investments of their superannuation fund, and this will give them a clearer picture of how their superannuation benefits are being managed to provide a retirement income. They will also have access to regular and detailed member information ensuring that the member is better informed about the growth of their benefits and returns. So the amendments confer powers and the administration of relevant parts of the SI(S) Act on the Commissioner of Taxation, provide for annual returns to be lodged with the ATO and remove the application of the culpability test.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —A few days ago I received a phone call from the chief executive of the Heinz cannery in Eden. During that phone call, I was informed that Heinz had decided to close its Eden operation. As from 30 June, the Heinz Greenseas Tuna cannery in Eden will no longer exist and nor will the jobs of its nearly 150 employees. This news is devastating to those soon to be redundant employees. It is devastating to the families, devastating to the town of Eden and devastating to the entire region.

speech.para: In a region that is already suffering from low morale due to the untimely decline of its timber industry, the loss of this industry represents another blow to the Eden community, one that the community just cannot afford. The Eden community needs help and it needs help from government. However, as the community seeks this help, it is becoming more and more obvious who is prepared to rally behind them and who is not. The coalition government is.

Over the last few days Centrelink has begun providing an extensive information and support service, which includes seminars at the Heinz cannery site as well as two customer service officers dedicated specifically to people affected by this closure. I thank Minister Truss for his assistance in this regard. In the next few days, a Job Network touch screen will be installed in Eden to provide better access for workers in Eden to the thousands of jobs available on the system. I thank Minister Abbott for implementing this so quickly.

Today, a delegation from the Bega Valley Shire Council travelled to Canberra to meet with federal government ministers to talk about the big picture, to examine possibilities for Eden within various federal government portfolios. With the recent cutbacks in the timber industry due to irresponsible New South Wales Labor government policy, it is vital that we actively pursue alternative industries and alternative employment opportunities for the survival of the Eden region. I thank Ministers Tuckey, who is in the House tonight, Minchin and Moore for meeting with the council delegation today at such short notice, for giving their time and for their total understanding of the issues at hand. The delegation received strong support from all three ministers, and we are now able to pursue opportunities within each of the departments.

The coalition is prepared to rally behind the Eden community. But what of Labor? The Eden community has been fruitless in its attempts to talk to the Carr Labor government. Neither Carr nor any of his ministers have yet agreed to even speak to the people of Eden. The Eden community is busily seeking alternatives. One alternative that has the potential to pull the region out of this slump is the proposed naval ammunitioning facility and the multipurpose wharf. This project has the potential to attract a wide array of new industry to Eden and to provide the employment boost that Eden so desperately needs. In the budget brought down by the Treasurer last night, $3.58 million was committed to doing the necessary preliminary work on this project. The coalition is behind the Eden community.

I am very disappointed in Heinz. They have operated the Eden cannery for 25 years, and it was there for 25 years prior to that. I understand businesses make certain commercial decisions, but I believe they have done the wrong thing by the Eden community by giving them virtually no notice. There are various new industry ideas for Eden, but we need more time to develop them. Heinz should have given us at least six months, if not 12 months, notice of closure. We could have had a number of these things under way in that time, but less than two months I think was quite outrageous. I will be writing to them asking them to delay this closure so that we can provide some alternatives for the town.

I will be in Eden on Friday to talk with the community again, and I will have an officer from Invest Australia with me to provide the community with information on how they can assist. The community really is in shock, I think it would be best described, and I can very much understand some of the reactions from many people. I was in Eden last week and certainly people were very angry. Even young school children were putting petitions around, and I admire them for what they were doing in that respect to bring that community together. It is a very resilient community. It has suffered a lot of blows in the past, but there are so many superb natural features in the region.

I am very confident we will work this through. Certainly, with the assistance of a variety of ministers and departments at a federal level, they will make great gains there. I think Heinz have a responsibility to the community in which they have been operating for quite some time to do the right thing and help the community through this by giving us more time before they move that operation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight because I want to say a few words to recognise the life of a great Australian and a great Australian artist who died recently. I refer of course to Arthur Boyd. I had the great privilege of meeting Arthur Boyd at the time he was presenting to the nation Bundanon, a wonderful property on the Shoalhaven which he so generously donated and which has been transformed by the Bundanon Trust into a great cultural centre for the creation and presentation of the arts.

speech.para: What many people may not know is that later in that year Arthur Boyd assigned the copyright on all his works equally to his children and to the nation so that the revenue which flowed from that might assist in funding the development of Bundanon. He was a person of great generosity—great generosity of spirit, great generosity financially. We are, as a nation, the richer for that. It was a pleasure for me on behalf of the Keating government to be able to provide the cheque for $5.4 million to the Bundanon Trust to develop and manage the property. I think the Australian people are going to get an enormous return on that investment, particularly as it is reinforced by the flow of revenue from those things which Arthur Boyd himself donated.

But, generous as that action was, significant as that contribution was, far and away the greater contribution was that which Arthur made through his art. It is art that is unquestionably at the forefront of world art. As well as Arthur being an outstanding Australian artist, he challenged and raised great ideas and great issues in his art. He asked questions that were very profound and very difficult. He did not pretend that he knew the answers to all the questions, but he raised things that a country is enhanced by considering. He did it in a way that was very beautiful. You did not have to get into the ideas, you could just enjoy the beautiful work. You do not have to go to art galleries to see it. I think one of the great things about Australia is the way in which it is possible to see in public buildings great works of art. The Victorian Arts Centre has a wonderful display of the Shoalhaven series of Arthur Boyd's paintings—or it did the last time I was there—and has done for many years. It is there on display for Australians to enjoy. That is what Arthur would have wanted.

He presented a great face of Australia to the world. He was an international artist, an artist internationally renowned. He was described most recently as the Australian Chagall. Whether that is fair to Arthur or to Chagall many people can have wonderful debates about—I am not really concerned. All I want to say is that he was an artist that the world saw as a leading exponent, and he was recognised as an outstanding Australian in a generation of great artists, particularly his friend Sir Sidney Nolan. They between them significantly changed European, American and particularly British views about Australia and Australian art in the way that before them Tom Roberts, Arthur Streeton and the Heidelberg School did.

Every nation to be great needs diverse sources of inspiration, diverse opportunities for people to develop and display their talent. In Australia we take great pride in the success of our sporting people, and we should. We take great pride when Australians win Nobel prizes for science, as Peter Doherty did recently, and we should. We do not always give due recognition when Australians are recognised internationally as outstanding artists. We produce many across the broad field of the arts; none greater in this generation that is just passing than Arthur Boyd. He was a fine artist. He was a great Australian. I was privileged to know him and to meet with his wife, Yvonne, and his daughter, Polly. I think Australia is the poorer for his passing.

talk.start.para: —May I identify the parliament with the remarks made by the member for Fraser. As the Speaker, my office is the gentler and the more colourful for the two Boyds that hang in it. Thank you.

—I rise tonight to regale the House with a tale of three preambles: the preamble to the Native Title Act, the preamble to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) and, of course, the Prime Minister's draft preamble to our Constitution. The first preamble I will speak about is one universally celebrated by members opposite, applauded by a large section of the media and embraced by all good, self-respecting, politically correct ideologues. These social democrats and small `l' liberals—not to be confused with my coalition colleagues—could barely contain themselves as they shouted aloud to the world that the preamble captured for eternity the ultimate and most accurate expression of the unique place this nation's `original inhabitants' held in our society and in our history. I would like to quote one person heavily involved in the conception of the preamble to the Native Title Act:

speech.para: It is quite a splendid preamble because, for the first time, along with the recent ATSIC Bill, it tells the truth about the history of this nation—the history that we ought to own. It says:
The people whose descendants are now known as Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders were the inhabitants of Australia before European settlement.
I ask you to note, Mr Speaker, that this quote uses the word `inhabitants', not the words `custodians' or `occupants'. To continue to quote this person:
I do not find this preamble one bit odious. In fact, I wish what it said had been enshrined in our constitution.

Note: `enshrined in our constitution'. The speaker was of course none other than the then senator and Leader of the Australian Democrats, the current member for Dickson. She fervently uttered these words on 17 December 1993 during debate on the Native Title Bill 1993.

What I think personally about the issue of the preamble to our Constitution is not important, but what sickens me is the ugly criticism of the Prime Minister by people who cannot hold a principled or consistent position themselves. When I first read that passage from Hansard and then looked back at the preambles to the ATSIC Act and the Native Title Act, I must say that I was stunned—stunned by the sheer hypocrisy, cant and duplicity of my colleagues opposite.
Let me remind you what the Prime Minister's draft preamble—the third preamble in this tale of mine—says about indigenous people:
Since time immemorial our land has been inhabited—
note the word `inhabited'—
by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, who are honoured for their ancient and continuing cultures.

One would think that Labor and the Democrats, when drafting a preamble to the Native Title Act, would not have been afraid to let loose their inhibitions and pen poetry. Why not indulge their bent for words other than `inhabitants', words like `custodians' and `occupants'? They used the word `inhabitants' three times in the Native Title Act preamble, and there was not a mention of `custodian' or `occupant'. I will tell you why they did not use those words. It is because `inhabitants' was, and remains, an adequate and accurate choice of words to describe the circumstances in question. If `inhabitants' was the first choice for the preamble to the Native Title Act itself, then why would it not be preferred for our Constitution preamble? After all, at the time the member for Dickson thought it was so catchy and endearing that she wished to promote it into our Constitution. Now the Prime Minister has given her the chance to make that wistful thinking reality, and she turns her back on it.

The second preamble I mentioned earlier was another which the then Senator Kernot took a liking to when, on 22 November 1993, in speaking to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993, she said:
This is an improved version of the preamble which was removed from the original ATSIC Bill.
You might ask why it was improved. She goes on to answer that question when she says:
It talks about how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders were the inhabitants of Australia before European settlement.

So `inhabitants' is good enough for two preambles structured by the ALP and the Democrats, but not good enough for the member for Dickson to use in a preamble to our Constitution. Is it because the thought police have taken the thesauruses away from the members opposite or is it because they are devoid of any consistency and originality that they oppose everything for opposition's sake? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On Anzac Day recently we recognised those who fought, suffered and died in defence of the freedom we all enjoy today. Australians have fought on distant shores since before the turn of the century and gone into battle in both world wars and later the Korea, Malaya and Vietnam conflicts. Yet on Anzac Day I met and spoke with some of those who are still fighting for recognition for their wartime efforts. They did not see active combat but were trained and prepared to go to war. They are the Australian servicemen affectionately dubbed nashos—there are over 200,000 of them.

speech.para: Let us not forget they too served their country. It involved personal sacrifices and in many cases interfered with people's careers. It changed the direction of their lives and often disrupted their families. It is long overdue that their efforts be formally recognised. All they ask is for government recognition in the form of a medal for national servicemen. It is not a competition between the value of one type of medal over another. It is a question of national recognition of service to the nation. Yet they remain disillusioned and frustrated in their attempts to have their military service in Australia acknowledged.

I was approached by several national servicemen at the Anzac Day services I attended in my home town in the beautiful village of Forth and nearby Ulverstone. They are disillusioned because they are still being ignored and frustrated and because they still have nothing to show for their service. Instead of taking their place in Anzac Day marches many take a back seat. Would it not be far better—and I am sure they would be much happier—for them to be seen carrying on the Anzac tradition?

The former Minister for Veterans' Affairs and, I would assume, this government know well what I am talking about. Last year national servicemen made representations to the former minister Bronwyn Bishop, seeking recognition for their service, but I am sorry to say—although not at all surprised—they received short shrift. The minister said in correspondence of 2 October 1998:
. . . that National Service was no more demanding than normal peacetime service and does not in its own right warrant the award of a medal.

What the minister failed to realise was that national servicemen are not arguing that their service was more demanding than normal peacetime service—although a case could be put to argue the contrary—but that normal peacetime service is voluntary whereas national service was compulsory. National servicemen had no choice.

Understandably, national servicemen were not satisfied and were angered by the former minister's response. Let us hope the current Minister for Veterans' Affairs takes a more understanding and compassionate view. Let him consider, as an example, the efforts of conscripted military personnel who served in Australia during the Vietnam War. They were called up in the belief that a direct military threat to Australia existed, as determined by three consecutive prime ministers. Sir Robert Menzies told this very House, on 29 April 1965, that the takeover of South Vietnam would be a direct military threat to Australia and all countries of South and South-East Asia. Prime Minister Holt said, in The Australian Military Forces Pocketbook issued in 1967:
. . . we here in Australia could soon find ourselves facing aggressive communism close to our shores.

In 1968 the cabinet of Prime Minister John Gorton gave serious consideration to Australia developing a nuclear capability because of the fear of attack on Australia by Indonesia and China. This information was only made public this year, under freedom of information.

Our national servicemen of that era were conscripted, trained and prepared for war. They had comrades killed. They were criticised, harassed and attacked by fellow Australians for serving Australia during the war. Indeed, their preparation for war was not only physical but psychological, making it all the more real even though they did not see active combat. In the case of the Vietnam War, it is a case of fairness and equity for national servicemen—a recognition of their military service in Australia.

For this reason I ask the minister to undertake an independent review of medals and recognition of our national servicemen. It could follow the lead of the Tasmanian branch of the RSL, which raised the matter at its recent state congress. It highlighted the depth of feeling over the issue. After considerable debate, the state congress passed a motion that a medal be issued to all persons who have served their country in the armed forces within Australia since 1945 and that a bar be attached recognising their type of service. This motion will be put to the RSL's national congress in Hobart in September.

This government would do well to show some leadership on this important issue and not simply put it in the too-hard basket. I am sure our national servicemen will not give up their fight for recognition—and nor should they.

talk.start.para: —I want to draw to the attention of the House the results of the landmark report called Tracking Australia , under the outstanding chairmanship of the member for Hinkler, who is in the House. I wish to draw to the attention of the House the upgrade work on the standard gauge between Geringhap and Ararat, through the heartland of the electorate of Corangamite and in particular the Pura Pura—Maroona track. On 29 April this year I visited that work and observed Transfield, a private sector company that is doing an outstanding job in terms of quality and efficiency in upgrading that track. It is using a modern wonder, an $8 million sleeper laying machine, the SMD80, which lays the tracks and the sleepers and puts the rails in position. Attending on that occasion was Peter Parkinson, the human resources manager of Transfield; John Sutton, CEO of VicTrack; Russell Trevaskis of VicTrack; local members of parliament Dennis Napthine and Bruce Chamberlain, and councillors of the rural city of Ararat.

speech.para: The key element of our visit was the exciting cooperation—and I mean that with all sincerity—between the federal and state governments in deciding to fund the upgrade of this particular section of national gauge track from Pura Pura to Moroona as part of the Adelaide-Melbourne standard gauge. The major problems of this section are well known to members of this House. Under the One Nation program of the previous government some $412 million was spent. I concede that they did a good job in making the standard gauge from Perth to Brisbane. But some other sections of the track were very poor, and in particular this track was very substandard. The objective is to get the track speed to 115 kilometres per hour for passenger trains and to 100 kilometres per hour for freight trains.

This follows on from an inspection that the chair of the Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform, who is in the House, the committee and I undertook in June 1998 where we looked at the Moroona to Pura Pura section where the sleepers were stacked on the side of the track, the rail was poor and there was mud underneath the sleepers. It was an absolute disaster. We drew that to the attention of this House. The committee recommended that the government spend $750 million over three years to improve the standard track around Australia, because to date the speeds on this standard track had been only 50 kilometres per hour, especially on this track.

The really exciting part about this visit is finding that the Victorian government is spending $15 million and the federal government is spending $8 million to upgrade this 44 kilometres of sleepered track in a cooperative venture. The track is being improved with new rail from the old rail, and approximately 70,000 concrete sleepers are being laid. They had been sitting stacked up on the side of the track for the last two or three years—the chairman and I well remember that. And new ballasts are being laid at the correct depth. The project is being managed by VicTrack and, more importantly, 30 local people are being employed.

We have in the gallery tonight some people who are interested in train travel: Greg and Heidi Wane, who come from the electorate of Corangamite at Ocean Grove. They produce a magazine called the Whistler News and use West Coast Rail to transport their publication from Terang in western Victoria. West Coast Rail is a very efficient privatised railway from Melbourne to Warrnambool. The Wanes use that particular railway for their business.

Also in the gallery we have future train travellers who might be in the Ghan and the Overland on this new track going from Melbourne to Geelong—through Cressy and the heartland of Corangamite along those flat planes. They are my daughter Sarah and my sons James and Andrew, with their friends Adam, Becky and Nichole Hounsell. Today they sang Waltzing Matilda at an international gathering held at the Polish Embassy. In the future they could provide Australia's traditional song to the train travellers of the future on the Melbourne-Adelaide run. And on that occasion it will take only nine hours, not the 13 hours it now takes on this substandard track.

subdebateinfo.title: Westralia Airports Corporation: Draft Master Plan

talk.start.para: —Going from trains, I would like to move on to planes. The Westralia Airports Corporation recently established a draft master plan for the future use of Perth airport and the probable impact of this expansion on the community over the next 20 years. This is a critical document. By and large it details significant movements in traffic and the effects on the local community into the next century.

speech.para: Prior to the last election, the corporation submitted this plan to the then federal transport minister, Mark Vaile, for approval. The minister, on advice from Airservices Australia, rejected parts of the document on the basis that they believed that projections of traffic levels on the proposed parallel runway would be unrealistic. Airservices Australia called for traffic to be transferred to the main runway and for the submission of a new Australian noise expectation footprint, ANEF.

It is this new forecast which has particularly caused difficulty for the people of the city of Canning. Vast areas of the city will, under the new ANEF projections, suffer a dramatic increase in noise; so much so that, according to the Australian standards, some residential properties would not be fit for human habitation. As a result of this new forecast, the state's housing department, Homeswest, has suggested, for example, that its entire urban renewal program for Queens Park may be at risk if this plan is approved.

When the ANEF map was produced, the Westralia Airports Corporation wrote to the City of Canning and gave them four days to respond to these new dramatic projections. Yes, Mr Speaker, four days to respond to a plan which has the potential to affect the lives of thousands upon thousands of residents. Obviously this is not enough time to consult with the people. Those who had previously considered they were not affected unduly and who had not made submissions or comments should now be given the opportunity in light of these new forecasts.

I would like to acknowledge the presence today of the Mayor of the City of Canning, Dr Mick Lekias, and the chief executive officer, Mr Ian Kinner, who have considered this matter to be of such importance that they have flown from Perth to attend a meeting I arranged with the Minister for Transport and Regional Services earlier tonight regarding this issue. In fact, that meeting is progressing as I am here addressing you tonight. I would also like to thank the minister for agreeing to this meeting and for considering the views of local representatives.

In response to these proposals and to the noise issue in general, there have been a number of events organised by the local community and local government concerning this document. I have attended these meetings and also supplemented these meetings by assisting in the information flow, detailing possible action and developing responses. I can report to this House that, at the numerous meetings in the community, hundreds of people attended who expressed concerns with the new proposals. I have tabled petitions today concerning this issue where over 4,500 people have called for action. My office has also received hundreds of phone calls, faxes and visits by concerned residents. It is sad that no member of the government has been involved in these initiatives or attended any of the public meetings, despite being encouraged to do so.

Let me finish by indicating what I believe would be the most appropriate course of action. The draft master plan must be put on hold, as requested by the City of Canning, for a period of three months to allow for further community consultation as the 18 May date of certification is too narrow a time frame to allow adequate input. The minister should visit the local area to understand the importance of the issue to the local community.

The federal government should introduce a noise amelioration program for Perth International Airport to address areas currently affected by aircraft noise and bring Perth International Airport within the ambit of the Aircraft Noise Levy Act 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Collection Act 1995. Prior to or contemporaneously with the signing of the Perth International Airport draft master plan the government should initiate a comprehensive social, economic and environmental study to examine the longer term ramifications of any proposed expansion of the airport with a view to implementing a compensation or other noise amelioration plan for areas identified as being affected.

We need to ensure that the local communities are informed, empowered and included in considering this plan in light of the current changes. Only then can the process of developing the airport be a success for both the Westralia Airports Corporation and the wider community.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 8 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

para.inline: House adjourned at 8.00 p.m.

debate.para: Mr Bevis to present a bill for an act to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to ensure that leave for participation in activities as a member of the Australian Defence Force Reserves be one of the matters which can be
taken to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for conciliation and arbitration.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on a publication called Airport Economics , written by Mr Leon Warren, who is a member of a Campbelltown anti-airport group. Mr Warren is one of many residents of Western Sydney who have taken a keen interest in the government's proposals to build Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek. One of the important issues addressed in Mr Warren's book is the suggestion that employment growth will result as a consequence of the second airport. On page 37, Mr Warren refers to a forecasting model used to estimate employment growth set out in the draft environmental impact statement on the Badgerys Creek airport. In this model it is suggested that the range of employment growth identified in Australia and overseas studies is between 500 and 800 passengers per job for direct employment and between 400 and 700 passengers per job for indirect employment. Mr Warren, in reference to this modelling, said:

speech.para: The model in this case is subject to both airports in Sydney operating at their maximum capacity. The assumption suggests that employers increase their staffing levels automatically each time they exceed 400 or 800 parameters. It does not take into account improved productivity gains and increased workloads that would be borne by existing staff.
Take banks, for instance, even though their profits and the gross national product has been rising, banks are shedding staff and closing branches all over Australia.

Reference is made in this book to the general fall of employment in the aircraft industry. The FAC annual report shows that in 1996-97 the total work force in this industry was 1,180 compared to the 1992-93 figure of 1,366. At the same time passengers per employee rose from 34,271 in 1992-93 to 51,316 in 1996-97. As to whether Badgerys Creek airport will generate a large number of jobs, we have only to look at the promise of jobs made in the EIS into the third runway. I quote from Mr Warren's book:

The Department of Arts, Sports, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, in its environmental assessment report on the third runway, noted that an estimated 17,500 jobs could be generated in the airport subregion between 1995 and 2010 as a result of the operation of the new runway, with a further 27,000 jobs generated in the wider Sydney region.

No attempt has been made to measure the employment impact of the third runway, but productivity gains and reduced employment numbers reported by the FAC and airlines would indicate that there has been no employment gains.
I would like to congratulate Mr Warren on his important contribution to the Badgerys Creek airport debate and wish him and his organisation well in their future campaign.

talk.start.para: —I want to address the committee on two meetings—and their ramifications—held in the community of Gatton recently. The issue concerns the further development of the Gatton campus of the University of Queensland. The first meeting was held at the Gatton shire hall—there were about 50 people in attendance—and was addressed by Craig Pearson, the Chief Executive Officer of Gatton campus, a former CEO and various other local dignitaries, including Bernie Sutton, the mayor of Gatton Shire and the former Deputy Premier of Queensland, Bill Gunn.

speech.para: The reason for this meeting was anger at what is perceived to be the demise of the Gatton campus of the University of Queensland. This is an important facility. When it was taken into the University of Queensland, it was done on the understanding that a leading facility would be developed at Gatton—a facility that would lead Australian health and agricultural research into the next millennium.

That, unfortunately, has not happened. What we see out there is growing concern at what is perceived to be the demise of the college. It seems that academics at St Lucia would like to see that University of Queensland involvement in agriculture and veterinary sciences consolidated into the St Lucia campus for their own academic ends. I do not think that is something that industry groups in agriculture and with veterinary concerns would support. I would like to see further support for the maintenance of the University of Queensland Gatton campus.

It was a great relief to me last night to see the investment that the government is planning to make in relation to research into genetics. It seems that, for example, the government understands what the university does not and that genetics is a revolution that is waiting to happen. We need a great deal of academic research and investment in that area. Since then there has been a meeting between representatives of the University of Queensland Gatton campus and the Premier of Queensland, Mr Beattie. Unfortunately, there has not been entirely a positive outcome. People who are concerned about the needs of agricultural industries in Queensland have to stand up and come forward and speak to the Premier. I have certainly spoken to the federal education minister, Dr Kemp, and I believe there is growing concern in this regard. I would like to see more members speaking up because, without support for agricultural research, we will be doomed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This government has continually applauded its efforts in introducing a Work for the Dole Scheme. It is a scheme that has targeted the most vulnerable, unemployed youth in Australia and a scheme that the government has expanded in this year's budget.

speech.para: The government expanded the Work for the Dole program and it is now targeting unemployed Australians aged between 25 and 34 years—Australians who this government has failed, Australians who cannot find a job. It is a program that is penalising the victims of unemployment. Unlike the LEAP and Jobskills programs that Labor had in place, it does not provide any formal training. The people that are involved in the Work for the Dole program go away with nothing. They do not go away with any training that they will be able to take to another job. It is rather about the mutual obligation that these young unemployed Australians have to receive their money and not about assisting them to move from welfare to work.

I have had a number of young people in my electorate come to see me about problems that they have been experiencing with Work for the Dole. There was a young girl who has put a lot of effort into retraining and preparing herself to enter the work force. She has undertaken secretarial and receptionist courses. She is working voluntarily for some agencies within the area, but she is not doing enough hours to satisfy the requirement that would prevent her from having to work for the dole, so she has been directed to do labouring work building a bridge. This is a young person who has used her initiative to train and prepare herself to enter the work force in her chosen field but, because of the program this government has in place, she is being forced to go out there, interrupt her preparation to enter the work force and build bridges.

Another young person came to see me very recently. I might add that it was the parents of these young people that contacted my office because they were so angry about the way their children and young people were being treated. A young boy went along to a session where they talked about the Work for the Dole program and signed up for it. What he signed up for was a labouring program but he thought he had signed up for a marketing program. He did not turn up for the labouring program because he was going along for the marketing program in a week. He had his youth allowance stopped simply because it was not explained to him fully. Once again, it was the most vulnerable people in society being penalised. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —If you had to name one aspect of our tax system that will leave Australia on the starting blocks as we enter the new century while others take advantage of exciting ages before us, it would have to be the level of capital gains tax in this country. Our current level of capital gains tax categorically ensures that Australia cannot compete with other countries when it comes to attracting the necessary venture capital. The fact that Australia has a wealth of intellectual assets in our scientists and researchers in areas such as health and agriculture and biotechnology makes this situation even more frustrating.

speech.para: It is time to follow the example of the US and the UK and significantly lower the rate of capital gains tax, particularly for R&D investments. Governments in these countries have recognised the need to remove tax disincentives, to invest in new companies and to create new and lasting job growth. Australia, in the words of one commentator, is in danger of becoming irrelevant in an area where it should be a leader. This is why American pension funds, which are the largest source of venture capital in the world, have not invested one cent in Australia. They have around $80 billion in capital to invest and most of it stays in the US, where investments held for longer than five years attract a capital gains tax of only 18 per cent. The rest goes to countries with similar generous capital gains tax levels.

These pension funds are probably the most prudent investors on the planet. Why, from a business point of view, would they invest money in ventures that are often high risk and take many painstaking years to yield results if, in the end, most of their returns are eaten up in tax? This also applies to Australian investors and, indeed, to the companies and researchers themselves.

We are risking the loss of our brightest innovators, who will simply take their business to countries that encourage and nurture R&D. What is the point of investing in the education of young Australians if they are not going to benefit from their enormous potential? Why become world leaders in health and research and biotechnology if we cannot profit from these developments? We cannot underestimate the impact of lower capital gains tax levels on jobs growth in Australia. As part of a business tax revolution that includes lowering the company tax to 30 per cent, I agree with BRW's Robert Gottliebsen when he predicts that, when we look back, this may be more significant than the GST. The problem has been identified by both the Ralph report and the health and medical research strategic review, chaired by Peter Wills. I hope the option of lowering the rate of capital gains tax, particularly for R&D investment, is transferred into legislation as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —I rise to register in the strongest possible terms my condemnation of the decision by government senators in consultation with and with the support of Senator Colston to oppose a Senate inquiry into the Brisbane Airport master plan. The details of this master plan are well known to the residents of Brisbane. Essentially, they involve the future construction of parallel runway which would have a huge impact on the residents of Brisbane's south side and north side—altogether some 100,000 persons.

speech.para: I register my condemnation for three basic reasons. The first is this, and it is perhaps the most important: to date we have not had any form of objective analysis by anybody as to any alternative runway option. We have simply had this one option put before us and had it said to the community, `Take it or leave it.' The only option therefore available to the rest of the community is to look to a Senate inquiry as a vehicle through which alternative runway options might be examined. The public at this stage do not have a database, do not have objective information on which they can be convinced that this is the only viable alternative for Brisbane's future air transport needs.

The second basis for my condemnation is this: Senator Colston, who supported government senators in the Senate on this matter, has absolutely no track record at all on airport matters in Brisbane—none whatsoever. It is simply an opportunistic intervention by him to support government senators in their hour of need in order to produce a 38-all vote and thereby prevent it from proceeding.

My third reason is this: it simply delays the day. The Senate numbers will change as of 1 July, and this motion will be put before the Senate again. It is at that stage when I look forward to this inquiry proceeding, its terms of reference being accepted and the prospect of public hearings being held across Brisbane's south side so that the truth of this matter and the interests of Brisbane's residents may be properly served.

talk.start.para: —On Thursday of last week, I had the opportunity to attend and witness the signing of a new home and community care agreement between the federal Minister for Aged Care, the Hon. Bronwyn Bishop MP, and South Australia's Minister for Disability Services, the Hon. Robert Lawson MLC. As the secretary of the government's health and aged care policy committee, it gave me great pleasure to be present at this event, as the care of our aged is a very important issue in my electorate of Makin.

speech.para: People in Makin and elsewhere want to have the opportunity to remain in their own homes for as long as possible without having to seek institution care. The new agreement signed last week will take effect from 1 July 1999. The Home and Community Care Program is a joint Commonwealth and state program which provides community care for frail, older Australians as well as for younger people with disabilities and their carers.

An amount of $823 million a year is spent on this worthy program, and, in my home state of South Australia, 55,000 people are assisted by the program, which provides home help such as cooking, cleaning and washing as well as transport, food services, personal care, community nursing, home maintenance and respite care. Home and community care funding in South Australia for this year is $72.6 million, representing $44.8 million from the Commonwealth and $27.8 million from the state government. This represented an increase of $2.2 million in the current year. I would like to take this opportunity to commend the South Australian government led by Premier John Olsen for agreeing to a contribution of $27.8 million for the Home and Community Care package, bringing the total funding to $72.6 million.

The most important aspects of the new agreement are: reduced duplication between the Commonwealth and state governments; increased service efficiency; emphasis on quality assurance and measuring standards; increased availability of post-acute care; and involvement of the private sector to ensure that the best possible providers are selected. These measures underline our commitment to ensuring the best possible care for our elderly and infirm. This commitment is further evidenced by the measures included in the Treasurer's `right for the times' budget, a budget for the new millennium. These measures include an enhanced primary care package for our older Australians and people with chronic conditions and, equally importantly, it contains more funding for respite care.

The Home and Community Care Program has allowed many people in my electorate of Makin to continue to live in their own homes while receiving the care that they need. This makes an enormous difference to their quality of life, their dignity and their happiness. I commend the government for expansion of this program and for the dignity and quality of life that it has made possible for so many people in my electorate of Makin.

talk.start.para: —I rise to acknowledge and commend the contribution to multiculturalism made by the National Multicultural Advisory Council in its recent report titled Australian multiculturalism for a new century: towards inclusiveness . The report, published in April 1999, was written, as I understand, after extensive community consultation. The report advocates an attitudinal change which, if Australians are to attain our national aspiration of social harmony, is absolutely necessary.

speech.para: The electorate of Lowe, which I am privileged to represent, is one of the most culturally diverse electorates, with some 40 per cent of the population being born overseas and more than 30 per cent being born of non-English-speaking background. Lowe has a large community from Italian, Greek, Chinese, Vietnamese, Korean, Lebanese and Sri Lankan backgrounds. The Lowe community prides itself on social harmony and warm acceptance of diverse customs and culture.
I am relieved to see that Australia has finally discarded its policy position of the 1950s, where a white Australia was the only politically acceptable Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded. The Main Committee will now consider government business.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 25 March, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —This debate deals with two related bills—the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999 and the Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 1999 . The first bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 by introducing a new reporting and registration scheme for bulk cargo consignments of high volume, low value cargo into Australia. The second bill proposes to amend the Import Processing Charges Act 1997 to reduce the screening charges to apply to those who register as special reporters under the scheme to be established by the first bill.

speech.para: The Customs Act requires pilots of aircraft and owners of ships to report to the Australian Customs Service information about cargo intended to be discharged at a port or an airport in Australia. The Australian Customs Services uses these reports to screen cargo and to carry out its responsibility to protect Australia against the importation of prohibited goods. The proposed reporting and registration scheme that these bills envisage is designed for high volume cargo such as documents and consolidated mail orders which are valued at less than $250 per consignment and transported by specialist operators. Currently, such consignments are reported at a consolidated level and the Australian Customs Service relies on physical random checks to inspect individual consignments.

The new scheme is intended to allow operators who register as `special reporters' to report cargo at a consolidated level, provided the ACS has access to their computer facilities where information relating to individual consignments is stored. Operators by registering would be aware and agree that the Australian Customs Service would have access to their relevant computer databases and would be able to make necessary privacy and security arrangements if this is a matter of concern to them.

The powers to the ACS under new subdivision D would ensure compliance by special reporters with the conditions and requirements in amendments to division 3 which establish the new registration and reporting scheme. These powers appear to be comparable to existing powers and provisions of the Customs Act which deal with search warrants in respect of things believed to be evidential material.

This scheme is intended, effectively, to enable a smoother transition of product of this nature through the border control, to enable Customs to work with those who are registered under the scheme to undertake appropriate checks through the course of their import. As the scheme will be less expensive to manage than the current arrangements, the government has made consequential proposals to reduce the charges for reporting under the new scheme. That, of course, is a consequential and, I assume, not unwelcome concession by the government in relation to the arrangements that they have proposed.

In relation to the working of Customs, this is an agency which is in considerable crisis at the moment. Customs has faced challenges which, plainly, it has failed to discharge, not the least being the two instances whereby large vessels sailed down the east coast of Australia and beached—one in Queensland and one in New South Wales—avoiding coastal surveillance. We are aware that there have been large and increasing consignments of illicit materials, particularly drugs, coming into this country at a rate which the government concedes is such that the availability and purity of those drugs is higher than ever before.

Of course, this has had consequences in Minister Vanstone's own administration of the department. Her department is operating with a crisis of morale. Within Customs, there is a real sense that the arrangements that the government has put in place necessary to provide support to them have been inadequate. There are now currently major inquiries being pursued as to the future arrangements that should apply in the area of the management of Customs resources. It is widely believed that Customs Minister Amanda Vanstone has lost the fight to prevent the breaking up of the Customs Service.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. While there is a cognate debate and therefore one would expect debate to range somewhat more widely than if the debate was on one bill only, what the honourable member is now saying is well beyond the purview of either bill. I ask you to ask him to come back to the legislation before the chamber.
—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration. In recalling the honourable member for Denison, I am sure he will stick to the contents of both bills.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is not within the standing orders to require, in relation to a debate on the second reading of the bill relating to Customs, that I not speak in relation to the administrative arrangement for Customs when these matters plainly flow from changes in the processing of arrangements internally in Customs.
—I will listen very careful to what the honourable member is saying. Please proceed.

—I was simply making the point that Customs is in crisis. It is widely reported that the minister has lost the fight to keep the Customs agency in the form it is now. There have been major breakdowns in the framework for the protection of Australia's border security. The arrangements in this bill are supported by the opposition; they are convenient and appropriate. But that should not prevent us, in a debate of this nature, drawing attention to the obvious fact that the agency that is the subject of this legislation is due for a major shake-up, and to ask how that shake-up is going to be effected.

speech.para: Reports that have been received from a number of sources suggest that the federal government is about to strip somewhere between 1,200 and 1,400 staff from the agency. There is an intention to create a new agency, Border Australia, to be set up with an amalgamation of these staff from Customs, 500 from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and 80 from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. And Customs is set to lose its commercial functions, which, reports suggest, will be transferred to the Department of Industry, Science and Resources, which will be responsible for the commercial side of Customs, for tariffs, antidumping and collections. So the functions now in this bill which are presently in the Customs agency will in fact be stripped from Customs and transferred to the Department of Industry, Science and Resources.

Moves in this direction were first proposed in a secret report to the Minister for Finance and Administration, John Fahey, in a bid to gain efficiencies and cost savings in border control. That so-called Sturgess report, named after its author Gary Sturgess, who is a former key adviser to the Greiner government, was handed to the Howard government last September. The secret report—the opposition has sought access to that report on a number of occasions and has been refused—is understood to have recommended the setting up of a single border agency and also to have been critical of the management of Customs. The report is also understood to have suggested that the new single border agency could be established outside the Public Service Act, with a corporate structure similar to that of Employment National, which of course has raised fears within the Customs Service of future outsourcing and privatisation. At the time of that report it is understood that Minister Vanstone opposed its implementation and succeeded in retaining the present structure. But the failures of Customs over recent times have weakened the minister's position.

The current government, after the recent election, has dusted off the recommendations of the Sturgess report.
